HEADLINE: THE STATE BUDGET: LEGISLATORS; 
Both Houses Defy Pataki, Passing Their Own Budget

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 30 

 BODY:
The State Legislature continued passing a budget today that would raise income taxes for the wealthiest New Yorkers, expand gambling in the state and collect sales taxes on Indian reservations, all part of its plan to restore spending on core services.
 The Legislature's plan to restore $1.9 billion worth of the cuts to education and Medicaid that Gov. George E. Pataki had proposed, would add about $2 billion in new state spending, taking the total budget higher than the $90.8 billion the governor wanted, but keeping it below the rate of inflation. 
 If the plan is complete by Friday, as legislators have promised, and if it survives a veto that Mr. Pataki has threatened, it will affect New Yorkers in countless ways. 
Shoppers would pay more for purchases because the plan would raise the state sales tax to 4.25 percent from 4 percent, at least for two years, when the plan calls for it to be phased out. Legislative leaders estimate that the tax increase would generate approximately $463 million in the first year and $564 million in the second.
Those at the high end of the income scale, about 5 percent of New York's population, would pay more income tax, legislative officials said, adding that 14 percent of all those affected live out of state. They said they expected hundreds of millions of dollars in annual new revenue to flow into the state treasury from various temporary tax surcharges on the wealthiest residents.
If legislators are correct, homeowners will escape a rise in their property taxes, something that many had feared would occur if the Pataki budget plan were enacted and local aid sharply cut.
And schools and health care providers would be spared drastic cuts, with programs like prekindergarten and small class size in the lower grades preserved.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said again today, however, that the Legislature's plan was more harmful, in the long run, to the economy -- and reiterated his promise that there would be political repercussions when all 212 of the Assembly and Senate members come up for re-election next year.
"This budget is one that as a matter of principle, I cannot support," the governor said at a morning event in which he appeared confident and even ebullient in the face of the legislative rebellion. "It is one that raises taxes by billions of dollars on every working family in every corner of the state."
But the state's top legislative leaders, Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader in the State Senate, and Sheldon Silver, the Democratic leader of the State Assembly, stood firm, and said they were making the decision not to foist onto local residents the property tax rises they believe the governor's cuts would have brought.
The Legislature continued, with machinelike efficiency, to pass the bills needed to make a budget, many by formidable margins. Both houses adopted a spending plan for education, higher education, labor and family assistance. That bill restored $1.1 billion worth of Mr. Pataki's proposed $1.4 billion in cuts in local aid to school districts, including $361 million for New York City, where all prekindergarten and class size cuts have been restored.
The average overall cut to individual school districts has been reduced to about 2.6 percent per district, from the roughly 8.6 percent under the governor's plan, those familiar with the legislation said.
In the health care arena, the Legislature, through a combination of restorations and adjustments to Mr. Pataki's proposed $1.4 billion worth of cuts to health services, including Medicaid, would provide $781.8 million for New York's patients and providers.
"We've ensured that the providers from hospitals, nursing homes and home health care will be able to deliver a reasonable health care system to New Yorkers," said Senator Kemp Hannon, a Republican from Nassau County, the chairman of the Senate's Committee on Health.
Over all, the Legislature cut $90 million in spending from the governor's budget. It eliminated about $250 million worth of the $1.4 billion in new taxes and fees the governor proposed. It plans to borrow $4.2 billion against tobacco settlement funds.
The revenue bill to pay for the restorations, and to cover what Mr. Pataki projected would be a $2.9 billion gap next year, was placed on the legislators' desks late Tuesday. It can come to a vote on Friday, under legislative rules.
Because local sales taxes are added to the state's tax, the rates around the state vary. With the state increase to 4.25 percent, the amount charged to shoppers in New York City would rise to 8.5 percent from 8.25 percent, the officials said, not counting a potential additional .25 percentage point increase in the city. On Long Island, the new rate would be 8.75 percent.
The income tax surcharge varies with income. For married couples who file jointly and earn more than $150,000 in net taxable income (meaning they would earn nearly $200,000 in gross income), the tax rate would go to 7.5 percent from its current 6.85 percent, then decline in each of the subsequent three years to 7.37 percent, 7.25 percent and then back to 6.85 percent, its current level.
In addition, households that earn more than $500,000 will pay .2 percent, or a 7.7 percent total increase, on income above that $500,000 level.
Income taxes would also rise for single people earning $100,000 a year in taxable income, and for heads of household who earn $125,000 in taxable income, with the scale of rates the same as for families.
In dollars, a household that earns about $165,000 in gross adjustable income, with a taxable income of $150,000, would see a tax bill increase of about $1,000, but about 25 percent of that would be returnable as a federal tax deduction, according to a legislative budget analyst.
Also included in the revenue bill is a plan to place video lottery terminals in thoroughbred and harness horse racing tracks in the state, allowing the tracks to keep more of the profits; a plan to enforce the collection of taxes on cigarettes and fuel sold on Indian reservations; and a plan to close three corporate loopholes.
The legislators will go along with a proposal by the governor to eliminate the state sales tax exemption on clothing under $110 for one year, but will lift the tax the next year.
Adopting an idea pushed by Mr. Bruno, the Legislature would allow the state to collect sales tax for sales over the Internet, a program that would bring in $100 million next year and up to $1 billion in the third year. It needs Congressional approval and action by the state's Tax Department as well.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Depression Rates Surveyed 

BYLINE:  By Richard Perez-Pena (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Hispanic and poor New Yorkers are more likely than other residents to suffer from "significant emotional distress," according to a survey released yesterday. In the survey of 10,000 residents by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, 6.4 percent of residents over all reported such distress, with symptoms like depression and anxiety. 
Among those with significant distress, 54 percent said they were also in poor or only fair physical health; among other New Yorkers, 17 percent said their health was poor or fair. Hispanics had a higher rate of emotional distress than other ethnic groups, at 11.9 percent, or nearly double the overall rate. Emotional problems were also more common among the unemployed and people with household incomes under $25,000. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)

HEADLINE: Martha Stewart Living Says Revenue Fell 14% in the Quarter 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said yesterday that it had posted a loss in the first quarter as government investigations into a stock sale by Ms. Stewart, its chairman and chief executive, cast a shadow across its business.
 With no sign that the investigations will be resolved soon, the company also warned yesterday that it expected to lose more money in the second quarter. Revenue is forecast to decline even more steeply as the company's television programs, magazines and product sales continue to struggle. 
 "The one thing we're carrying that no one else is is the long investigation and the negative press stories," the company's president, Sharon Patrick, said in an interview.
Total revenue fell 14.6 percent in the first quarter. Worst hit was publishing, with a 21 percent decline caused by lower ad sales and circulation. Merchandising, which consists mainly of Martha Stewart Everyday products sold at Kmart, dropped 7 percent. Television revenue also declined, by 1.4 percent, with lower ratings and lost airtime from the "CBS Early Show," where Ms. Stewart was a regular until last summer.
She left the show after CBS executives insisted on asking her questions about the investigation into her sale of nearly 4,000 shares of stock in ImClone Systems. The company was formerly run by her friend Samuel D. Waksal, who has since admitted committing securities fraud, perjury and other crimes. He is scheduled to be sentenced in June.
Ms. Stewart, who has not been charged with any crime, has said her sale was "entirely lawful" and took place because she and her stockbroker agreed to sell if the share price fell below $60. No evidence of an agreement has turned up, and the broker's assistant has admitted lying about the reasons for the sale. 
Revenue in the first quarter totaled $58 million, down from $68 million a year ago. At the same time, corporate costs jumped sharply, to $10.2 million from $8 million, mainly for legal fees and insurance to cover officers and directors. For shareholders, that means a loss of 9 cents a share in the quarter, which ended March 31, in contrast to earnings of 8 cents a share for the first quarter of last year.
"It's surprising just how long this negative period has lasted for them," said Laura Richardson, a principal with Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston, "and how difficult it is to pinpoint when we might get on to the next phase of things for them." 
It is unclear when the investigations, which are being conducted by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission, will conclude, but they are dragging down Ms. Stewart's company, executives say.
"The economy was difficult in 2001 and in the first part of 2002, and our magazine was doing very well," James Follo, the chief financial officer, said in an interview. "Ad pages were outperforming the market. So clearly there was a dramatic falloff once this investigation came up." 
In a conference call with analysts and investors, Ms. Stewart noted that during a similar call in March, she had described herself as "increasingly hopeful" that her situation would be resolved soon. 
"Obviously, that has not happened," she said yesterday, "and I can make no predictions as to when it will." She added that despite the problems, her company "remains a laboratory for creative thought and a place where ideas are generated into inspiration for the home and for the homemaker." 
Mr. Follo said the company would continue to introduce products and programs. "They may have slowed," he said, "but they haven't stopped." 
The share price, battered after Ms. Stewart's name surfaced in connection with the ImClone insider-trading investigation last summer, fell another 11.3 percent yesterday, to close at $8.68. 
In the current quarter, which ends June 30, the higher corporate costs are expected to continue, while merchandising revenue is expected to fall 30 percent as Kmart closes more stores around the country. Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has a guaranteed minimum payment from Kmart, but the difference between sales in stores and the guarantee will not be paid until early next year, Mr. Follo said, when Kmart's fiscal year ends. 
Neither he nor Ms. Stewart discussed the progress of the investigations in the conference call, although David A. Rocker, an investor who owns about 6 percent of the company, said at one point: "We're all eager to get this behind us."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Shares Decline Slightly to End a Month of Strong Gains

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks finished fractionally lower in a lackluster session yesterday, as investors weighed weak regional manufacturing data against cautious optimism about the economy from the top central banker.
 Still, the three main stock gauges finished April with their biggest monthly gains since the fourth quarter of 2002. 
 "The market is digesting further the major moves we've had," said Andrew Baker, senior Nasdaq trader for Wedbush Morgan in Los Angeles. 
With most first-quarter earnings out, "we have to see where the next few quarters take us," Mr. Baker said.
In testimony before the House of Representatives, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the economy seemed poised for a rebound with the end of the Iraq war, but expressed concern about a lingering caution among businesses.
His remarks before the House Committee on Financial Services gave investors only limited comfort as they studied a closely watched survey showing business in the Midwest contracted for a second month in April. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago business barometer fell to 47.6, below expectations for a reading of 48.9 and below 48.4 in March.
Tim Heekin, director for trading at Thomas Weisel Partners, said, "People viewed Greenspan's comments as neutral to slightly positive." The Chicago manufacturing data had less of an effect, he added.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 22.90 points, or 0.27 percent, at 8,480.09. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.92, or 0.10 percent, to 916.92. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 6.99 points, or 0.48 percent, at 1,464.31.
In April, the Dow climbed 6.1 percent, and the S.& P. 500 added 8.1 percent, their biggest monthly gains since October 2002. The Nasdaq jumped 9.2 percent, its biggest monthly gain since November 2002.
Trading was heavy, with about 1.78 billion shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, and 1.58 billion shares traded on the Nasdaq. Issues advancing outnumbered those declining by 20 to 13 on the Big Board, and by 9 to 7 on the Nasdaq.
After a sharp rally in stocks over the last seven weeks, investors want to see hard evidence that the economy and corporate profits are recovering, analysts said.
Better-than-expected first-quarter earnings have fanned optimism about the corporate profit outlook, propelling the S.& P. 500 index up for the month.
Jitters about corporate credibility resurfaced when Tyco International said it would take about $1.1 billion in after-tax charges in its second quarter after unearthing fresh accounting problems. Nonetheless, Tyco's stock rose 23 cents, or 1.5 percent, to $15.60; it was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Among losing issues, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia sank 11.3 percent after it said its first-quarter loss widened sharply from a year earlier, because of weak advertising at its flagship magazine and insider-trading allegations involving Ms. Stewart. The shares fell $1.11, to $8.68.
Shares of JDS Uniphase fell 2.7 percent, a day after it reported a quarterly loss amid the spending slowdown in the communications industry. JDS shares slipped 9 cents to $3.23 and ranked among the Nasdaq's most-active issues.
Duke Energy rose after the company said its quarterly earnings fell, but still managed to beat analysts' forecasts. Its stock rose 31 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $17.59.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Tax Cut Without Spending Reductions Could Be Damaging 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the economy was poised to grow without further large tax cuts, and that budget deficits resulting from lower taxes without offsetting reductions in spending could be damaging to the economy. Opponents of the large cut favored by President Bush took Mr. Greenspan's testimony as support for their position.
 Mr. Greenspan's statements to the House Financial Services Committee were made as new Treasury data showed that tax revenues have arrived at a much slower pace than expected this spring. As a consequence of the revenue shortfall and increased spending enacted this month, government and private analysts said today, the budget deficit this fiscal year will be at least $80 billion higher than the Congressional Budget Office projected last month. 
 With a large deficit, Mr. Greenspan said, "you will be significantly undercutting the benefits that would be achieved from the tax cuts."
The combination of Mr. Greenspan's testimony and the prospects of a higher deficit gave added ammunition to Mr. Bush's political opponents, as the president continued today to press Congress to approve a $550 billion, 10-year tax cut.
"These deficit numbers are just the latest reminder that what many of us have expressed concern about is becoming even more of a problem," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.
The president met today on the tax issue with Republican Congressional leaders. Afterward, Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, said that the president and all the leaders wanted as large a tax cut as possible and that Congress might consider more than one tax measure this year.
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, played down any disagreement with Mr. Greenspan. Last week, the president announced that he would renominate Mr. Greenspan to his fifth term as Fed chairman, and Mr. Greenspan, 77, said he would accept.
Mr. Fleischer said today that Mr. Bush's first priority was creating jobs immediately and that the government could reduce the deficit "over time." He agreed with Mr. Greenspan that the best way to lower the deficit was to hold the line on government spending.
Mr. Greenspan said that with the end of the uncertainties associated with the war in Iraq, the economy was in a position for strong growth. But if that does not occur, he said, the Fed was prepared to lower interest rates further.
As is his practice, Mr. Greenspan spoke elliptically in his Congressional testimony and never addressed the tax legislation before Congress specifically.
But he said that even without additional stimulus, "the economy is positioned to expand at a noticeably better pace than it has during the past year." 
He also said new academic evidence had strengthened his opinion that budget deficits led directly to higher interest rates.
Mr. Greenspan's view on tax cuts is similar to one he expressed in February, but the environment has changed. Congress is now on the verge of drafting and voting on actual tax legislation, and the Fed chairman's views on economic matters carry more weight in Congress than the opinions of any other economist.
In response to a question about the need for additional economic stimulus, Mr. Greenspan said that with the tax cuts enacted in 2001 and sizable growth in government spending, "we already have a significant amount of stimulus in place."
He added that he was skeptical of the ability of changes in tax and spending policy to "fine tune" the economy in the short term.
Mr. Greenspan said he strongly supported the president's tax policy, particularly the proposal to eliminate taxes on most stock dividends, "provided it is matched by cuts in spending."
Deficits are especially important in the near future, he said, because of the pressure on the economy early in the next decade when the baby boom generation begins to reach retirement age.
The shortfall in tax revenues has been apparent all spring, but the magnitude did not become clear, economic analysts said, until they examined the Treasury's daily reports of tax receipts in the two weeks since the April 15 filing deadline.
William C. Dudley, chief economist at Goldman Sachs, said he was seeing "a pretty sizable shortfall relative to expectation."
Goldman is forecasting a $425 billion deficit in the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. In February, the White House projected a deficit of $304 billion. Last month, the Congressional Budget Office, using a different method of calculation, projected a deficit of $246 billion.
A senior Republican staff member in Congress who has analyzed the Treasury data said that revenues were running about $40 billion lower than the Congressional Budget Office expected. He said tax refunds were about $20 billion higher than anticipated and tax payments about $20 billion lower.
One reason for the shortfall in revenues, economists say, is that the poor performance by the stock market in 2002 resulted in smaller tax payments of capital gains taxes and fewer taxes paid by business executives who exercised stock options.
In addition to the deficit increase resulting from lower revenues, the projections by the White House and the Congressional Budget Office do not count the $42 billion in additional spending, mostly for the war, that Congress approved this month. Nor do they consider the likelihood that Congress will approve tax cuts and make at least some of them retroactive to Jan. 1 and the probability that the administration will ask Congress for additional spending authority for reconstruction costs in Iraq.

The death of one man and the hospitalization of 15 other people who drank coffee at a church social has mystified the tiny, tight-knit town of New Sweden, Me. Tests point to arsenic, and rumors are rife. A22

Greenspan Opposes Tax Cut
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested to Congress that a large tax cut was not necessary to generate economic growth and that the budget deficits resulting from lower taxes without offsetting reductions in spending could damage the economy. A32

States Push Gambling Limits
Facing daunting deficits and with little appetite for raising taxes, a growing number of states have tried tapping into the $50 billion gambling industry through measures that expand state lotteries, license new casinos and negotiate higher percentages from Indian gambling. A31

Forensic Security Doubted
Ten days before Timothy McVeigh was executed for the Oklahoma City bombing, lawyers for F.B.I. laboratory employees sent an urgent letter to the attention of Attorney General John Ashcroft saying that a key prosecution witness might have given false testimony about the security of forensic evidence. The letter was opened long after the execution. A24

Immunity Granted to Agent
Prosecutors have agreed to give limited immunity to a veteran F.B.I. agent entangled in a Los Angeles espionage investigation, but they are also considering new and potentially more serious charges against both him and a prized bureau informant with whom he had a long-term affair, officials said. A30

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Anthrax Bacterium Decoded
Scientists at the Institute for Genomic Research in Maryland have determined the full sequence of DNA units in the genome of the anthrax bacterium and found it resembles that of a common soil bacterium. A20

NEW YORK/REGION B1-7

Critics Say Pataki Is Playing to Peoria
Gov. George E. Pataki has staked his political future on a budget battle with the Legislature, and even his aides acknowledge that he may well lose. Critics say his fight against a tax increase is intended to play to a national audience, furthering his personal ambitions. A1

Chilling Trail of Child Abuse
State records made public under court order offered chilling examples of just how disastrously New Jersey caseworkers had failed to act to protect children in its foster care system despite evidence that they were at serious risk. B1

Switch on Aid for Mentally Ill
The New York Legislature has unexpectedly rejected a Pataki administration plan to make short-term improvements at adult homes for the mentally ill, instead turning over most of the proposed money to the home's operators. B1

Hearing on Transit Suit
A state judge will hear arguments today in a lawsuit that seeks to stop the imminent transit fare increase, on the ground that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misled the public about the true nature of its finances. B2

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 4632 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through June 11). The most anticipated show by any American artist to emerge in a decade or more. "Cremaster," Mr. Barney's nine-year, five-film project, here presented whole for the first time, is an inspired benchmark of ambition, scope and forthright provocation for art in the new century. I recall Elizabeth Murray's describing how Philip Guston's crazy late works gave her heart to do her own mature paintings. Mr. Barney has brought to the art world a new freedom to explore narrative. He has introduced a new repertory of materials, gooey, strange, malleable and synthetic, which nobody thought of as germane before. Never mind that the films and many (not all) of his related sculptures, installations and photographs are very beautiful. The show, an installation itself, brings them together. The earliest "Cremaster" sculptures are film props, cobbled into installations that don't jell. But the latest are better: twin steel towers framed in plastic, a suite of abstract sculptures derived from automobile chassis. Vaseline and plastic combine with cement and steel -- pink and gray, rough and smooth, hard and soft -- the materials sustaining a narrative of formal eloquence. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "MONTIEN BOONMA: THE TEMPLE OF THE MIND," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through May 11). The art of the Thai artist Montien Boonma (1953-2000) combines many influences, from Southeast Asian Buddhism to Arte Povera and Joseph Beuys. But his art, by turns witty and somber, is not primarily about hybrid identities; it is about how to forge a life of psychic balance in an unbalanced and unbalancing world. In part he did so through the use of repeated, resonant symbols: the monk's alms bowl, the temple bell. He also turned art into an embracing sensual experience by infusing his installations with healing fragrances. There's nobody like him and nothing in town like this modestly scaled survey show. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

* "EGYPT REBORN: ART FOR ETERNITY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (permanent installation). The second and final phase in the museum's reinstallation of its world-renowned holdings of ancient Egyptian art, this dazzling display rounds up more than 600 objects -- from king-and-queen-size monuments to tiny rings and amulets -- from the predynastic period to the 18th dynasty. Together with the first phase, which opened in 1993 and covers later Egyptian art, visitors will now be able to trace the entire course of this brilliant and complex civilization from its beginnings to its absorption by the Roman Empire in 30 B.C. The heart of the new installation is an introductory gallery that provides a wonderful summation, with a survey of sculptural styles and displays of weapons, pottery, cosmetics, jewelry, furniture and funerary arts. The adjacent galleries are devoted to an extensive chronological survey. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"FRAKTUR TREASURES FROM THE SCHWENKFELDER LIBRARY AND HERITAGE CENTER," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through May 11). Among the more vibrant practitioners of fraktur, the Pennsylvania German art of embellishing letters and documents, were members of a Protestant sect called the Schwenkfelders, still going strong in Pennsylvania, where they migrated in the early 18th century. They brought with them the old-country custom of illuminating documents with decorative writing, drawings, borders, angels, hearts, flowers, birds and more esoteric symbols. The highly stylized work was called "fraktur" from the broken elements of the lettering. The Schwenkfelders put their all into Geburtscheine (birth certificates), Vorschriften (writing samplers), love letters, marriage certificates, religious texts and house blessings. The work in this show, both religious and secular, is lent by the Schwenkfelder Library in Pennsburg, Pa, which since 1884 has collected more than 1,000 examples of Pennsylvania fraktur and is especially rich in Schwenkfeldiana. Don't let all the cutesy hearts and flowers put you off; there's an innocent exuberance about this work that's captivating. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+ (Glueck).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 8). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through Aug. 15). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "MATISSE PICASSO," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 4520 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through May 19). If you're thinking of skipping it because of the crowds, that's not a good enough excuse. This is one for the ages: an eye-educating, often revelatory parlor game, with the fate of modern art as the stakes. The premise is a little dubious -- the two of them competing as if in stately isolation from everything else going on in art -- but the results look great. Choosing a winner is the sport of the event and the inevitable outcome of pitting titans mano a mano. Matisse comes out looking consistently good. To grasp 20th-century art, Picasso once said, "you ought to see side by side everything Matisse and I were doing." He was right about that. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 9 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. Admission: $20; $15.50 for students and 65+; under 16 with an adult, free. Reserved tickets: Ticketmaster, (212) 307-5577; or toll free, (866) 879-6662, with Ticketmaster surcharges (Kimmelman).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources make them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50 for students and 62+ (Smith).

"POETRY OF SIGHT: THE PRINTS OF JAMES McNEILL WHISTLER (1834-1903)," New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089 (through May 10). A salute on the centenary of his death to the painter's brilliance as a printmaker, this show presents more than 130 etchings, drypoints and lithographs that trace Whistler's career from its beginnings in Paris to his last years. A much less showy and theatrical side of Whistler is apparent in this display, which includes the famous "sets" done in France, London and Venice. Other graphic work, correspondence, photographs and personal documents are also on view in this well-organized presentation. Hours: Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Glueck).

* "CHRISTIAN SCHAD AND THE NEUE SACHLICHKEIT," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through June 9). Schad's career effectively lasted only 15 years from around 1915 to 1930, and for just two or three of those years was he doing what deserves to be remembered now. Not much time. But just enough. Schad at his mordant best precisely captured an anxious culture affected by war and the threat of it: his bloodless portraits in Vienna and Berlin suggest deep unease and foreboding beneath porcelain surfaces. They are explicitly unemotional, even when they are frankly erotic, as they frequently are. His drawing, akin to some done by Dix and Grosz, shy away from the issues of class conflict that inflamed both of those other artists. To the end, Schad remained aloof. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+
(Kimmelman).

* "TRANSMITTING THE FORMS OF DIVINITY: EARLY BUDDHIST ART FROM KOREA AND JAPAN," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through June 22). The role of Korea in the development of Buddhist art and thought in Japan and therefore in the formation of Japanese culture itself emerges from decades of habitual marginalization in this beautiful exhibition. Dominated by meditating Buddhas and handsomely attired bodhisattvas dating from the sixth to the ninth centuries, the show, which has been organized with the Korea Society of New York, dispenses lessons in several kinds of grace, religious as well as formal. It highlights the forceful stylization and subtle abstraction of the human figure, which while common in Asian and African art, is rarely equaled in Western sculpture between the medieval and modern periods. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+ (Smith).

* "WHISTLER, WOMEN AND FASHION," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 13). A dandy, a wit and a social butterfly who cultivated his image as a star aesthete, James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) had a lifelong interest in fashion and women's clothes. This show honors the centenary of the painter's death by exploring his intense, unabashed involvement with fashion. He obsessed over what his female sitters wore, choosing the clothes they posed in and in some cases actually designing them himself. For Frances Leyland, the fashionable subject of one of his most smashing pictures, he created an elegant, loose-fitting tea gown of diaphanous pink chiffon worn over a white underdress. The display includes many major images of women in their finery and several magnificent gowns of the Whistler period along with smaller oils, drawings, pastel studies, costume designs, prints and watercolors, and relevant 19th-century fashion plates. It's a fitting tribute to a bravura brush. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

JOHN WILLIAM HILL, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through May 10). Hill (1812-1879) founded the now little remembered American Pre-Raphaelite movement. He was immune to the medievalism of the English Pre-Raphaelites, but he took to heart John Ruskin's admonition to work from nature. Most of the skillfully made drawings and watercolors here are conventionally picturesque, but two densely worked watercolors of fruits, vegetables and nuts on the ground have an earthy palpability that one imagines Henry David Thoreau would have appreciated (Ken Johnson).

JANNIS KOUNELLIS, Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623 (through May 24). These works on paper from the 1970's and 80's by Mr. Kounellis, a maverick sculptor and painter who participated in the Arte Povera movement in the 1960's, tap into the many themes of his larger projects. They range from the merest of sketches to finished drawings. Fragile wisps of thought, more substantial images like factories and locomotives, black overall patterns of skull-faces that seem to evoke a mass catastrophe: some fragments are powerful bits of visual poetry, but others are slight to the point of meaninglessness (Glueck).

* "KURT SCHWITTERS: COLLAGES, PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, OBJECTS, EPHEMERA," Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444 (through May 23). The German artist Kurt Schwitters (1887-1948) made artful arrangements of found scraps -- torn photographs, ticket stubs, labels, newspaper clips and other discarded bits -- into abstract compositions that balanced colors, forms, textures and printed matter to dazzling effect. More than 60 of his works, Dada-oriented but also much influenced by Constructivism and Russian Suprematism, are brought together here in a museum-quality display that ranges in date from before 1920 to the late 1940's. One standout in this bountiful show is a gem from 1931, "Untitled (Red, Gray, Black)," a rigorously structured composition with all the elegant trappings of Suprematism-Constructivism brilliantly translated into "Merz," Schwitters's no-meaning name for his own visual language (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

FERNANDA BRUNET, "Bang," Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through May 16). Graphic pop and gestural dynamism combine in this Mexico City artist's paintings. Ms. Brunet takes images of explosions, deluges, volcanic eruptions and tidal waves from Japanese comic books and turns them into semiabstract compositions, in a palette of earth tones and silver. They humorously suggest transports of erotic ecstasy (Johnson).

JOHN CEDERQUIST, "Furniture That Builds Itself," Franklin Parrasch, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 246-5360 (through May 31). Mr. Cederquist's beautifully made woodworks are simultaneously functional pieces of furniture and zany cartoons in two and three dimensions. With painted Mickey Mouse arms wielding drills and planes as if in the act of building, these funky sculptures are deceptively whimsical meditations on the mind's construction of reality (Johnson).

EMILY EVELETH, Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through May 10). With a soft painterly touch, Ms. Eveleth turns humble jelly doughnuts into monumental, voluptuous objects of desire. Glowing and looming against dark backgrounds singly or in piled groups, they laze like corpulent odalisques. Each has its dark, raspberry-stained orifice turned to the viewer, to slightly alarming effect (Johnson).

TOM WESSELMANN, "The Great American Sixties," Maxwell Davidson, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7555 (through June 13); "Nudes and Abstracts," Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, (212) 366-4774 (through May 10). Wesselmann then and now: Davidson's selection of works from the 1960's includes one of the Pop Art master's classic Great American Nude apartment paintings -- real telephone and radiator included -- and seductive small studies of female body parts: pillowy lips, nubile breasts and coy painted toes. The new work at Miller finds the artist in a Matissean mood, folding his pin-up iconography into compositions of Cubist semiabstraction and, with a series of large reliefs of sweeping, brightly colored planes, breaking into purely decorative abstraction (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

OLIVE AYHENS, "Bridges," Gary Tatintsian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through May 24). It is hard to capture the dizzying dynamism of New York City in painting, but Ms. Ayhens succeeds with her exuberantly expressionistic canvases. She paints overhead views of streets and bridges with reckless confidence, insouciant disregard for ordinary perspective and a fine eye for detail and light. In some cases she creates shotgun weddings of urban and wilderness scenery with environmentalist intentions but mainly to vertiginous effect (Johnson).

RAINER GROSS, "Doppelganger/Contact Paintings," Axel Raben, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 647-9064 (through May 24). This New York-based German artist makes sensuous abstract paintings by a process of his own invention that involves fusing two paintings face to face and then pulling them apart. Exhibited singly or as diptychs, the paintings look like flaking wall sections. They have lush, supersaturated colors and dry, crusty surfaces that look like velvet from a distance (Johnson).

"KARAOKE DEATH MACHINE," Daniel Reich, 308 West 21st Street, (917) 408-9097 (through June 2). This is more like a visit to someone's tiny, dark and incredibly cluttered apartment than to a gallery exhibition; actually it is Mr. Reich's tiny, dark and incredibly cluttered apartment-cum-gallery. A stream-of-consciousness salon-style installation of more than 100 small works by more than two dozen artists as well as many images lifted directly from commercial media, the show is uneven, to say the least. But it has a grainy video copy of an early film by Niki de Saint Phalle and an excellent title (Johnson).

JEAN-FRANCOIS MORICEAU AND PETRA MRZYK, "Only for Your Eyes," Marcus Ritter, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 463-7375 (through May 17). This young cartoon-making team generates sight gags with seemingly effortless abandon. Hairy prehistoric people shaving their private parts; anthropomorphic paintings on strike, carrying signs that say, "We want a new curator"; an owl with Mickey Mouse ears; a woman with square breasts; a giant eye with two pupils. More than 100 of these black-ink line drawings, individually framed and stacked up against the wall, will give your sense of humor an invigorating workout (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"EXTRA," Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 925-2035 (through May 10). The curator Marc-Olivier Wahler asks, "How many extra layers can we graft onto reality before it collapses?" The 11 works here do little to answer the question, but they make an entertaining show. They include Bruno Peinado's giant brown Michelin man with an Afro, Wim Delvoye's tattooed pig, Peter Fischli and David Weiss's trompe-l'oeil studio props, Olivier Blanckart's Village People made of paper and tape and adorable little robotic dogs programmed to fight by Stephane Sautour (Johnson).

* "THE STAGE OF DRAWING: GESTURE AND ACT," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through May 31). It's not easy to assemble a truly engaging show from a vast collection of drawings like that owned by England's Tate. But this one, selected by a British artist, Avis Newman, with Catherine de Zegher, director of the Drawing Center, really works. Not a tiresome institutional tour but a vividly personal one, it views drawing as "an open-ended and exploratory activity," with exhibits ranging from a 295-foot line on a roll of wrapped paper to precise renderings of 19th-century hairdos. The mix of artists runs from J. M. W. Turner to Andy Warhol; the juxtapositions reveal affinities across centuries and cultures (Glueck).

Brooklyn

ROBERT GRUNDER, Sixtyseven, 67 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 486-0387 (through May 18). Mr. Grunder's semiabstract paintings of mall stores and parking lots are O.K., but his bird's-eye views of freeways, overpasses and cloverleaf intersections painted on white grounds have a cool dynamism that nicely evokes the speediness of modern life (Johnson).

SCOTT TEPLIN, "Moron," Jessica Murray Projects, 210 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 384-9606 (through May 11). Mr. Teplin's delightfully inventive drawing is like a conference call among Dr. Seuss, R. Crumb, Ed Ruscha and Rube Goldberg. Words like moron, flapjack and bonus hole are dug into the ground, constructed from industrial steel or whirling in space, while floating beds, gobs of mud, circulating tubes, spurting, gnarly nipples and disembodied mouths convey a spirit of gleeful surrender to the mind's own perversely polymorphous energies (Johnson).

Other Galleries

"DE LO QUE SOY/OF WHAT I AM," Lehman College Art Gallery, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx, (718) 960-8731 (through May 12) and "Taino Treasures: The Legacy of Dr. Ricardo E. Alegria" (through today). This survey of contemporary self-portraiture by 22 women of Latin American or Caribbean descent takes the genre beyond Kahlo-esque narcissism. A few pieces include images of the artists, but in most the first-person presence is only obliquely in evidence. Through tomorrow there is also a show of Taino sculpture, created from the 10th to the 15th century by the indigenous people of the Caribbean (Cotter).

* TARA DONOVAN, Ace Gallery, 276 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 255-5599 (through May 15). Installation art proved long ago that lots of space combined with lots and lots of one material, arranged by stupefyingly simple labor-intensive methods, can work wonders. This solo debut provides supporting evidence that, if not too original, is amazingly succinct. The materials include transparent tape, Elmer's glue and pencils; the high point is something that looks from afar like a fairly large cloud or snow bank but is not (Smith).

ANN SPERRY, "30 Pieces/30 Years," Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205 (through June 26). Since the early 1970's, Ms. Sperry has been bending, shaping and welding metal into metaphorically suggestive abstractions. The best works in this retrospective have an industrial surrealism similar to, though not as surprising as, that of Donald Lipski (Johnson).

Last Chance

"AFRICAN-AMERICAN ARTISTS, 1929-1945: PRINTS, DRAWINGS AND PAINTINGS IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Metropolitan Museum, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). Covering the time from the Depression through World War II, this display of more than 80 works by Jacob Lawrence, Romare Bearden, Bill Traylor and Horace Pippin among others is divided among artists who subscribed to the notions of European Modernism and those who dealt with issues of cultural heritage and racial identity. It highlights the Met's own holdings of African-American art, which have been considerably supplemented by 204 prints recently donated by Reba and Dave Williams. With the show's works grouped in categories like "Faces," "The South," "The North," "Labor," "Religion," "Recreation" and "War," it makes a nice if rather bland introduction to issues confronting artists of the era. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

"MADONNA AND STEVEN KLEIN: X-STATIC PRO=CESS." Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, near Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300 (through tomorrow). Mr. Klein's tacky mural-size photographs of the rock diva Madonna in various histrionic ensembles and sets might as well be stills from unusually egregious music videos except that they occasionally twitch. Their blatant derivativeness can make you momentarily giddy with something resembling delight (Smith).

* LARRY MANTELLO, Henry Urbach Architecture, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-0974 (through tomorrow). Mr. Mantello's terrifyingly funny "Box Rap" is like a walk-in CARE package of contemporary Americana, ready for shipping anywhere out to the world. Within a closet-like compartment, the artist has packed a cornucopian jungle of Disney dolls, cartoon videos, lollipops, Christmas ornaments, junk food containers and condom packages and accompanied the assemblage with a star-spangled sound track of patriotic songs. He also extends his gift for acidic confection to collages that weave together news items and advertisements, athletes and body parts to suggest a culture composed of a whole lot of everything but in which nothing is whole (Cotter).

* JENNY SAVILLE, "Migrants," Gagosian, 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-1111 (through tomorrow). This 32-year-old London painter's plus-size pictures of naked, corpulent female bodies has given figurative painting a good shot in the arm. This exhibition finds her shifting into melodramatic overdrive. Enhanced by viscerally expressionistic painting, pictures of the artist's head lying on its side suggest aftermaths of domestic brutality. The image of a screaming full-figured woman, her face bathed in blood, might be a homage to Francis Bacon's screaming pope (Johnson).

* "SEEING RED I: PIONEERS OF NONOBJECTIVE PAINTING," Hunter College Art Galleries, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue, (212) 772-4991 (through tomorrow). The optical and symbolic power of red is the basis of this one-color show, which presents a lineup of wonderful paintings, beginning with work by two significant emigre painter-teachers, Hans Hofmann and Josef Albers. The show is meant to mark the evolution of color theory and the effect of new scientific advances in the field on nonobjective painting; it celebrates some of the pioneers of this movement (which contains no identifiable imagery) in the United States. The focus on one color affords a more intense observation of differences in surface and texture, subtle gradations in tone and the play of light. Besides the controlled geometrics of Albers's nested boxes and the dynamic Expressionist splash of Hofmann's fiery painted ball, there are works by Jack Youngerman, Tony Smith, Richard Anuszkiewicz, Richard Pousette-Dart, Kenneth Noland and Robert Motherwell, among others (Glueck).

BETTY WOODMAN: "Souvenirs," Max Protech, 511 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 633-6999 (through tomorrow). Recent travels in Europe, India and East Asia have given the ceramist Betty Woodman, an inventive vessel maker, some engaging ideas that build on a long Woodman-esque tradition -- for example, lively miniature stage sets whose crisply delineated actors are vessels and shards in Matisse-style cutout shapes. They were derived from the archaeology of the Aeolian Islands off Sicily. A visit to Asia and the sight of sculptures of deities clad in fabric inspired her to make a group of vases dressed in brightly colored robes and echoing womanly shapes. There are many more delights in this animated show (Glueck).

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES; 
What Price English Glory?

BYLINE:  By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
There is no shortage of fine dealers specializing in English antiques in New York. The list includes Florian Papp, Kentshire Galleries, Philip Colleck, Hyde Park Antiques and Clinton Howell, to name just a few. Nonetheless, yesterday's opening of a Manhattan branch of Mallett, the venerable London antiques firm, is an event in the antiques world. Mallett sells only the creme de la creme, at prices that make people faint.
 Founded in 1865, the gallery is probably the world's leading purveyor of high-end English furniture from the 17th through the 19th century. It is certainly the most expensive one, and proud of it. 
 The firm took over the former Devenish gallery premises at 929 Madison Avenue, at 74th Street. It gutted three floors of a five-story town house and reconfigured them to make luxurious room settings, including a fully furnished dining room with all the glittering trappings. 
Among the eye-catchers are a pair of circa 1755 carved mahogany over-scaled hall tables made for Hagley Hall in Worcestershire; two early-18th-century carved mahogany stools covered with brilliantly colored period floral needlework; a neoclassical white marble Adam mantle piece; and a 10-fold painted leather English screen, circa 1750.
The gallery interiors, with raised ceilings and art-filled walls, look like those in a private 18th-century English country house. The grand pieces of furniture are toned down with sporting pictures, Chinese porcelains and amusing knickknacks. At street level, Mallett created an enticing enfilade of rooms, beginning at the picture window in the front, so you can see all the way through to the back wall before entering. 
"I'd decided to come to New York before 9/11," said Lanto Synge, the executive director of Mallett. "We always wanted to come, but we had to find the right building. And there's another reason: we have a new clientele, a breed of young workaholics. They don't want to go to London, but they are still passionate about English antiques."
He spoke about a young Wall Street banker who made contact via the Internet. He called the banker when he was next in New York. "We got together after his workday," Mr. Synge said. "He was in jeans but very knowledgeable. He was a real collector. I used to think people didn't buy seriously until they were in their 50's. I was wrong. Collectors are now starting much earlier."
Mallett, commonly known as Mallett's, has always been a mecca to serious aficionados of English antiques. Early Anglophiles in America included Judge Irwin Untermeyer, whose 18th-century English furniture is now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; William Randolph Hearst; and Paul Mellon.
"We're known for our extraordinary fantasy pieces," Mr. Synge said. "We're unpredictable; we mix English, French and Chinese. We may have a butterfly cabinet from the 1830's or two contemporary chairs by John Makepeace."
In more recent times collectors like Jayne Wrightsman, Henry Kravis, Ann Getty and Elton John have made pilgrimages to London to peruse the stock.
Now Mallett has come to the United States, which accounts for 60 percent of its clientele. (Mallett has also sold to several American museums, including the J. Paul Getty; the Metropolitan; the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston; and the Art Institute of Chicago.)
The opening showstopper is probably the tall, all-gold George I bureau bookcase that belonged to Queen Carlota Joaquina, wife of King John VI of Portugal. It is attributed to James Moore, a leading London furniture maker who died in 1726, and his entrepreneurial partner, John Gumley. They supplied palatial furniture to both Burlington House and Blenheim Palace.
Apart from its beveled mirror doors and side mirror plates, the entire exterior, even the shell above the arched doors, is covered in golden gesso that looks like stamped leather. The gesso is richly carved in Renaissance-style strapwork patterns with scrolling foliage. 
The desk was made about 1720. The interior is neatly fitted out with shelves, small drawers, pigeonholes and a cupboard, all veneered with burr yew wood and walnut. "This bureau bookcase is one of a pair; we sold its companion in 1977," Mr. Synge said. "An Englishman would never have ordered two bureau bookcases. Only Europeans ordered them in pairs." 
Another notable piece is a Regency Egyptian-style collector's cabinet-on-stand from about 1810. Attributed to James Newton, it is a tour de force of the cabinetmaker's art. The exterior has two rosewood doors decorated with bands of tulipwood and boxwood. The corners boast ebonized sphinx heads. Between them is a foliate screen, with gilded foliage on an ebonized background. Above the screen is a hand-cut gilt metal gallery. The interior has 16 cedar-lined rosewood drawers in graduated sizes with ivory knobs. The stand has ebonized legs with gilded stripes, like a barbershop pole, and large black hairy paw feet.
"This was clearly a private commission," Mr. Synge said. It is selling for $512,000.
Mallett, of course, is known for its quintessential English antiques. "When we have brown furniture, it has to be the ultimate," Mr. Synge said.
Some of the earliest pieces are the most refined, including a perfectly proportioned, handsome dropfront oak desk fully veneered in exquisite burl walnut. The price is $145,000. The burl is perfectly matched on the front in panels bordered with herringbone cross banding in walnut.
On the ground floor is a small but magnificent Chippendale-period mahogany tripod tea table with a piecrust border. Because it is English, the tea table, which is selling for $360,000, costs a fraction of what it would if it were American, since so few survive. It is in mint condition, and the carving is exquisite.
Such pieces represent the best English furniture, the kind of understated pieces that most people are seeking. Their prices range from $15,000 to $2.2 million. Mallett also sells Continental antiques, like the Louis XIV Boulle bureau Mazarin, circa 1690, that is currently in New York. And it produces a few contemporary pieces, like coffee tables with antique Chinese lacquer panels, and two-tier glass drinks tables.
It may seem like a brave move to open up in New York during a recession, but Mallett, a public company quoted on the London Stock Exchange, has done extremely well recently. Last year sales rose 48 percent, to $40,537,600, with $8,308,000 in profit. "It was an exceptional year," Mr. Synge said. 

Barye Bronze Sale
Christie's sale of 160 bronzes by Antoine-Louis Barye, the 19th-century French animalier sculptor, totaled $2.7 million (against an estimate of $1 to $1.5 million). Lot 50, a sculpture of "Roger Carrying Off Angelica on the Hippogriff," set a record for the artist at auction.

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Cold? What Cold? For Some, It's Pool Season

BYLINE:  By NANCY M. BETTER 

 BODY:
IN early April, just before embarking on a trip to the Bahamas, Jack and Carol Davis called Ray Lopez, who services their swimming pool in Weston, Conn. "We told him to get it open, the sooner the better," Mr. Davis said.
 Upon their return, the pool was up and running, although the air temperature was below 40 degrees, the yard was muddy with melted snow, and the trees were still bare. Mr. Davis, a retired health care executive, was unfazed by the elements. "When you open your pool, it's like you're declaring the start of summer," Mr. Davis said. "You're announcing that winter's over." 
 The Davises have joined a growing group of homeowners who want to ignore what the calendar tells them, extending the pool season for as long as they can. It is not enough for these people to provide a cool oasis for family and friends during the dog days of summer. They want to be first on the block to open their pool, tempting the neighbors with plumes of steam rising enticingly from the water, even if it means wearing sweaters and long pants while huddling in the poolside chaise lounges. 
Since 1996, the average season for in-ground pools in the Northeast has increased from 3.5 months to 4.4 months, according to a recent study by P. K. Data, an Atlanta-area market research firm. In some cases, homeowners are aiming to double the traditional Memorial-Day-to-Labor-Day season. "This is a trend largely fueled by technology," said Suzanne Barrows, a spokeswoman for the National Spa & Pool Institute, a trade group in Washington. "Heaters are cheaper and more efficient than ever before, and that puts them in the reach of more people. Now you don't have to wait for warm weather before opening your pool."
Indeed, phones are ringing at the offices of pool service companies while the ground is still frozen. Mr. Lopez, the caretaker for the Davises' pool, said he opened a dozen pools during the first week of April despite two snowstorms that closed area schools. "We're definitely getting more requests to open earlier," he said. "But a lot of people aren't actually using their pools; they just want the property to look pristine, and the cover isn't a pretty sight."
Kevin Vevante, owner of Aquacade Swimming Pools in Hicksville, N.Y., said many of his clients open their pools a month or two before they plan to swim. This is partly to get the most out of their investment. Mr. Vevante estimates that a new in-ground concrete pool lined with gunite -- not including patio, landscaping or fencing expenses -- costs from $75,000 to $100,000. Professional maintenance of such a pool can run from $2,000 to $4,000 annually. "If you're going to spend that kind of money, you're going to want the pool open as long as possible," he said.
Die-hard swimmers often care more about water temperature than aesthetics. Henry Singer, a Manhattan lawyer with a weekend home in Pound Ridge, N.Y., tries to heat his pool to 80 degrees by early May. "It's my summer exercise," he said. "I probably swim 200 laps every weekend." To conserve energy, Mr. Singer heats his pool at the beginning and the end of the season, and lets the sun do the job in between.
In some communities, heating bills are a price worth paying if it means early season dips. Chris Hollander, the service manager at Swimming Pools by Jack Anthony, which services more than 250 pools in the Hamptons, estimates that 90 percent of his customers have pool heaters. His company began opening pools in March for weekend homeowners. "Some people want to come out for Easter or Mother's Day and have the pool ready," he said.
Mr. Hollander said there are practical advantages to opening early. Because heat causes algae to bloom, it is easier to clean the water and balance the chemicals in cooler weather. And equipment repair or replacement means it can take two to four weeks to get a pool fully operational.
Some homeowners opt to open other features ahead of the main pool. Bill Evanson, chief financial officer of Anthony & Sylvan Pools of Mayfield Village, Ohio, said customers are building or adding spas with separate heaters that can operate independently of the main pool. Some are also putting in waterfalls for visual appeal and soothing sounds. Mr. Evanson chalks it up to what he calls the "recocooning" phenomenon.
"Families are traveling less and staying home more," he said. "The pool is a social center, not just a place to swim." 
Mr. Evanson's company, which built and installed about 4,000 pools across the country in 2002, is also doing a brisk business in so-called recreational pools, the large, shallow pools that are popular for playing volleyball and basketball, or doing water aerobics and other aquatic exercises. "The emphasis isn't on swimming anymore," Mr. Evanson said. "There are so many different uses for a pool."
Many homeowners are increasingly reluctant to shut their pools after Labor Day. "I've had requests to stay open until Thanksgiving," Mr. Lopez said. "It seems kind of crazy. But in this economy, we have to be a little more lenient. We'll let people stay open later if they really want to keep paying."
Heating costs mount quickly as days grow shorter and temperatures drop. To avoid clogging pipes with leaves and other debris, pool owners also have to keep filters and skimmers running constantly. Mr. Singer, the lawyer, estimates that he spends an extra $2,000 to keep his pool usable through October.
"We've gone about as far as we can go," said William Kennedy, the president of P. K. Data, the market research firm. "Nobody in the Northeast can keep a pool open 365 days a year -- unless you're a lifetime member of the Polar Bear Club."

HARDWARE
Heating Systems Range From Gas to Electric to Languid Solar
BEFORE choosing a heating system for a pool, you can get a heating audit from a local heating equipment dealer. Based on the weather data for your region, this computerized report will give you the approximate monthly cost of various systems. Or try the online calculator from the Florida Power and Light Company (www.fpl.com). Example: If you heat a 20-foot-by-40-foot pool in the New York metropolitan area to 80 degrees every day in May, your heating bill for the month will be about $330.
There are three basic types of pool heating systems. The best system for your needs is determined by your pool's size, shape and location, as well as your budget. Any system will benefit from the addition of a thermal pool cover, since 95 percent of a pool's heat loss occurs through evaporation.

GAS HEATERS -- Gas-fueled heaters are effective at raising temperatures quickly, but are relatively expensive to operate.

HEAT PUMPS -- Heat pumps are slower acting than gas pumps, but less expensive. Heat pumps use electricity to operate; they extract heat from the air and transfer it to the pool water. Lately, the cost of heat pumps has come down. A pool that uses $1,500 per year for gas heating may only require $500 for a heat pump.

SOLAR HEATERS -- Best for use in warmer regions, solar heaters also can be used to extend the season in cooler climates. The heaters use panels, usually located on the roof of your house, to heat water circulated through your existing pool pump. Monthly operating costs are negligible.
System costs vary. But heat pumps are typically $3,000 to $3,500, gas systems are $2,800 to $3,000 and solar ones are $5,000 to $10,000. NANCY M. BETTER

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Love Me, Love My Car

BYLINE:  By JASON TANZ 

 BODY:
EVERY car buyer faces difficult questions. Should I buy the extended warranty? Do I need a DVD player? How about alpaca floor mats? But people who purchase a Pontiac Aztek face another head-scratcher: how to respond to passersby who pull up next to them and inform them -- usually in obscene terms -- that their cars are the ugliest things ever to touch asphalt?
 There is no correct response to the inevitable assault. Joe Garcia, an Allentown, Pa., network administrator who has been driving his Aztek since October 2000, strikes back. "I used to get upset about it," he said in a March telephone interview. "Now I just say 'Hey, look in the mirror.' " 
 Rich Cottrell, who owns a manufacturing company on Cape Cod, uses self-effacing comebacks, like "I built it in my garage" and "It was designed by NASA to transport astronauts." 
Other Aztek drivers turn the other cheek and hope to avoid confrontation.
Once a year, WardsAuto.com, an auto industry data service in Northfield, Mich., publishes a list of the nation's best-selling cars. Owners who hit it right can rest easy, knowing their resale value is assured. There is no comparable worst-seller list -- the models with the lowest sales are likely to be limited-edition, exclusive cars or very expensive ones, not undesirables. But there are cars that bomb -- models that quickly turn into the ugly ducklings nobody likes. It's a tradition that goes back as far as the Edsel and includes such legendary fiascos as the AMC Pacer and the Yugo.
How does it feel to be one of the few who bought a car that captured no one else's imagination?
Since the Aztek was introduced in 2000, owning one has become the automotive equivalent of wearing a Red Sox cap in the Yankee Stadium bleachers. The car attracted unprecedented vitriol almost immediately, largely for its appearance -- a bit like a Toyota 4-Runner crossed with a turtle and highlighted with heavy black plastic cladding. Car and Driver derided its "rather cartoonish, space-cadet styling." Forbes.com called it "a truly unattractive car that might have been the unfortunate offspring of a tryst between a Volkswagen Thing and a Honda CRX."
One enterprising Aztek hater created an online petition to "Help Stop the Aztek Before It Starts." More than 400 people signed it between June and December of 2000. (Sample comment: "This is taking freedom of expression too far!! Don't forget to laugh at anyone driving an Aztek!") And in perhaps the most embarrassing blow for the car, Colby Donaldson -- who won an Aztek on the second season of "Survivor" in 2001 -- announced that he did not want it. He later sold it on eBay. 
Aztek owners have ways of defending their vehicles against the slings and arrows of wisecracking fellow motorists. They talk loudly about the car's handling and outdoorsy features, like the optional tentlike camping extension that attaches to the back. They praise its unique design and quirky personality. And they stick together. But now they face the prospect of being deserted by their only real ally: General Motors itself.
The Aztek has been a consistent sales disappointment for G.M.'s Pontiac division. The company initially hoped to sell as many as 70,000 a year. Instead, it sold 11,500 in the first six months. The company did a quick redesign and introduced a new version -- without the clunky black cladding that many critics found so unappealing. It also slashed the price. But sales still didn't come close to the 50,000 mark. In 2002, Pontiac sold 28,000 Azteks. And now comes talk of the predictable next step: the Aztek is expected to be discontinued as soon as late 2004, leaving its drivers with orphan cars, as the survivors of a discontinued model are called. (Pontiac won't confirm or deny the rumors. "It's there for the next two years," said Jim Vurpillat, the marketing director for Aztek. "Beyond that we don't discuss.")
"Clearly, the vehicle has not met its expectations," said Chris Cedergren, an analyst at Nextrend, an auto-industry research and consulting company in Thousand Oaks, Calif. "It just has not hit a chord at all."
"There's no doubt that it was a failure," agreed Haig Stoddard, manager of industry analysis at WardsAuto.com.
Should the calamity come to pass, Aztek owners will at least find themselves in good company. Just in the last few years, carmakers have discontinued several models after embarrassingly short life spans -- the Lincoln Blackwood, the Cadillac Catera and the briefly revived Mercury Cougar all come to mind. And at each announcement of a demise, thousands of owners have suddenly found themselves driving cars acknowledged as failures and virtually certain to lose a fair percentage of their resale value.
In 1998, the Ford Motor Company introduced a new version of its Mercury Cougar, which had been a popular and slightly upscale version of the Mustang in its first incarnation in the 60's and 70's and then morphed into a rather bland midsize coupe. The new Cougar was presented as a sleek, sporty front-drive model. In November 1999, John Scullin, a freelance graphic designer from Brockton, Mass., picked up a sapphire-blue 2000 Cougar. "I wanted an older, classic-style car," Mr. Scullin said. "As soon as I saw it, I was sold."
Mr. Scullin's Cougar quickly became his avocation. He spent hours customizing it and chatting online with fellow Cougar owners, many of whom became friends. In 2001, he brought together a six-car caravan that drove 900 miles to attend a CougarFest, an event in Detroit, supported by Ford, in which the car's enthusiasts were invited to tour the plant and hold a cookout.
But the market for a coupe like the Cougar was unhealthy, and the Cougar did not provide a cure. Plans were made to close out the Cougar and it was pulled from the market in 2002. The year the Cougar was discontinued, Mr. Scullin said, Ford stopped supporting the CougarFests for owners of the redesigned, late-model Cougars. "Ford has treated the Cougar as the relative nobody wants around," he said.
Another car introduced amid a rosy cloud of optimism was the Cadillac Catera, an Opel-based car touted as "the Caddy that zigs," which came out in 1996 and was intended to compete with European entry-level luxury sedans like the BMW 3-series and Mercedes Benz's C-class offerings. The Catera failed quickly and convincingly. Early models were beset with mechanical problems, and a confusing advertising campaign that featured a cartoon duck failed to attract the sophisticated young buyers that G.M., its parent, had in mind.
The Catera peaked with sales of 25,000 in 1997. In 1999, only 15,000 were sold.
By the time Mike Diamond of Thousand Oaks, Calif., bought his Catera in November 2000, for $20,000, it had already been several months since G.M. announced it would stop making the cars. But he was undeterred. He had owned orphaned vehicles before -- two Infiniti M30's -- and he liked the Catera's German-engineered handling and the reduced post-announcement price. What he wasn't prepared for was the scorn he felt the company heaped on the Catera. "They have fundamentally said that the whole car was a mistake," Mr. Diamond said.
A search of the Innovation Timeline on Cadillac's Web site confirmed Mr. Diamond's impression, yielding no trace that the Catera ever existed. Cadillac now has a new entry-level sedan, the CTS (which bears no resemblance to the Catera), but Mr. Diamond said he won't be buying one. "Now that they've told people the Catera was a bad idea," he said, "why would I go out and invest in the next bad idea?"
Some drivers whose vehicles have been orphaned claim to be happy about it. Katy Staley of Hazel Park, Mich., said she was proud to be one of the few to pick up a Lincoln Blackwood, a $50,000 luxury truck, in the year between when it was introduced and when the assembly line was closed in 2002. "It makes my truck more important to me, because I know there are only 3,600 of them out there," she said.
But it can take a long time for an odd duck to make it to collector status, if it ever does. "Some failed cars do come through and become highly coveted and collectible, but the majority do not," said Dave Dubie, a showroom sales manager for the Barrett-Jackson Auction Company, a seller of collectible cars in Scottsdale, Ariz. "If it's any kind of mass-marketed car, it will not become a future collectible." And for the immediate future, the economic ramifications of having one's car orphaned are rarely favorable.
"It completely destroys the resale value," said Mr. Cedergren of Nextrend. "Autos are about fashion, for the most part. A three-year-old car that looks like a new one has a lot more value than a car that you know is three years old because they've discontinued it."
Aztek owners are not waiting for the official announcement to express their displeasure with General Motors. They are already complaining that the company gave up on the car before it had a chance to succeed. When Mr. Cottrell was shopping for his Aztek, he visited several Pontiac dealers who, uncomfortable with the unusual car, tried to steer him away from it. "They said, 'Oh no, you'd be happier in a minivan,' " he recalled. "They said 'Well, it's overpriced, you know. It's not very popular.' " Many other Aztek owners complain that they have not seen any advertising for the car since it was introduced.
"I get letters from them all the time saying 'I haven't seen an ad lately,' " said Mr. Vurpillat, the Aztek marketing manager. He said that the Aztek was advertised in some local markets, though not nationwide. "We have other brands that we have to market and other brands that we have to launch," he said.
Aztek fans do their best to carry on. Two years ago, Mr. Garcia set up his first Aztek Rally in the parking lot of the Fashion Center shopping mall in Paramus, N.J. About 20 Aztek owners showed up to display their cars and spend the night in a campground. Last year, over 120 people went to the second rally in Owego, N.Y., including Mr. Vurpillat and some other representatives from G.M. This June, Mr. Garcia will hold another rally in Lehigh Valley, Pa.
Why is Mr. Garcia spending his free time and energy promoting what is surely a failing automobile? "No one else is," he said simply.
Another Aztek owner taking an us-against-the-world attitude is Tom Moog, a voice-over actor in Apex, N.C. In February, he set up an online meeting place for fellow free spirits, www.aztekfanclub.com. So far the site has registered more than 100 members who swap advice on installing hood protectors, flushing the transmission and -- of course -- responding snappily to critics.
Mr. Moog is not put off by the rumors of the Aztek's demise. "I hold my head up and I smile," he said. "I am an individual, I am unique, and I don't have to fit the mold of what society tells me to be."
