SECTION: Section 5; Column 2; Travel Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 2013 words

HEADLINE: LOW COUNTRY CRUISING IN EAST ANGLIA 

BYLINE:  By AURELIA C. SCOTT; AURELIA C. SCOTT writes frequently about travel.

 BODY:
IT'S easy," the young man said, demonstrating the combination throttle and gear shift in our rented 12-foot electric boat. "Forward, reverse, stop." 
 As I settled into the driver's seat for the morning excursion, he added, "Don't trail your ropes or they'll snag." 
 Then, with a grin, "And if the ducks are passing you, you're going too slow."
Last September, my husband, Bob, and I spent two weeks exploring East Anglia, a rural area of eastern England that is home to a 117-square-mile wetland (slightly bigger than the borough of Queens), the Norfolk and Suffolk Broads. We exchanged homes with an English couple, trading our Victorian in Portland, Me., for a white-washed cottage in Hemsby, a village on the edge of the Broads. 
 Part nature preserve, part recreation area, the Broads welcome about a million visitors annually, who fish, bird-watch, bicycle, hike andboat along nearly 125 miles of navigable rivers and shallow lakes, or "broads." The waterways wend through a bucolic landscape of reed beds, windmill water pumps, manicured fields confined by blackberry hedgerows and medieval villages of flint-walled churches and thatched cottages. 
We spent our days walking, boating and exploring villages. That first self-drive expedition on the River Thurne was as easy as promised. 
We rented our craft in Potter Heigham, a village famous for a medieval stone bridge built low over the water. Instead of testing our bridge-avoidance skills, we steered downriver, past brightly painted vacation cottages and boathouses. 
Sailboats and swans glided through the waterside neighborhood; ducks cropped postage-stamp lawns; homeowners waved from deck chairs. 
After several hundred yards, we left the houses behind and entered typical Broads habitat. Six-foot-high marsh grass and reeds blanketed the shore of the 50-foot-wide river. Marsh harriers wheeled overhead. White-beaked black coots rode the swells. 
I counted eight solitary fishermen, each of whom had carved out a space among the reeds. The only sounds were the calls of birds, rustling reeds and the gentle chug of the few slow-moving boats.
This serene, seemingly natural landscape is actually the result of centuries of human intervention. From possibly as early as the ninth century until the 14th, peat quarries were excavated in the treeless marshes beside East Anglia's many rivers. 
The peat heated such grand buildings as Norwich Cathedral, which in 1343 burned 400,000 pounds of Norfolk peat. By the 15th century, however, the water table began to rise and the quarries gradually filled, becoming the Broads.
On that first day on the water, we turned left at the whitewashed Thurne Dyke wind pump. Like most Broads' wind pumps, the one in Thurne village is a beautiful and nonfunctional artifact; plain electric pumps regulate the water levels in the marsh today. 
After mooring our boat more or less proficiently, we walked along Thurne's winding lanes admiring the undulating thatch roofs, each unique to the thatcher. Then with our boating map spread on a table at the Lion Inn, we debated our next destination and ate a hearty plowman's lunch of local bread, cheddar, ham and pickled onions.
While we loved the freedom of steering our boat along the waterways, we also enjoyed two guided tours. 
One day, we boarded a Broads Tours Company double-decker riverboat in bustling Wroxham on the Bure. After reassuring us that the river is only eight feet deep, our captain-cum-tour guide took us downriver past fanciful riverside cottages, including one shaped like a windmill and another like a beehive.
Throughout the 90-minute tour, the captain regaled us with an entertaining mix of history and personal reminiscences. We learned, for example, that older cottages are built on 90-foot alder wood stilts sunk into the marsh, while newer ones are built on steel. 
We learned also that the Broads' distinctive wide-hull, gaff-rigged sailing vessels known as wherries can navigate fully loaded in three feet of water. And we learned why most of the Broads' pubs are located on a bend in the river: 
In the days before engines, when the wind died, the wherries congregated at river bends. "And what better is there for sailors to do when there is no wind," asked our captain rhetorically, "but drink?" 
Another day, we joined a naturalist and another couple on a "wildlife water trail" managed by the How Hill Nature Reserve on the River Ant near Ludham. In a small electric boat, we left the river and glided into the reed bed, following a channel dug 200 years ago by reed cutters. 
Reeds swayed above our heads and brushed the sides of our little boat. We watched ruddy darter dragonflies lay eggs on the strawlike stems and listened to the call of a rare Cetti's warbler. 
The waving reeds are a crop as well as a refuge for rare species. An 18-inch-thick Norfolk reed thatch roof, we were told, can last for 70 years.
Suddenly, we heard a quiet putt-putt and behind us appeared a flat-hulled open boat driven by a ruddy-faced man in a squashy hat. It was Eric, a thatcher, out to cut marsh grass to use as roof capping. 
"Beautiful day for it," he called as he edged past us in the five-foot-wide channel.
That evening, we celebrated another day on the water with dinner at the Fisherman's Return in Winterton-on-Sea. In a 300-year-old flint and brick building, this pub offers exceptional meals in a cozy dining room warmed by a small fireplace and a large, dark-paneled bar room with a dart board. 
I tried a fizzy hard cider that came with a "careful, it's strong" warning from the smiling bartender (it was), while Bob sipped a Norfolk Wherry Bitter. Then we settled into a table near the fireplace for thick slices of hot, locally smoked salmon followed by fresh grilled lemon sole, tiny new potatoes and caramel apple tart.
We had intended to do as much walking as boating in the Broads. Paths are marked on local maps and identified with roadside signs. Yet we discovered that river walks often confined us between towering stands of reeds with no view of the water. 
And one meadow looked much like another as we trudged across it. So we shifted our focus to visiting nature preserves and ambling through villages. 
Typically, we would see a hand-made sign picturing the main historic occupation of a village (fishing boats, farmers, reed cutters), a village green, pub, church, grocer and tidy flower-bedecked homes. We found that grocers give directions, churches welcome visitors, local people love to discuss their gardens, and pubs offer well-prepared local specialties.
We combined village and nature walks one day in tiny Ranworth on the Bure River. Our first stop was St. Helen's Church -- to see the view from its bell tower and to admire its prize possession, the most complete 15th-century rood screen in England. Painted in faded blues, greens, yellows and reds the carved dark wooden screen depicts then-popular saints and the apostles, all looking, to my modern eyes, pale, hopeful and hungry.
Bob's poor eyesight made it unwise for him to climb the bell tower, so I set off alone. As I climbed up the narrow tower's steep, uneven stone steps, it was easy to imagine that the year was 1402, not 2002. 
I paused to breathe when I reached the wooden platform beside the bells, then climbed two iron ladders to the roof. Our informants had been right -- the view of church spires, white sails and blue ribbons of water threading through green fields was worth the quaking in my legs.
I rejoined my husband on the Norfolk Wildlife Trust's boardwalk nature trail, which guides visitors through all the Broads' habitats -- open water, reed bed, fen and alder woodland. The trail -- less than a mile -- leads to a visitor center in a thatched wooden building set on pontoons in Ranworth Broad. There, we collected a stack of postcards and toured an informative display about the Broads' ecology, economics, and social history. 
Just upriver from Ranworth is Horning, a village whose traditional prettiness made it one of my favorites. Its long main street beside the boat-filled Bure is lined with thatched cottages abloom with window boxes, local shops rather than tourist traps, pubs and several 19th-century hotels. 
On the day we visited, we ate a vegetable curry and local sausages and mash at the New Inn, a half-timbered pub with a beamed ceiling, and watched a heron stalk across a waterside lawn. 
To visit villages that weren't on a river, we drove narrow country lanes -- for instance, from tiny Sea Palling on the coast, south past the vast red Horsey wind pump, to stately Martham, whose Georgian houses range along its village green. 
By the end of our visit we were already waxing nostalgic about the call of gray lag geese, the whisper of reeds and the sight of a thick thatch roof curving above a window like an embrace.

Boating through the reeds, past swans and fishermen

Getting There
 East Anglia is a drive of around three and a half hours from London. We took the M11 to the A11 toward Norwich. From Norwich, the A47 leads to the Broads.
 Several airlines fly to Norwich International Airport from Manchester, Edinburgh and Amsterdam, but none from London. 
 But there is fast train service from Liverpool Street Station in London to Norwich, taking 1 hour 40 minutes.

Boating and Walking
 A comprehensive guide to activities, restaurants and accommodations in the Broads can be found at www.norfolkbroads.com.
 The Broads Authority, 18 Colegate, Norwich NR3 IBQ, (44-1603) 610-734, publishes excellent maps and guides to the area. Its Web site, www.broadsauthority.gov.uk, also provides a helpful introduction to the area. 
 Another source of information is the Norfolk Wildlife Trust, which manages several nature preserves in the Broads. Contact it at Bewick House, 22 Thorpe Road, Norwich, Norfolk, NR1 1RY; (44-1603) 625-540, fax (44-1603) 598-300; www.wildlifetrust.org.uk/norfolk.
 Broads Tours, a boat company consortium, offers guided tours and boat rentals by the hour, day or week, with rates starting at $16 an hour, $83 a day and $830 a week, at the rate of $1.60 to the pound. It has offices in Wroxham, Potter Heigham and Horning. For more information, call (44-1603) 782-207 or see www.broads.co.uk.

Where to Stay
 As house exchangers, we had our own home in Hemsby. But the Norwich Area Tourism Agency, Guild Hall, Gaol Hill, Norwich, NR2 1NF; (44-1603) 662-661, fax (44-1603) 666-687, www.visitnorwich-area.co.uk, lists many accommodations in its guide to the Broads.
An option is staying on the water. Norfolk Broads Direct, a subsidiary of Broads Tours, (44-1603) 782-207 and www.broads.co.uk, rents fully outfitted houseboats for three to seven nights. Prices range from about $500 to $1,500 depending on size of the boat and time of the year. 
 We toured several bed and breakfasts in the Broads:
 The Old Station House Bed and Breakfast, North Road, Hemsby, Great Yarmouth, Norfolk NR29 4EZ, (44-1493) 732-022, has three beautifully appointed, sparkling queen bedrooms. They share a bathroom, but each has a sink and they are being converted to private baths. The rate, $60 a room, includes a full breakfast. 
 The Swan Inn, Lower Street, Horning, Near Wroxham, Norfolk, NR12 8AA, (44-1692) 630-316, fax (44-1692) 630-821, is a historic inn on the River Bure. The 11 pleasant, modern rooms with private baths go for $95 to $105, with breakfast. 

Where to Eat
 The Fisherman's Return, the Lane, Winterton-on-Sea, Norfolk, (44-1493) 393-305 and www.fishermans-return.com, serves lunch and dinner daily. Dishes include grilled sole, battered cod, lamb shank in ginger, and fresh local crab. Dinner for two with wine runs about $50.
 The New Inn, Lower Street, Horning, Norfolk, (44-1692) 631-223 is open for lunch and dinner daily. Dishes include vegetable curry, Cromer crab, steak and ale pie, lamb shank in tomato. Dinner for two with ale, about $40.
 The Lion Inn, the Street, Thurne, Norfolk, (44-16692) 670-796, offers lunch and dinner daily. Choices include lamb balti, cumberland sausages and mash, grilled bream, six types of curry. Dinner for two with ale, about $40. AURELIA C. SCOTT

HEADLINE: SHEDDING POUNDS IN LEAN TIMES

 BODY:
 THE downturn in international tourism has led to exceptional deals on flights to Britain and accommodations there. "The industry is pulling together to really try to give British tourism the push that it needs right now," said Sarah Long of VisitBritain, formerly known as the British Tourist Authority. 
 Flight offers change so often and expire so rapidly that the best fares can usually be found on airlines' Web sites or on sites like Travelocity.com or Expedia.com. Last month, some flights between New York and London were going for less than $300 round trip. Prices rise as high season approaches, but there are plenty of deals this month and next. And even July and August -- high season -- still hold some bargains.

PERSON: Douglas R. Carmichael 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Eager to Be the Auditors' Auditor

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
BY his own admission, and yet by accident, Douglas R. Carmichael has been preparing for decades for his new job as the first chief auditor for the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, the recently created regulator of the accounting industry.
 Mr. Carmichael, 61, has taught auditing and accounting at Baruch College at the City University of New York for 20 years, and was on several people's short lists of candidates for the job. It is easy to see why: he has written widely used books on auditing and helped draft auditing standards in the 1970's and 80's. 
 He has also testified before federal regulators on rules that should govern accountants and before judges hearing cases involving complex accounting questions or ethical issues, expressing his opinions on what auditors should and should not have done. Those appearances have not endeared him to accounting firms, which have often been the defendants in such lawsuits.
"The litigation work has given me a real opportunity to know what is going on out in practice and to have a more realistic perspective," Mr. Carmichael said in an interview last week. He then uses that perspective in teaching students, many of whom will become auditors, he added.
Mr. Carmichael, who speaks slowly and gives the impression that he has carefully considered every word, was drawn to auditing the way other college students might be drawn to philosophy or even poetry.
"It brought together so many different elements in addition to accounting," said Mr. Carmichael, who received an economics degree in 1963 from the University of Illinois and a doctorate in accounting there in 1968. "It included ethics and legal liability and the use of technical tools like statistical sampling."
That holistic approach to auditing makes Mr. Carmichael a very persuasive expert, said Brian J. Gallagher, a lawyer at Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman in New York. "He understands, more significantly, the logic behind it all, what the standards are supposed to do, how these standards are supposed to work," said Mr. Gallagher, who has worked with him as an expert witness. "He defines that job, the one he has now."
Several accountants and lawyers who have worked with Mr. Carmichael or faced him as a hostile witness were reluctant to comment on his new position out of concern that any criticism might lead to unwelcome attention from the accounting oversight board. Some said privately that they feared he would endorse auditing standards that would be too restrictive, setting the bar unrealistically high for what accountants are expected to review and discover.
Others said they thought he would take a more moderate position as a regulator than he has in lawsuits.
After receiving his doctorate, Mr. Carmichael taught at the University of Texas in Austin. The American Institute of CertifiedPublic Accountants hired him in 1969, and he spent the bulk of the next 14 years researching and writing auditing standards, the rules and procedures that auditors are to follow when reviewing companies' financial results.
"We've got over 900 pages of well-developed standards," said Dan M. Guy, a certified public accountant and a litigation consultant in Santa Fe, N.M. Mr. Guy both worked with Mr. Carmichael and succeeded him at the institute. "Doug and I made a big contribution," Mr. Guy said.
Mr. Guy remembered calling Mr. Carmichael for help in resolving difficult issues even after Mr. Carmichael left the institute in 1983 for Baruch College. After that move, Mr. Carmichael began testifying in lawsuits as an accounting and auditing expert. His work for plaintiffs and, occasionally, for defendants began almost by accident, Mr. Carmichael said. 
But he said he testified only when confident of the facts. He described a case in which a lawyer asked for his help in defending an accounting firm that had been sued after failing to detect a fraud. Mr. Carmichael agreed initially, then learned that when the auditor had sought to confirm that the company's customers were legitimate, he had failed to notice that many of the customers' addresses were post office boxes.
"That was a clear warning sign that something was going on," he said. He did not testify.
And Mr. Carmichael does not condone subpar work, several colleagues said. He is demanding of his students and of himself, said Martin Benis, an accounting professor at Baruch, who hired him from the accounting institute.
"Not only is he not tolerant of substandard work, he does not tolerate fools easily," Mr. Benis said. "He has tremendous pride in the auditing profession, and he believes, I think, that the auditing profession has suffered a couple of black eyes because of substandard work."
Several lawyers said Mr. Carmichael's impatience with sloppy work, along with his willingness to give his opinion in no uncertain terms, make him a very good witness for whichever side he is on -- and make him trouble for opponents. He does not yield in his views, they said.
"The first time I ran into him, he was on the other side," said Gregory Markel, head of the litigation department at Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft, a law firm in New York, who found him to be an "extremely capable technical accountant, a highly articulate, strong-minded fellow."
"And I decided the next time I wanted him on my side," he added. 
Mr. Markel was representing an accounting firm that was being sued for not finding fraud at a company it audited; Mr. Carmichael was an expert witness for the plaintiff. "I've questioned a lot of expert witnesses in my day, including a fair number of accountants," Mr. Markel said, "and he was about as tough as I've seen."
Mr. Carmichael said he would continue as an expert witness in just a few lawsuits -- with board approval -- and withdraw from the rest.
Mr. Carmichael lives with his wife, Carol Schaller, the author of several books on computer auditing, on a farm in Lumberville, Pa., north of Philadelphia. He commuted to teach at Baruch, he said, but will now be on leave from the college. He plans to keep an apartment in Washington.
The new job may not endear him any further to accounting firms, Mr. Guy said, but he added that after serving as an expert witness against some firms, Mr. Carmichael was already accustomed to their hostility.
"It's not where you win friends," Mr. Guy said.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Coaching Unemployable to Be Reliable

BYLINE:  By Anthony DePalma 

 BODY:
SOME people let work define their lives. Not Israel Torres. For a long time he let his life define his work, and both were calamities. 
 For much of the last two decades, Mr. Torres, now 43, was on drugs. Crack, cocaine, you name it. They were his life, and his work. Dealing drugs was easy money, but it meant doing hard time, lots of it. Five years in one prison, three in another. When he got out, his former life came back like a stain in an old table. Another five years behind bars. 
 But the last time he was released, things changed. When his welfare benefits ran out, he was sent to a community group in the Bronx that promised to teach him not only how to find a job but also how to keep it. 
As politicians cut welfare rolls, they sometimes seem to forget that lives shattered by poverty, drug addiction or other problems may have lost the rudiments of work. Getting a job is hard. Sticking with it is harder.
Mr. Torres admits he had never held a real job, and didn't know what it meant to work responsibly. But last year, after a two-week boot camp that drilled him in fundamental work concepts like reliability and responsibility, he started on the production line at the A. L. Bazzini Company, an old New York nuts and dried fruits firm that moved to Hunts Point a few years ago. You can smell the roasting peanuts a mile away. 
Early this year, Mr. Torres got his first W-2 and he rejoiced. He now has money in his pockets, a regular job and a steady life. It feels good, he said, really good. 
"How're you doing?" a visitor asked Mr. Torres as he stirred a huge vat of cashews on the Bazzini production line. His one-word answer said it all: "Perfect." 
Mr. Torres is where he is now in large measure because of the Bazzini company's willingness to take risks and because of an employment program that combines job training with job custodianship in a new and effective way. 
"We're basically door-openers for people with multiple barriers to employment," said Mary Sprague, director of Managed Work Services, a program run by VIP Community Services, a nonprofit group in the Bronx. 
The concept is simple. Employers with low-skill jobs to fill are recruited. Sultana Distribution Corporation in the Bronx and Kruysman Inc., an envelope company in Queens, have also participated. So has the Bronx Zoo. The employers contract with Managed Work Services to fill fairly interchangeable positions. The company pays the program, which pays the workers.
Recruits go through two weeks of basic training, learning essentials like being on time and dressing properly for work. Counselors make sure they have sturdy shoes and wristwatches, and can read a bus schedule. 
When employees show up for work at the plant they are accompanied by a job coach paid by the program who oversees their break-in period. Like a production-line guardian angel, the coach helps take care of arranging doctors' appointments and baby sitters, the kinds of little issues that, if not handled properly, can cost workers their jobs. In a pinch, the coaches can replace workers on the line.
After six months of supervision, the workers can move to permanent jobs, which the program helps find. Just over 220 people have entered the program since it began last year. Of those, 121 did not complete the six-month transition period because one of those little life issues got in the way. An additional 45 are in the program and about 54 who completed the transition period have gotten permanent jobs, 10 of them at Bazzini. 
Rocco Damato, chief executive of Bazzini, said that besides getting highly motivated workers, he also qualifies for tax credits for hiring local people. 
Mr. Damato is participating in the program again and now has nine more transitional workers, including Theresa Berry, 45. She was on welfare pretty much since she was 18, addicted to drugs and unable even to consider taking a job. About a month ago, after her welfare benefits expired, Managed Work Services sent her to Bazzini. 
"I never thought I could make a month, but I did," Ms. Berry said proudly. She puts labels on boxes and stacks them on pallets. She makes $7 an hour, and for the first time in years she is making plans.
"I'm going to get me a new apartment, and then I'm going to buy things for my three godchildren," she said. More important is what holding down a job after so long says about her. 
"It shows," she said, "I can do something outside of just doing drugs." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Israel Torres, a former addict with a prison record, is holding down a steady job thanks to a boot camp in basic work skills. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS; 
Looking at Dollars and Cents of Widowhood

BYLINE:  By DIANE COLE 

 BODY:
IT'S not a pleasant truth. But for women, planning for retirement should generally include planning for possible widowhood, given the nearly six-year gap in life expectancy between the sexes. In fact, in the 2000 census, almost one-third of women between the ages of 65 and 74 described themselves as widowed. For women above 75, the figure was 61 percent.
 Moreover, on average, a woman earns just 76 cents for every dollar a man earns. That adds up to an estimated lifetime difference of more than $300,000, according to the Women's Institute for a Secure Retirement, a nonprofit organization, known as Wiser, that was founded by the Heinz Family Foundation. That means both less potential for an independent nest egg and a greater likelihood of lower Social Security benefit payments in retirement. 
 In addition, as many Americans worry about the path of the economy -- not to mention the effects of war and terrorism -- financial planners are reporting an increase in inquiries from men and women about how to prepare for the unexpected. 
Planning, of course, does not ease the pain of loss, but it can reduce financial anxieties. Sandra Barty of Center Lovell, Me., found herself without retirement savings when her husband, Dick, died in 1999.In fact, at the age of 57, "I didn't know where the money would come from that I needed to pay my living expenses, month to month," she said.
The couple were hardly poor. But upon her husband's death, income from his consulting business ended, and there were no insurance policies or other apparent sources of income.
"I was in shock," said Ms. Barty, 61, who has since become an educational consultant "I was grieving. I felt detached from the consequences of daily living. But the reality was, I also needed money to pay the bills."
The most direct way for women to build financial security is to set up and contribute to their own retirement accounts, said Ginita Wall, a certified financial planner in San Diego and the author of personal finance books.
More broadly, experts advise women to take a more active role in family financial matters. "A man is not a plan," Ms. Wall said.
"Too many women say, 'Oh, he's so good with money!' " Ms. Wall added. "But you need to know the basics, at the very least, because if he dies, you will be the one carrying things forward."
Women who are not involved in managing the family finances run the risk of finding out too late that their spouses were not nearly so good with money as they believed.
Nonetheless, financial planners report that many couples still play traditional roles, with men managing the family finances. "With careers, children and households to juggle, even highly skilled professionals are happy not to have one more thing on our plates," said Cindy Hounsell, the executive director of Wiser. But, she warned, these women may save time in the short run without realizing the long-term consequences.
In contrast, Janet Hays, now 73 and living in New York, used to sit down with her husband, David, every New Year's Day to plan their budget and investment decisions for the year. They used the software Quicken to keep track of their expenditures and to make sure they remained on target with their budget.
That financial teamwork prepared Ms. Hays, the author of "Retire in New York City -- Even if You're Not Rich" (Bonus Books), to handle her finances after her husband died in 1995, when both were 66. "There was a sense of partnership with finances throughout my marriage," she said, "and that provided the foundation afterward, as well."
Planning, of course, does not mean only saving. Financial counselors say couples should also consider estate planning to be sure their assets are distributed as they wish with as few tax consequences as possible.
Before having a will prepared, couples should double-check the names of beneficiaries who are listed on all legal and financial documents, including trusts.
"Most people don't realize that where I.R.A.'s, 401(k)'s, other retirement instruments and property are concerned, your will is not necessarily the last word," said Aytan Y. Bellin, a lawyer in New York who specializes in elder law, trusts and estates and disability law. "Even if you have cut a person out of your will, if he or she is the designated beneficiary on those other deeds or accounts, they are the ones who will inherit that property."
Widows who plan to remarry may want to consider a prenuptial agreement.
"Working out the prenup agreement was emotionally difficult because I found it very disturbing to think through every awful possibility to prevent against," said Jane Lattes-Swislocki, who lives in Rockland County, N.Y. Her first husband died in 1987, and she remarried four years later.
Her primary purpose in writing a prenuptial agreement, she said, was to protect the financial interests of her children, who were still young. Nine years into the second marriage, with her own four children and her husband's two children from his first marriage more on their own, the couple drafted what she calls a "midnuptial" agreement. It takes into account not only the children's interests but also the property the couple have bought jointly.
WHENEVER you have legal documents written or revised, make sure you understand the ramifications of every legal provision, said Ms. Wall, the planner in San Diego. She recalled a widow whose husband had transferred all his real estate assets into a trust with the intention that should he die, his widow would receive the rental income until her death; the property would then be left to his children from his first marriage.
"But that's not what happened," Ms. Wall said. Because the trust's wording was ambiguous, the widow received only a small part of the income. The rest went to trust funds designated for her husband's children.
Perhaps the most basic issue is deciding whose advice is best. After her husband's death, Ms. Barty received well-meaning advice from relatives and friends, and she "inherited" a lawyer and broker from her husband. But she found that none of these people could provide the comprehensive planning she wanted.
In such cases, "look at the advisers you and your husband had, and if you're not satisfied, then find someone else," said Alexandra Armstrong, chairwoman at Armstrong, MacIntyre & Severns, a financial planning firm in Washington. Better yet, she said, couples should find advisers with whom they are comfortable while they are still together, and with whom either spouse could work if the other dies.
Ultimately, Ms. Barty sought out a financial planner, Janet Press, based in Tarrytown, N.Y. Ms. Press helped her see that she had a source of income after all: she could rent out her husband's country house, which she had inherited, and earn enough money to pay her own housing expenses. Ms. Press also encouraged her to pursue ways to use her graduate training asa teacher and consultant to earn a living.
But when it comes to financial preparedness, the sooner the better. "As you plan for retirement, from the start be a partner with your husband," Ms. Press advised. "Make sure you share the same goals, and that you both understand the consequences of your decisions."

HEADLINE: A New Technology, Now That New Is Old 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
MARTIN PICHINSON is one of Silicon Valley's undertakers. His company, Sherwood Partners, has carved out a prosperous niche as an expert in shutting down failed technology start-ups on behalf of venture capital firms and other disenchanted investors. And, this summer, he plans to move his company's headquarters to Palo Alto, Calif., the heartland of opportunity for his rapidly growing business.
 Mr. Pichinson, 57, does not always bury companies. Some can be rehabilitated or sold off. But Sherwood Partners has shut down 150 once-aspiring start-ups in the last two years, and Mr. Pichinson figures that thousands more are destined to fold. His company stands ready to help things along. 
 "We're doctors of reality," said Mr. Pichinson, who began his business career in the garment industry. "You don't have to have a Harvard M.B.A. to know that more money has to come in than go out." 
The winnowing of the corporate population is just one sign that the information technology industry is maturing in ways that will affect technology companies, their customers and investors for years to come. But what's painful for Silicon Valley is beneficial for those who use the stuff it produces.
The industry, according to Irving Wladawsky-Berger, a strategy executive at I.B.M., has entered "the post-technology era." It is not that technology itself no longer matters, he explained. Instead, he said, the steady advances in chips, disk storage and software mean that the focus is no longer on the technology itself -- with its arcane language of processing speeds and gigabytes -- but on what people and companies can do with it.
As a result, industry executives and analysts say, the balance of power is shifting away from technology suppliers and toward their corporate customers. At the same time, the use of lower-cost building blocks of computer hardware and software is spreading, making it easier for companies and individuals to share data and work together using industry standards rather than remain dependent on one or two main suppliers.
These trends, they say, point to increased pressure on prices and profits for most technology companies, a good deal for corporate customers and a very tricky time for investors.
This is more than a backlash against the bubble years, or a mere pendulum swing in attitudes and practices. The technology itself will still deliver waves of innovation in the future. Yet an industry that has risen to account for 10 percent of the economy and nearly 60 percent of business capital spending can no longer play by its own rules.
"I don't see a loss of faith in technology, but gravity has been turned back on," said Dick Lampman, the director of Hewlett-Packard's research laboratories. 
Yet an article published last week in The Harvard Business Review does question corporate America's faith in the value of technology. Titled "IT Doesn't Matter," the article argues that information technology is inevitably headed in the same direction as the railroads, the telegraph, electricity and the internal combustion engine.
All of these industrial technologies aged from their boom-time youth to become, in economic terms, ordinary factors of production, or "commodity inputs," the article noted. "From a strategic standpoint, they became invisible; they no longer mattered," wrote Nicholas G. Carr, editor at large of The Harvard Business Review. "That is exactly what is happening to information technology today."
Most corporate executives, however, still think there is a lot they can do with technology to give them an edge. Glen Salow, the chief information officer of the American Express Company, sees the recent trends in the industry as working to his advantage. First, he said, the hard times in the technology business have increasingly meant that big corporate customers hold the upper hand in their dealings with suppliers. That shift, Mr. Salow added, has given him not only more bargaining power on price, but also more influence in the products and services that are developed.
Corporate customers want to use technology to achieve goals like cutting costs, improving customer service and speeding the pace of bringing new products to market. But in the past, the computer industry has often treated customers with a certain arrogance, selling raw technology, take it or leave it.
MR. SALOW recalled a conversation he had in the late 1990's with the chief executive of a major computer company, whom he declined to identify. As Mr. Salow recalled, the computer executive told him, "My job is to make the hottest box on earth and deliver it on your loading dock."
"You don't hear that kind of talk anymore from him or anyone else," he said. "There has been a huge change from that perspective. The voice of the customer is being heard."
Corporate customers are insisting that technology companies adopt industry-standard software formats and communications protocols, so that the many different kinds of computer systems in corporate data centers can work together. In doing so, the companies are encouraging a technology trend that was really kicked off by the Internet, with its global reach that connects all sorts of technologies. For the Internet to work, the computer plumbing had to cooperate. And hardware and software standards make it more difficult for technology companies to "lock in" customers to their more expensive, homegrown technology offerings.
With their new power, customers are also pressing for greater flexibility in how they buy computing resources -- especially as a utility-style service in which they pay only for as much as they use, as if they were buying electricity. Mr. Salow signed a utility pricing and outsourcing deal with I.B.M. last year, in which 1,500 technology workers were transferred to I.B.M. The arrangement, he explained, reduces fixed technology expenses, giving American Express more flexibility. 
The widespread use of software standards, Mr. Salow added, enables the thousands of internal programmers at American Express to build new applications almost as if snapping together Lego blocks, reducing the amount of code that has to be written by hand. A result, he said, is that the software for, say, a new credit card offering or a fraud-detection feature can be built and put into use in about two weeks; five years ago, this might have taken six months. 
"It all frees you up to take more gambles because each risk is not so costly and you can move a lot faster," Mr. Salow said.
Several big companies besides I.B.M. -- including Hewlett-Packard, Sun Microsystems, Microsoft, Oracle and Veritas -- are moving to utility computing. But Salesforce.com was founded in 1999 specifically to capitalize on the trend. It sells sales-force automation software over the Internet; users with a standard Web browser get access to it for a monthly fee.
Marc R. Benioff, the founder and chief executive of Salesforce.com, regards his company as a force for change in an industry that he says is still mired in the "preutility era." In the future, Mr. Benioff said, "the risk and complexity of computing should shift to the utility."
Mr. Benioff's message and his low-cost, no-frills offering have gone over well at a time when companies are squeezing technology budgets.
Salesforce.com expects its revenue to about double this year, to $100 million. The company has started with sales-force automation, a software market where Siebel Systems is the leader.
Yet Mr. Benioff has ambitious plans to move into other big software markets where companies like SAP, PeopleSoft and others sell software for managing manufacturing, planning, human resources and other operations for large corporations. These big, complex "enterprise" software systems can cost millions of dollars and take several months or years to install and use.
"I think there is going to be a huge democratization of these enterprise technologies because of this on-demand computing enabled by the Internet," Mr. Benioff said. "Our evangelical mission is to destroy enterprise software as it exists today."
THE push toward utility computing, according to Mr. Wladawsky-Berger of I.B.M., fits neatly into his concept of a post-technology era. "In the last few years," he said, "the underlying components have become so powerful, reliable and inexpensive that you don't have to worry so much about the underlying engine, and you can move up to higher-level concerns." 
I.B.M. has moved more and more toward becoming a provider not only of technology, but also of business expertise in 17 industries from banking to electronics and transportation. Its $3.5 billion purchase of PricewaterhouseCoopers Consulting last year was a step toward that goal.
Mr. Wladawsky-Berger is in charge of guiding that strategy, which I.B.M. is promoting as "on-demand computing." The on-demand concept represents a maturing of computing in a sense, he said, but more as "the next evolutionary step in information technology, where the fun really begins" rather than an aging industry in decline.
Each successive wave of computing -- from mainframes to minicomputers to personal computers to the Internet -- has opened the door to new users and created new problems. Each of those, in turn, must be addressed if the industry is to move ahead. The Internet brought an explosion of computing complexity. And while many dot-coms are gone, Internet technology has spread widely, becoming a mainstream technology in corporations.
Marc Andreessen, a co-founder of Netscape Communications, whose software introduced Web browsing to millions and touched off the Internet boom, is now chairman of Opsware, whose data-center software is intended to tackle the complexity crisis. "At Netscape, we were building all the software components that made this possible and created the problem, and we didn't grasp the implications," said Mr. Andreessen, who is 31.
I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and Sun have also begun major efforts to address the complexity problem with automated management tools that can replace people. But analysts say there is also room for innovative start-ups like Opsware.
"At the same time there is this relentless cost-cutting, there is also a lot of excitement about this market for tools to cope with the complexity conundrum, where a boatload of computer science is going to have to move into the corporate mainstream," said Mark Stahlman, an independent industry analyst.
Roger McNamee has been a professional investor in technology companies for more than two decades, starting as an analyst at T. Rowe Price. In 1991, backed by Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm, Mr. McNamee became a co-founder of Integral Capital Partners, a so-called crossover fund investing in start-ups as well as fast-growing public companies. Integral Capital thrived in the 1990's. But late in the decade, Mr. McNamee said he and his partners became "really concerned about how wacky the market had become." In the second half of 1999, at the peak of the bubble, Integral returned $1.5 billion to investors in its main fund.
In 1999, Mr. McNamee and three colleagues founded Silver Lake Partners to invest in mature companies. Silver Lake quickly raised $2.3 billion from institutional investors and wealthy individuals, including three of technology's best-known billionaires, Bill Gates, Lawrence J. Ellison and Michael Dell. Silver Lake's strategy is to make longer-term investments, taking a five-year perspective, of $250 million or so in each company. "We're looking mostly for winners in consolidating industries," Mr. McNamee explained. "This is a period of thinning the herd."
And once the downturn is over, Mr. McNamee is skeptical that spending on technology will ever return to its long-term trend, dating back to the 1960's, of increasing at two to three times the growth rate of the economy. So, he said, broad-based technology funds are probably a formula for losing money. "This is absolutely a stock-picker's environment," Mr. McNamee observed. 
For its part, Silver Lake is betting that the corporate winners will include Flextronics, a contract manufacturer of computers, cellphones and other products; Seagate Technology, a disk drive maker; Gartner Inc., the technology research firm; and Ameritrade, the online broker.
One of Silver Lake's investors, Mr. Ellison, the chairman of Oracle, has been one of the most vocal proponents of the view that the technology industry is graying. "Thousands of companies are on life support that just have to die," he said. "Our industry is in the inevitable process of maturing."
Yet Mr. Ellison's concept of a maturing industry is not exactly a listless old age. There will be fewer companies and slower growth, he said, but still plenty of leeway for entrepreneurial creativity. "There will continue to be very cool new computing technologies," Mr. Ellison said.
Unlike so many industrial technologies -- railroads, say, or the telegraph -- the stored-program computer is a general-purpose tool, animated by software, a medium without material constraints. The unrelenting pace of improvement in processing speeds, data storage and miniaturization means the tools are more powerful and smaller; people then figure out things to do with them.
Indeed, innovation continues apace, despite the downturn. Advances are evident in a range of technologies -- wireless, data center automation, speech recognition, intelligent software, telephone service over the Internet, sensors, natural language processing, and on and on. 
Underestimating the potential for computing has proved a common pitfall over the years, from Thomas J. Watson at I.B.M. in 1943 ("I think there is a world market for maybe five computers") Ken Olsen at Digital Equipment in 1977 ("There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home").
Jim Gray, a computer scientist, has worked in the industry for more than 30 years. For his pioneering research on databases and transaction processing at I.B.M. and elsewhere, he won the 1999 A. M. Turing Award, sometimes called the Nobel of computer science. "I've seen the 'end' at least twice in my career -- only to be surprised by the next wave," said Mr. Gray, who now works for Microsoft. "My guess is that this computer thing has just gotten started."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; 
Pantries Face Bare Shelves And Higher Demand

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Elisa Baez, a 25-year-old mother of three from the Kingsbridge neighborhood in the Bronx, is neither homeless nor unemployed. Still, she goes to a food pantry on 86th Street and West End Avenue to stretch her paycheck with donated rice and cans of tuna fish. 
 But lately, she has been leaving empty-handed. "They run out of food sometimes," Ms. Baez, a nursing home attendant, said as she left the West Side Campaign Against Hunger last week. "So I have to come back." 
 As one of the city's largest and best-run pantries, the West Side Campaign, located in the basement of the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, usually has a surplus. But for the first time in its 25-year history, dozens of people are being turned away each day.
 "You can see through the shelves," Kirstin Swanson, a pantry spokeswoman, said as she surveyed the supermarket-style aisles the other day. 
 Throughout the city, activists say, the anemic economy has driven tens of thousands of working New Yorkers, like Ms. Baez, into food pantries and soup kitchens, and simultaneously shrunk donations to those organizations.
The West Side Campaign, for example, served some 3,000 households in March, nearly 1,000 more than in March 2002. Meanwhile, it is receiving 30 percent less food from the federal government, by far its largest supplier. 
 "That mirrors the pretty dramatic need in food pantries across the city," said Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger, which represents 1,018 pantries. "Even the best programs are turning people away, so I can only imagine what the others are doing."
 City officials paint a very different picture. 
 "There is no indication of an upsurge of demand, no request for additional food, and no indication that people are being turned away," said Frank Sobrino, a spokesman for the city's Human Resources Administration. If the West Side Campaign Against Hunger is seeing an increase, he added, "they haven't told us." Nevertheless, other food organizations echo the message of the West Side Campaign. The Food Bank for New York City, which supplies much of the canned food to city pantries, reports a 7 percent decline in its stocks this year. City Harvest, which redistributes bread and other perishables from restaurants, is reducing its deliveries by one million pounds, or about 5 percent. 
 "We're seeing less food throughout the entire food chain," said Julia Erickson, City Harvest's executive director. Because fewer people are eating out, she said, "restaurants have less food to give." 
 The outlook may worsen, advocates warn. The contingency budget proposed by Mayor Bloomberg would eliminate the only city program that supplies food to pantries and soup kitchens. The $7.7 million program provides about eight million meals a year. 
 On her return trip last week, Ms. Baez was able to fill two large bags with powdered mashed potatoes, rice and canned fruit. She began coming to the pantry last winter, she said, because money had become tight. 
 "I used to be full-time, but now I'm only part-time," she said. "Everyone is making less money." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: NEW YORK OBSERVED; 
A Virus of Fear

BYLINE:  By MARC SIEGEL; Marc Siegel is an internist and an associate professor of medicine at New York University Medical School.

 BODY:
THE small waiting room in my office near New York University Medical Center is just as congested as the rest of New York, with patients sitting practically on top of one another. As with the subway, it feels as if germs here might spread more quickly than other places, and I half expect my patients to catch the bug their neighbor is harboring. But whether the risk of catching something from another patient is real or imagined, one thing is certain. The stress of living and working in the city may make it seem so. 
 Added to this mix we now have the tangible-seeming risk of SARS. My waiting room is filled with patients brimming with the same question. "Could I have SARS?" a patient blurts out. Unsolicited, an office secretary replies, "You must ask the doctor." Meanwhile, the 13-inch television set in the middle of the room is playing all SARS all the time and updating my patients on the virus every hour. 
 An Asian-American architect has come to see me for the first time. No one sits next to him in the waiting room, and when he coughs, the room empties out altogether. 
 In my examination room, the architect announces that he returned from Hong Kong a few weeks ago. He travels to China and Hong Kong on business every few weeks, but because of the effect of the SARS scare on the economy there, he has lost his latest architectural job and has had to come back. On the plane bringing him home, he says, no one would sit with him. 
 He has come to me with a cough and symptoms of a cold, but no fever, no muscle aches, no difficulty breathing. Hearing this, I want to don a mask, but I put on gloves instead. 
 My patient plays down his symptoms, clearly realizing I may be worried about SARS. 
 "It's just a cold," he says. "It was going away, then it came back a little. It's only a tickle." 
 Without saying the magic word, I reassure him that what he has sounds not like something sinister but like simple bronchitis. I give him an antibiotic and send him home. 
 Afterward, I am suddenly nervous, thinking of my two young children. Doctors are not immune to worries about contagion. The concern doesn't go away completely until I have taken a shower and irrationally washed away the psychological remnant of my fear. It is the same thing I used to do for AIDS in the 80's, scrubbing my hands after every encounter with every patient, whether or not they might have AIDS.
 A week later, the architect has returned to the office with a smile rather than a cough. During that week, the specter of SARS has spread through the world more rapidly than even the disease itself. Though no new cases have been reported in the city, New Yorkers are increasingly frightened, increasingly wary. 
 Asia is more isolated than before, and the architect has no immediate prospect for work there. Here in New York, he thinks people are taking into account his Asian features and coloring and avoiding him on the street. I can see this occurring in my waiting room, where the other patients now deliberately avoid not only him but anything he has touched. 
 So why is the architect smiling? In my consultation room he confesses that he was actually afraid he had SARS, but now that he knows he doesn't, even though he is not working, he believes his future is bright. 
 New Yorkers are a nervous bunch to begin with, and their doctors are no exception. Most of us, doctors and patients alike, are medical Zeligs; like Woody Allen's character, we take on the symptoms and even the personality of the latest threat. In this case the global health alert and travel advisories that are meant to contain the droplets of the virus also spread virulent fear by word of mouth. The city felt this fear and vulnerability for many months pre-SARS; now the fear of bioterrorism has been converted into a fear of a deadly mystery virus.
 The stress of living in New York helps distort perceptions. The scientific literature analyzing the health of the city's residents shows, for example, that a disproportionately high percentage of adult New Yorkers suffer from heart disease related to a higher level of stress. After studying this phenomenon, the journal Psychosomatic Medicine reported in 1999 that these conditions were due to the strain of life in New York itself. 
 New Yorkers compensate for the pressure they feel by paying more attention to their symptoms, to every itch and twinge, as if this vigilance might protect us from an ever hostile environment. We seek out doctors more, and use elaborate health care nets to protect from the ultimate free fall.
 Our method of coping seems to be more successful than it gets credit for. A few weeks ago, to widespread amazement, the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene released statistics showing that despite all the stress of city living, the average lifespan in New York is higher than anywhere else in the country. 
 AND so, in the new era of fear of SARS, we molt and adapt, and before long we develop a new sort of shtick. Though New Yorkers always cough and kvetch, I've never heard so much nervous coughing before. We have always seemed on the verge of catching something, or, if not actually catching something, at least complaining that we might. Now each raspy breath seems more significant, each sniffling acquaintance seems ominously afflicted. 
 My office phone is ringing continually with respiratory complaints. I know better than to counter these concerns with the bald statistic of zero deaths from SARS in the United States so far. I don't want to appear to be playing down serious potential risk. If SARS spreads as easily as the common cold but is more deadly, it could cause medical mayhem here. Because we live in close quarters, the spread of any disease may be eased by proximity.
 In the meantime, New Yorkers are building a defense to the fear. Simply put, we get used to the latest obsession more quickly than people in other places do. There is nothing about this in the medical literature, but I am positive that as a group we dust ourselves off faster, suppress our worries quicker and return to work faster. We may be complainers, but we rally fast.
 Our respiratory filters join our gas masks and our stash of antibiotics in our tiny closets. If and when SARS actually comes here, beyond the small number of current probable cases -- two in New York City, according to the Centers for Disease Control -- we will have prepared ourselves for the idea. 
 We were made to feel vulnerable by the attacks of Sept. 11, but we were also toughened by them. And we were tough before. Like the architect, I am almost ready to get used to the idea of SARS, to resume my normal business and stop thinking about it. Before long, the patients in my waiting room will follow suit. 
 By the time SARS takes hold in New York, if it does, we'll be ready. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Yorkers are old hands at building defenses to their worries, even aboard the No. 6 train. We may be complainers, but we rally fast. (Catherine Leuthold/Corbis SABA)

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Profits Recover.Jobs Vanish. Stocks Rise.

BYLINE:  By JEFF SOMMER 

 BODY:
The three major stock market indexes rose last week as upbeat corporate earnings announcements cheered many investors, despite a report that unemployment deepened in April.
 It was the third consecutive positive week for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which is up 5.7 percent for the year, and for the Nasdaq composite index, which has risen 12.5 percent. 
By contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell the previous week, is up only 2.9 percent for the year. 
 On Friday, investors shrugged off a Labor Depart-ment report that the unemployment rate in April rose to 6 percent from 5.8 percent, matching an eight-year high. 
 McDonald's was the best performer among the Dow stocks, rising 11.26 percent for the week. Shares of SBC Communications and J.P. Morgan Chase also rose more than 7 percent each.
 For the week, the Dow gained 276.33 points, or 3.3 percent, to 8,582.68, while the S.& P. 500 climbed 31.27 points, or 3.5 percent, to 930.08. The Nasdaq rose 68.34 points, or 4.8 percent, to 1,502.88.
 The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 3.93 percent, from 3.89 percent a week earlier. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Bah, Wilderness! Reopening a Frontier to Development

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE 

 BODY:
MORE than a century after historians declared an end to the American Frontier, the Interior Department made a somewhat similar announcement last month, with no fanfare. On a Friday night, just after Congress had left for spring break, the government said it would no longer consider huge swaths of public land to be wilderness.
 The administration declared that it would end reviews of Western landholdings for new wilderness protection. As long as the lands had been under consideration for the American wilderness system, they had temporary protection from development. 
 With a single order, the Bush administration removed more than 200 million acres from further wilderness study, including caribou stamping ground in Alaska, the red rock canyons and mesas of southern Utah, Case Mountain with its sequoia forests in California and a wall of rainbow-colored rock known as Vermillion Basin in Colorado.
By declaring an end to wild land surveys, the administration ruled out protection of these areas as formal wilderness -- which, by law, are supposed to be places people can visit but not stay. Now, these areas, managed by the Bureau of Land Management, could be opened to mining, drilling, logging or road-building.
The idea of designating an area as wilderness -- wild land left as is, for its own sake -- is an American construct. Artists and writers in the mid-19th century led the charge for wilderness, with Henry David Thoreau arguing from his pond-side home in Concord, Mass., that wilderness sanctuaries were a necessary complement to civilization.
In setting aside the first wildlife refuge in 1903, on Pelican Island in Florida, President Theodore Roosevelt protected a patch of America that is now the smallest of the formally protected lands -- a mere five acres. And since passage of the Wilderness Act of 1964, 106 million acres have been given the wild lands designation, with more than half of that total in Alaska.
Over the years, the Bureau of Land Management, the nation's biggest landlord, with 262 million acres under its control, has continued to survey its vast holdings, trying to determine whether more land is suitable for wilderness. But the Bush administration says wilderness reviews should have ended 13 years ago, at the close of a study period mandated by Congress. This interpretation is challenged by conservationists who plan to appeal the Bush order in court. 
If the Friday night declaration represents the beginning of a broad new land management policy, the Interior Department has not said so. There was not even an announcement of the end of the wilderness reviews on the department's Web site.
Instead, the change came about in a settlement of a 1996 lawsuit filed by the State of Utah against the Interior Department over a reinventory of three million acres conducted by Bruce Babbitt, the interior secretary at the time. Most of the lawsuit had been dismissed and sat dormant until the state amended its complaint in March.
"This does not mean that someday down the road we may still manage some of these lands as wilderness," said Patricia Lynn Scarlett, an assistant interior secretary.
The move follows a consistent pattern in the president's environmental policy: to change the way the land is managed, without changing the law. Whether the issue is allowing snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park or logging in the Pacific Northwest, the course has been to settle lawsuits by opponents of wild land protection, opening up the areas to wide use, without going to Congress to rewrite the rules.
Oil and gas developers and others point out that the Clinton administration did the same thing -- making broad changes of policy by administrative order -- but on behalf of an environmental constituency. In their view, wilderness protection amounts to a land grab, putting potential timber or mining areas off limits. They say citizen groups were abusing the law by bringing land surveys to the government, which then managed the land as de facto wilderness. Leaders of some Western states have long complained that wilderness study essentially eliminates the chance to gain any economic value from the land, money that is needed for state coffers.
To many conservationists, the announcement was more than another setback. Wilderness, in the oft-quoted line of the writer Wallace Stegner, is "the geography of hope." To have that geography capped, they argue, has had the same effect on some outdoor lovers as the fencing of the public range had on open-country cattle ranchers. "They are trying to declare, by fiat, that wilderness does not exist," said Heidi McIntosh of the Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance.
The interior secretary, Gale A. Norton, said that the policy reflected the administration's attempt to cooperate with local officials and heed concerns of industries that rely on public lands' resources. "The Department of the Interior believes that we should manage these lands in a way that provides the greatest benefit to the public," Ms. Norton wrote in a letter to Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah.
In another letter, Ms. Norton said it seemed senseless to consider declaring any more wilderness areas in Alaska because its elected officials are against expanding this protection. But critics say that in California, a majority of elected officials favor more wilderness. And in New Mexico, Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, has asked the government to prevent drilling in 1.8 million acres of the Otero Mesa, an area that has all the qualities of wilderness.
The New Mexico land is the largest contiguous piece of Chihuahuan Desert grassland left in North America, Governor Richardson said. It may be wild, but for now, it can no longer be Wilderness.

GRAPHIC: Photos: After a Bush administration order, Fisher Towers in Utah, top, and Bering Glacier in Alaska among other areas could be reopened to mining, drilling, logging or road-building. (Jamie Buscher)

HEADLINE: State Says Businesses Must Wait 2 More Months for 9/11 Recovery Aid 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Four months after applying for government aid under a program to help small businesses in Lower Manhattan recover from the World Trade Center attack, 1,600 businesses are still waiting for their promised grants, and government officials now say they will have to wait up to two months more.
 Owners of many businesses say they need the money now as they continue struggling to overcome steep losses they suffered when the September 2001 terrorist attack forced them to close for weeks or months and then led to sharply reduced business after they reopened. The undelivered grants total more than $54 million, an average of nearly $34,000 each. 
 But the state agency that runs the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program says that the delay, paradoxically, is a sign of the program's success. Officials of the agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, say the program drew so many qualified applicants that the total amount of the approved grants, $535.3 million, exceeded the $481 million that the agency established for the program. 
A spokesman for the agency, Alex Dudley, said that more than 13,500 companies had been approved for the existing $481 million allocation, and that the vast majority of those companies had received their grants.
The agency's need to obtain the additional $54.3 million has caused the delay in delivering the grants to the 1,600 businesses that were approved for that amount, Mr. Dudley said last week. Another factor, he said, is that many applications arrived in a surge in the weeks before the Dec. 31 deadline, causing a backlog in the review and approval process that kept the agency from knowing until March how much more money it had to seek.
The agency is now asking for those funds from another state body, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which controls hundreds of millions of dollars in unallocated money that the federal government has made available, Mr. Dudley said.
Obtaining the additional funds requires the approval of both the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's board and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the federal agency that provided the money, and a successful effort will take until July, a spokesman for the Lower Manhattan agency said. 
The spokesman, Matthew Higgins, said the agency's board was likely to consider the request at its next meeting, on May 15. If it approves the application, a 15-day waiting period for public comments is required before the request can go to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, where, Mr. Higgins said, consideration of such applications usually takes about 30 days.
But Roy A. Bernardi, the department's assistant secretary for community planning and development, said his agency would "make every effort to fast-track" any such request, and an aide, who spoke on the condition of not being identified, cited possible approval by his agency "within two weeks."
Either way, it means more waiting and more frustration for people like Bruce Kessler, who said that he applied on Dec. 27 for a grant for his catering company and that Empire State awarded it more than $20,000 on Feb. 24. He needs the money now, he said.
"We lost $150,000 to $200,000" in the year after the trade center attack, he said, and "we're still 50 percent down" from the level of business before then. He said he wanted to use the money "to hire people to market the company more," which he said was vital in seeking to gain new clients in a very competitive business. His firm, CEO Catering, was on Warren Street, several blocks from the trade center. It has since moved to SoHo.
"When you call, they apologize and empathize and say they're doing the best they can," Mr. Kessler said of his inquiries to Empire State about when he might see the money.
Mr. Dudley said pretty much the same thing: "We're working as hard as possible to get them the money as soon as possible."
Under the program, businesses and nonprofit groups between 14th Street and the Battery with fewer than 500 employees were eligible for compensation for economic losses stemming from the terrorist attack.
Those in the trade center or close to it were generally eligible for up to 25 days' worth of losses, to a maximum of $300,000. Those in the program's zone farthest from the trade center -- from Houston to 14th Street -- generally qualified for up to three days' worth of losses, to a maximum of $50,000.
Though the total $535.3 million approved for more than 15,000 businesses and nonprofit groups averaged about $35,000 each, Empire State reported in November that half of the grants were for less than $13,300.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bruce Kessler has moved CEO Catering from downtown to SoHo. He says he needs a $20,000 grant to "market the company more." (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)
