HEADLINE: As SARS Outbreak Took Shape, Health Agency Took Fast Action 

BYLINE:  By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. with LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 2 

 BODY:
It took until mid-March nearly four months after the first outbreak -- for the world to learn of SARS. Yet a look back at the early days of the epidemic, and at the earliest warnings given to the World Health Organization, leaves little doubt that the agency acted as swiftly as it could.
 Some opportunities were missed along the way, and the health agency was led astray by assumptions that later proved wrong. But public health experts say the agency's investigators are only as powerful as the information they have to work with. And from the start, they were frustrated by the lack of official candor in China, where severe acute respiratory syndrome first erupted last November. 
 "W.H.O. did a fantastic job," said Dr. Jack Woodall, the moderator of ProMED, the Federation of American Scientists' Program for Monitoring Emerging Diseases, which as early as Feb. 10 posted an alert on its Web site about a mysterious outbreak in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou. "They acted marvelously and exemplarily, as fast as they could. But it dragged on and on because China wouldn't cooperate. 
"The World Health Organization isn't the world health police," he continued. "It's a club, like a club in Boston where everyone's a member and they slap each other on the back. Every member's a sovereign country, and if they don't want to report something, they don't."
Dr. Barry R. Bloom, dean of the Harvard School of Public Health, said the global alert issued by the health agency on March 12 was "enormously courageous."
"They took an enormous risk," Dr. Bloom said. "If you ask 'What risk?' I remind you of swine flu."
In 1976, a single death in New Jersey from what was feared to be a genetic echo of the killer swine flu of 1918 set off a panicky rush for a vaccine. The disease disappeared after infecting only 500 people, the vaccine was abandoned after 32 deaths from side effects, and the director of the federal Centers for Disease Control was dismissed.
The Outbreak Center, on the fourth floor of Building L of the W.H.O. campus here, began officially querying China about its mysterious epidemic on Feb. 10. As Chinese officials have since acknowledged, the response was a mix of inept diagnoses, outright lies and, finally, stonewalling.
Over the next two weeks, Chinese officials said that the outbreak had killed only five people and that it had been snuffed out in the province of Guangdong, where Guangzhou is. They then said it had been caused by a mycoplasma, then by chlamydia. They then stopped responding and forbade doctors to do so. It was not until April 20 -- when China's health minister was dismissed -- that the epidemic's true scope began to emerge.
By Feb. 12, frustrated flu specialists in Hong Kong working with the World Health Organization quietly carried out a sort of medical commando raid, slipping into Guangdong hospitals to get tissue samples from dying patients. But because the specialists were looking for bird flu viruses, they missed the apparent cause of SARS, a coronavirus.
And on Feb. 19, the organization and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sent a joint investigative team to Beijing to find out what was going on in southern China. But Beijing health officials stalled the team until they gave up. Permission to visit Guangdong was not given until April 2.
There were two unlucky misses very early in the epidemic. On Nov. 20, at what is thought to be the very beginning of the outbreak, a W.H.O. flu specialist who was in Beijing for a vaccine conference heard of a spate of unusual deaths among health care workers in Guangdong, which he now suspects included SARS cases. He requested tissue samples, but the ones he received contained only common flu strains.
And on Nov. 27, a report of a "flu outbreak" closing schools and factories was picked up by a Canadian Health Ministry computer that sifts news reports for the W.H.O. But the report was never translated from the Chinese.
More important, investigators believed as late as mid-March that China was secretly and stoically fighting a new bird flu strain, possibly one as lethal as the swine strain, then called "Spanish flu," that killed more than 25 million people in 1918 and 1919.
That notion was reinforced on Feb. 19, when two real cases of bird flu were diagnosed.
"In retrospect, this was a total coincidence," said Dr. Stephen M. Ostroff, deputy director of the C.D.C.'s National Center for Infectious Diseases. "But our feeling was that this was the unifying hypothesis behind the outbreaks."
The crucial moment that sent the disease caroming around the world, probably a sneeze or cough in Hong Kong's Metropole Hotel, took place on Feb. 21.
But that would not be known for weeks, and even Canadian officials say the W.H.O. reacted as quickly as it could.
"They were working with what they had," said Allison McGeer, a Toronto doctor who later fell ill herself fighting the epidemic, but recovered. "We knew from ProMED that something was going on. But having the announcement a few days earlier would still almost certainly have not been able to prevent initial spread. There were too many things we didn't know."

An Illness Emerges
On Nov. 20, Dr. Klaus Stohr was in Beijing to discuss China's flu vaccination policy. Dr. Stohr heads the W.H.O.'s flu program, for which 111 laboratories around the world annually scan 200,000 samples from flu victims, looking for candidates for the next year's vaccine.
As it happened, the first case of SARS had emerged that month in Guangdong, perhaps in the markets where all sorts of live animals, including chickens, cats, turtles and badgers, are sold for food. At the meeting in Beijing, Guangdong's representative described a small flu outbreak that had killed several people in one hospital. "I think that was SARS," Dr. Stohr said in hindsight. 
At the time, though, there was no particular reason to suspect that the outbreak was anything other than flu, Dr. Stohr said. In epidemiological terms, "one or three or five deaths in a province of 55 million is nothing."
"But," he said, "I thought, 'Let's be on the safe side and get the virus.' " 
Tests of samples from Guangdong at the C.D.C. and a Japanese laboratory turned up routine flu strains, Dr. Stohr said, so they were discarded.
"If the conference had been in December, and there had been 100 deaths -- I don't know," he said, "but things might have been different."
As early as January, hospitals in small cities in Guangdong were telling the provincial health department about clusters of atypical pneumonia. Herbal medicine shops were besieged and the price of white vinegar shot up 12-fold because it was believed that boiling it into vapor would disinfect a house.
Whether or not reports of those cases were sent on to Beijing, they were not being disclosed to the W.H.O.
In December and January, "it was dead silence from China," said Dr. Guenael Rodier, the W.H.O.'s chief of communicable disease surveillance.
That, epidemiologists said, was not surprising.
"Numbers on health outbreaks are the most politicized numbers in the world," said Dr. Stephen O. Cunnion, a retired outbreak specialist from the Navy who posted the Feb. 10 warning on ProMED after hearing from friends in China. "From China, you can't even get an accurate count of how many people have been killed in an earthquake." 
On Feb. 5, Dr. Stohr said, panic grew when the Chinese subsidiary of the drug company Roche took out ads saying that its drug Tamiflu worked against bird flu.
"That put in the minds of people that a bird flu epidemic had started," he said. The company later apologized.
No laboratory had by then found bird flu in humans, but southern China was primed to fear it. An outbreak there in 1997 infected only 18 people but killed 6 of them. The outbreak was stopped by the slaughter of 1.4 million birds.
Moreover, Dr. Stohr said, in December, an unusually powerful strain killed many wild birds in the Hong Kong Botanic Gardens.
Mutating bird flus are an epidemiologist's nightmare. Though most strains that infect humans -- usually poultry farmers -- cause nothing worse than conjunctivitis, the 1997 strain, which the 18 victims all caught from birds, had the same mortality rate as smallpox.
A fatal strain that could be passed from human to human "is the sword of Damocles hanging above all of us," said Dr. Rodier. "The good news about SARS is that it's not a pandemic flu."
On Feb. 11, in response to an official W.H.O. inquiry, Beijing tersely replied that an unidentified pneumonia in Guangdong had hospitalized 300 people and killed 5.
Guangdong's Communist Party secretary announced to the news media that "the illness has been effectively treated and controlled."
But at the same time, provincial health officials publicly urged anyone with fever or cough to seek immediate medical help and suggested that residents fumigate rooms with a vinegar-based steam wash, wear gauze masks, and stay away from shopping centers and train stations.
The next day, said a W.H.O. official, a flu lab in Hong Kong affiliated with the agency was asked to get some samples clandestinely.
Developing a vaccine takes about eight months, so if a dangerous new flu was likely to hit the world by the next winter, time was already short.
The lab's doctors "had friends and relatives working in hospitals in China, so they took the bus or train over and got samples from patients who died," the official said.
But because they were looking for bird flu, they found nothing. 
On Feb. 14, Li Liming, director of the Chinese Center for Disease Control, said that there had been no new cases since Feb. 10 and that the situation was "under control and not as serious as the rumors say." 
On Feb. 18, the Chinese disease center announced that chlamydia bacteria had been found in two patients' lungs, and that it must have caused the outbreak.
"We didn't believe it," Dr. Ostroff of the C.D.C. in Atlanta said. Antibiotics also cure chlamydia.

A Worrisome Turn
On Feb. 19, the plot took a twist. A Hong Kong laboratory reported on a 33-year-old man and his 9-year-old son who had hurried to Fujian Province to see the man's dying 8-year-old daughter. The father died on his return on Feb. 17; the son was sick. Both had the H5N1 strain of avian influenza.
Dr. Stohr said a Hong Kong colleague asked him, "Are you sitting down?" before giving him the news. This might be the nightmare bird flu -- a fatal strain that had passed from human to human.
Ultimately, however, that one-family outbreak seems to have spontaneously died out. The cause of the daughter's death remains unknown.
Officials outside of China, now very worried, tried another route. Dr. Keiji Fukuda of the C.D.C. and Dr. Hitoshi Oshitani of the World Health Organization were dispatched to Beijing and told to get to southern China.
Prompted by the C.D.C., Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, pressed China's deputy health minister, then visiting Washington, for permission for the team to visit.
Permission was granted, and they arrived Feb. 23. "But it was the Asian cultural thing of not wanting to say no," said Dr. James W. LeDuc, director of the C.D.C.'s division of viral and rickettsial diseases. "Keiji got to Beijing and found out he didn't have an invitation."
The two men were left sitting in their hotel rooms for two weeks with nothing but routine briefings. In early March, they left in frustration.
Investigating outbreaks is always politically touchy. As a United Nations agency, it has no power to order member states to cooperate.
"If I wasn't happy with the U.S. investigation of SARS cases in Pennsylvania, would I have the right to pop up in Philadelphia?" asked Dr. Michael J. Ryan, coordinator of the W.H.O.'s global alert system.
Because the W.H.O. does not have enough money to field its own teams, it must send volunteers. The C.D.C. in Atlanta is the biggest contributor but, W.H.O. officials said, some countries are about as eager to see American health inspectors as Iraq was to see American arms inspectors.

Facing the Facts
With China uncooperative, momentum stalled. Then on Feb. 21, the disease escaped China when a 64-year-old Guangdong doctor checked into the Metropole in Hong Kong and infected guests who would spread it to Toronto, Hanoi, Singapore and elsewhere in Hong Kong.
The true nature of the disease -- that it was not a flu, but a pneumonia indifferent to antibiotics and antivirals -- was not understood until March 11, when two factors merged.
Dr. Carlo Urbani, a W.H.O. clinician, chillingly detailed the outbreak he was fighting in Hanoi. Johnny Chen, an American businessman who had been in the Metropole, had infected 22 hospital workers and 7 at his garment business in Hanoi. Dr. Urbani would soon die of the disease.
Tissue samples, flown to Bangkok on a plane chartered by the United States Embassy because local airlines refused to carry them, showed no flu. Meanwhile, workers in a Hong Kong hospital were falling sick. An airport worker who had also been in the Metropole had been put on a jet nebulizer to clear his lungs and had infected 112 others. A Hong Kong laboratory found no flu in them.
On March 12, the W.H.O. issued a global health alert as a routine news release. With war in Iraq looming, it got relatively little attention. Three more events prompted its much more emphatic March 15 alert.
The Canadian authorities reading the first announcement recognized that the pneumonias in one Toronto family fit the pattern. The authorities in Singapore said a hospitalized flight attendant who had stayed at the Metropole also did.
And then, at 2:30 a.m. on March 15, Dr. Ryan was awakened by Singaporean officials warning him that a doctor who had treated pneumonia patients there had just left a conference in New York, told relatives he was feeling sick, and boarded a plane home with a stopover in Europe.
Dr. Ryan spent the next four hours hunting down the plane and getting the doctor safely isolated in Frankfurt. That incident galvanized W.H.O. officials into issuing a much more urgent and detailed alert.
They also picked a name.
"We have to brand this," said Dr. David L. Heymann, the W.H.O.'s chief of infectious diseases. After tries like Atypical Pneumonia Without Diagnosis, they settled on a pronounceable acronym. 
Asked if he thought an earlier alert could have saved any lives, Denis G. Aitken, an aide to the W.H.O.'s director general, the senior official on hand that day, said he doubted it, noting that the four new outbreaks were well under way by early March.
"If you lose sleep over that, you'll become petrified," Mr. Aitken said. "You just have to face the facts."

Rise of a Virus
Previous articles in this series examined the economic impact of SARS and the early spread of the epidemic. A later article will chronicle the search for the virus that causes it. The articles remain online at nytimes.com/sars.

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday with a front-page article about the World Health Organization's response to the SARS epidemic misidentified the official shown with Dr. David L. Heymann, the organization's executive director for communicable diseases. He was Dr. Klaus Stohr, scientific director of its SARS investigation, not Dr. Michael J. Ryan.
The article also misidentified the organization that runs ProMED, the Program for Monitoring Emerging Diseases, which posted an alert on its Web site on Feb. 10 about what later proved to be a SARS outbreak in Guangzhou, China. The parent group is the International Society for Infectious Diseases. (The Federation of American Scientists established the program but turned it over to the international group in 1999.)

HEADLINE: COMMUTER'S JOURNAL; 
The Price We Pay for Heading South Each Morning

BYLINE:  By JACK KADDEN; Jack Kadden is an editor at The Times. His e-mailaddress is kadden@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LET'S pause to savor a golden moment that will pass all too quickly.
 As of this month, New York State rail commuters are paying more, on a per-mile basis, than Connecticut commuters -- 7 percent more, to be precise. 
 That's because they were hit with a 25 percent fare increase on May 1. Previously, we were paying 18.3 percent more than they were, according to Connecticut Department of Transportation figures. 
But, the planets will soon move back into alignment and we will recapture the honor of bearing the largest burden of any commuters in the nation.
As early as July 1, Connecticut plans to raise fares for travel to New York by an average of 15 percent. For a commuter from Westport, that means a monthly ticket will rise to $292, from $254. When the increase takes effect, we'll be paying 8 percent more than New Yorkers.
The reason for this disparity is simple: Connecticut makes commuters pay a far larger share of the cost of running the railroad than New York, or any other state -- roughly 74 percent, compared with 58 percent for New York City subway and bus riders and 51 percent for Long Island Rail Road riders.
To some people, that's not such a bad thing. After all, why should an insurance executive in Hartford or a real estate agent in Norwich have to subsidize my railroad ticket?
Moreover, some argue, most commuters from Fairfield County are making big salaries and won't miss an extra $38 a month. That's less than the cost of an oil change for a Lexus.
But there's another way to look at it.
Fairfield County is an important economic engine for the state's economy, and its future depends on easing the highway crisis that makes driving to work on Interstate 95 or the Merritt Parkway such an exercise in frustration.
Arguably, I-95 is one of the worst roads in the nation, and its crowded, dangerous conditions have become a disincentive for businesses that are considering moving into the state. There is no easy solution to the traffic problem, but getting more people to use Metro-North couldn't hurt.
That's why Prof. Fred Carstensen, an economist at the University of Connecticut, thinks the fare increase is such a bad idea.
"It's an outrage, because it's bad policy," he said. "You have a congestion problem in Fairfield County, and this will add to it."
He's convinced the fare increase will send more people to their cars, increasing traffic and air pollution. And he's not alone.
State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Greenwich Republican and a member of the legislature's Transportation Committee, said a recent report by the Transportation Strategy Board concluded that the only way to ease traffic is to increase rail ridership. "The fare increase operates counter to that," he said.
Harry P. Harris, chief of the Bureau of Public Transportation for the state's transportation department, said he doesn't think many commuters will switch. "There is no question there will be a momentary drop in ridership," he said. "There always has been." But he added. "It always bounces back in a month or two, because the cost of driving to New York City is so horrendous."
Maybe and maybe not.
At a hearing last month on the fare increase, Terry Shea of Fairfield, said, "I commute to New York with my wife, and at a combined cost of almost $600 a month, it will be a whole lot cheaper to drive."
He said a lot of people on the train were talking about forming carpools.
Mr. Harris said most in-state fares won't be going up, so local commuters won't have a reason to give up the train. But he conceded that they represent only 6 percent of riders in Connecticut. He also said the state has not done any market studies. And that is Professor Carstensen's biggest complaint.
He said the state should conduct a full-blown study of the economic and environmental impact of higher fares. "We ought to stop flying blind. We ought to figure out what the rates of return are."
He estimated that a 15 percent fare increase would only bring in 11 percent more revenue because of people who choose to drive. Moreover, he said, a comprehensive study would only cost about $50,000, which he called "chump change." He's right; it's less than one half of 1 percent of the $12 million the fare increase is expected to raise annually.
Ultimately, Professor Carstensen admitted that the state has little choice but to raise fares, given the $1 billion budget deficit it faces.
But Senator Nickerson argued, "If we don't start addressing the region's transportation needs now, when will we start?"

HEADLINE: Going in (Nostalgic) Circles 

BYLINE:  By ABIGAIL SULLIVAN MOORE 

 BODY:
FOR only 50 cents, you can step into the past by taking a ride on the historic carousel in Bushnell Park in downtown Hartford.
 Sheltered by a pavilion with stained-glass windows, the antique wooden carousel sits near the bottom of a gentle slope, above a new toddler playscape and a shallow reflecting pool adorned by modern sculpture. 
 The carousel was purchased by the Knox Foundation in 1976 for $55,000 from an Ohio amusement park to help revitalize downtown Hartford, said Louise DeMars, executive director of the New England Carousel Museum, which manages the carousel for Hartford. 
The 89-year-old carousel has been supported by the city and with donations from corporations and private individuals. Support has also come from the nearly 600-strong Friends of the Bushnell Park Carousel, whose dues range from $10 for a Cherub membership (for children) to $5,000. 
Most recently, the carousel's floor was refurbished. Ms. DeMars is now seeking money to restore the housing that encircles the carousel's top like a faded gold crown. She hopes to raise $27,000 through local foundations, corporations, carousel members and the National Carousel Association.
Ms. DeMars has raised $1,000 so far, and there is talk of having a big party at the carousel in the fall to come up with more money.
Restoration needs aside, the carousel generates 500 rides on weekdays when school is out and up to 1,000 rides on weekends, said Mark T. Krell, the carousel's assistant manager.
"It brings out the children in everyone," he said.
The carousel will run from May through late October.
Each year, Hartford school children receive free tickets, Ms. DeMars said. Area schools also come for "spin and learn," a one-hour session that combines a trip to the carousel with a visit to the state Capitol.
"Last year, we had someone who was 96 years old," Mr. Krell said. "She wanted to ride a horse that went up and down."
Of the carousel's 48 horses, 36 are "jumpers," which move up and down; the rest are stationary. There are also two chariots that, Ms. DeMars said, accommodated the wide skirts worn in the early part of the century.
"Back then, the carousel was considered a thrill ride," she said. 
Everything in the Bushnell Park Carousel is carved in the ornate Coney Island style, a carousel design characterized by big gold buckles and shiny fish-scale armor on the horses.
"I like the glitz," Ms. DeMars said.
The three-tiered carousel also brings out the romance in people. 
Two West Hartford residents, Ian Smith, 36, and Sandy Collins, 35, are planning to exchange their wedding vows, standing on the carousel during an evening ceremony May 24 before 175 guests. 
"I used to go there as a kid," Mr. Smith said. "I loved it."
For Ms. Collins, the carousel evoked memories of visits to other carousels with her father, who died when she was 17. Holding the wedding at the carousel is a way to remember him, she said. 
After the vows are exchanged, the guests will be invited to take a spin.
"The carousel seemed like a magical place to begin our journey as a married couple," Mr. Smith said.

HEADLINE: Hartford Y to Close Rooms 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
IT'S a small room with bad lighting and scuffed furniture. On a recent Saturday morning, as a cold rain splattered the window and corridor signs announced Alcoholics Anonymous meetings and candy machine hours, the shabbiness of the place was palpable. But for Angel Sanchez, who just got out of jail, a room at the Hartford Y.M.C.A. is a sanctuary he can afford. Hearing the place is scheduled to close left him with a worry as raw as the weather.
 "'I heard about that and I don't know what I'm going to do," he said. "'The only other place for me is the shelter." 
 Choice doesn't figure much into the lives of the 120 or so people who live here, a short stroll from the gold-domed Capitol. They are accustomed to having little. They stay here, they said, because it is clean, safe and on a bus line, but mostly because it's cheap: $25 a night; $20, for a shared bath. Some, like Mr. Sanchez, arrived fresh out of prison with nothing more than a few dollars and a change of clothes. Others are exiled from home for one too many battles with alcohol, drugs or mental health.
Whatever brought them here, the question of where they will go when the Y.M.C.A. shuts down its residence remains in limbo. Last month, the board of directors announced it wanted to focus resources on programs and jettison the residential units above its athletic facilities and administrative offices. The board wants to spend $10 million to build or rent space for two neighborhood centers in the north and south end of Hartford.
The Y.M.C.A. also plans to spend about $13 million on new gyms, locker rooms and racquetball courts; the existing athletic facilities were built in 1938. The projects are contingent upon a feasibility study and raising the money. Daniel Tracy, a Y.M.C.A. board member,said he expected the process to take two to three years, but said the organization was committed to closing the single-room residences.
"This is the painful part of all of this," Mr. Tracy said, of displacing the men and women who live at the Y.M.C.A. 
When the 128-room residential tower was completed in 1972, it was the last residential facility built in the United States by a Y.M.C.A., said Kevin Washington, president of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater Hartford. A major source of funding for the complex was supplied by the local insurance industry to create temporary housing for corporate recruits.
"You can see we don't have the corporate types anymore and haven't in a long time," he said. "Housing was on its way out then."
But other similar facilities in the state, including Y.M.C.A.'s, are maintaining and even strengthening their residential components. Hartford's Y plans to renovate and expand to convert its 85 single rooms into 71 efficiency apartments to provide transitional housing for low-income women, said its housing director, Carol Dunn. Two Y.M.C.A. residential complexes in Bridgeport and New Haven are flourishing, said Philip Dwyer, director of the Central Coast Y.M.C.A. that serves those areas. 
In Hartford, the Y wants to strengthen its athletic facilities (although its pool is scheduled to close) and get back into the neighborhoods to reach some 4,000 children, Mr. Tracy said. The Y.M.C.A. residents require a range of services the organization cannot provide, such as drug and employment counseling. Indeed, other than the A.A. meetings, the only fliers in the rack outside the elevator are for rental apartments and Chinese takeout.
In Hartford there are plans for the construction of 1,200 new residential units within the next two years that are expected to attract middle and upper income people. Harry Freeman, the city's director of economic development, said the apartments or condos, including sites like the $500 million Adriaen's Landing hotel and conference center, will be market or luxury rate. Market rate rentals begin at $1,000 a month. Asked about affordable housing downtown, Mr. Freeman could only point to the market rate units.
"'If you add up the cost of a month's stay at the Y, it's $600," he said. "There are a lot of apartments in Hartford for $600." Mr. Freeman also pointed out the city's home ownership program, a program once directed by Mayor Eddie Perez in his days as a neighborhood organizer. Under the plan, low-income Hartford residents can buy houses at below market rates and with little down payment.
Yet Y.M.C.A. staff said only 18 of the residents were long-term, staying for more than two months. The rest are looking for a way station. Mary McAtee, executive director of the Connecticut Coalition to End Homelessness, said many people used the Y.M.C.A. as a respite from the city's eight shelters or a relative's sofa.
"They're going to end up in the shelters and the shelters are already overflowing," Ms. McAtee said. Others are trying to establish a foothold on the future. A man who dashed out the front door Saturday morning was headed to work.
"I've got to catch a bus," he said. "I'm working construction. Twenty-five bucks an hour."
The man said he waited in front of a drugstore for contractors to offer work; Mr. Sanchez found work with a landscaper the same way.
George Real, 41, has regular work. He's the assistant superviser of the laundry room at St. Francis Hospital. What the Y provides him with is an affordable safety net between arguments at home. He said the most inexpensive hotels run about $200 a week and aren't always near public transportation.
On a recent morning, he leaned on his muscled, tattooed forearm as he watched television from his bed. He was killing time before leaving to pick up his children for the day.
"No one bothers you here," he said. "It's not expensive. Sure you have to put up with people, kids coming in and out of the lobby for the gym, but there's a canteen downstairs that sells hot dogs and deli food." 
Mr. Real parted the curtain to display a panoramic view of the park, the Capitol and the handsome Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch bedecked with seraphim.
"See that?" he said with child-like wonder. "I'm up here with the angels."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Hartford Y.M.C.A., top, is planning to shut down it residential complex, which would displace the people who stay in its rooms, above. George Real, left, said no one bothers him at the Y and it is inexpensive. Angel Sanchez, below, said his only choice may be to stay at shelters. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: S.O.S. From the Stacks 

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN 

 BODY:
THIS is a tale of two cities in the one called New Rochelle.
 In the last year tension between the two New Rochelles has mounted. Dueling Web sites have sprung up. Campaign funds compete. Dueling leaflets are handed out. Countless meetings have been called. 
 The conflict is over the financing and fate of the city's library, a community institution that is rarely the target of such intense cross-fire. 
Because of a confluence of events and decisions by the New York State Education Department, the New Rochelle City Council and the New Rochelle Public Library Board of Trustees, residents of New Rochelle may lose their main library, as well as the Huguenot Children's Library, if they do not vote to approve a new tax to support a $2.96 million budget on June 3. In the past, the library was paid for out of the New Rochelle city budget. But the city is suffering budget woes, and the City Council voted to remove library financing from its charter early this year after learning of the state law requiring that city residents must vote on library budgets. As a result, the library's city-based financing runs out on June 30. The new tax has already been voted down twice; the June 3 vote will be the last. 
The possibility that New Rochelle's library -- the second busiest in Westchester and among the oldest -- may have to shut down has become a lightning rod for mounting frustration and anger over New Rochelle's budget problems. It has also polarized this second-largest city in Westchester along political, social and economic lines, dividing even lifelong residents and former classmates. 
At a time when New York State is threatening substantial cutbacks in cultural and community subsidies, and Westchester County has already reduced its contribution to local libraries, New Rochelle's situation may be a preview of cutbacks in store for other communities.
"The financial problems in Albany are terrific, and what's at risk are precious services," said Maurice J. Freedman, director of the Westchester Library System, who spoke at a recent information session about the New Rochelle situation sponsored by the League of Women Voters of New Rochelle. The meeting was attended primarily by a consortium of library advocates who have hired a media planning company for a public education campaign and have established their own Web site (www.saveourlibrary.org).
"We're not talking about just budget cuts, we're talking about the survival of the library," said Pat Anderson, director of the New Rochelle Public Library. The library, although the highest net lender in the county, ranks 30th out of 38th in per capita spending, she said. 
The bitter disagreement over who should be underwritingNew Rochelle's library is, in part, a result of a law passed in 1996 by the New York State Legislature concerning the management of small city school district libraries. The law stipulates that those libraries be financed with a tax separate from the city budget, as the schools themselves are. Those taxes are voted upon directly by residents. 
No one in Albany, or in New Rochelle, noticed that the New Rochelle library was chartered this way until 2001, when James L. Farrell Jr., a library development specialist with the New York State Education Department in Albany, visited library trustees, at their request, to discuss additional sources of money. 
"I went down and explained to them that they should be voting on the budget, and they were in shock," Mr. Farrell recalled. 
The library trustees, all seven of whom were appointed by the school board, put a $3.4 million budget to a vote last year on June 12 with little publicity and only one polling place for 37,000 registered voters. It was defeated, 2,208 to 1,518. They tried again on July 9, this time with 12 polling places, but the proposal was again turned down, with a much closer vote of 3,948 to 3,770.
The third and final vote will be on a pared-down budget of $2.96 million, as well as for two seats on the library board, which will eventually be fully elected, according to Thomas Leghorn, vice president of the library's board.
If the library budget passes, it will increase New Rochelle city taxes by about 1.7 percent, or an average of $174 a year, according to the city's finance commissioner, Howard Rattner. 
If the budget proposal fails, however, there will be no more city money for the library, according to Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle, a Democrat. "If the vote doesn't pass, the library will close on June 30," he said. The city is having problems raising tax revenues because of the declining economy, he said, "and because we're the only city in New York State operating under a tax cap." 
New Rochelle's tax cap was put into effect in 1993, and prohibits city taxes from being raised more than the consumer price index. The cap was imposed in exchange for a 1 percent increase in sales tax, which brings in about $9 million a year, according to Charles B. Strome, the city manager. 
"I don't see a way that the city can maintain all public safety and public works services and continue to fund the library," Mr. Strome said, noting that the city's collection of fall leaves was completed only last month because of a shortage of maintenance workers.
Opponents of the library vote, a group formed by members of the Republican, Independence and Conservative Parties, call themselves The New Rochelle Public Library Coalition. They are sending information to residents by direct mail, e-mail and telephone, and have their own Web site (www.nrpl.info), according to Douglas A. Colety, chairman of the New Rochelle Republican Party. He said that voters have already spoken, twice, voting down the separate tax, and thus the city should continue to finance the library. Further, he said, whether there is a separate tax or not, the library's board should become fully elected immediately, or else the city will have taxation without representation. 
"The mayor is trying to use scare tactics by threatening to close the library," said Mr. Colety, who led a coalition boycott of the recent League of Women Voters' meeting because his group was not permitted to present an opposing viewpoint. 
"This is an attempt to circumvent the tax cap, and the city administration is behind the attempt to sneak this tax through," Mr. Colety added.
Mr. Idoni, for his part, dismisses that criticism. "There has been some political opportunism by my opponents, who see city finances as a weakness in this election year," he said. The mayoral and city council elections will be held in November; Mr. Idoni is expected to run again. 
The politicization of the library issue has greatly distressed library supporters, including Gayle Golomb, president of the League of Women Voters of New Rochelle and a native of the city.
"This is not political, it's a quality-of-life issue," she said. "We are already on an austerity budget in New Rochelle." 
Michael E. Boyle Jr. is one of two Republicans on the City Council who believes that the city should continue to finance the city's library.
"I wanted to keep the library in the city budget," Mr. Boyle said. He favors a phase-in agreement, whereby taxpayers could contribute increasing levels to the library, with the rest coming from New Rochelle, Westchester County and New York State.
Ms. Golomb, a former classmate and longtime friend of Mr. Boyle's, said she thinks he is fooling himself about the availability of extra money. "Money will not appear from the sky," she said. "There are no magic solutions after the vote." 
ON a chilly spring Saturday afternoon, though, there is little evidence of either warring factions or impending doom in the airy, light-filled $10 million library. The building, set in the heart of the city, is noisily abuzz with purposeful activity: a teenager, sucking a ring-pop, works at a table; an itchy toddler fidgets at a glass-encased computer terminal; a mother does research on her son's autism; five white-haired ladies wait at a table in the cafe for an afternoon concert. 
Some patrons were unaware of the potential threat to the library's fate and horrified to learn of it.
"That's ridiculous, I'm outraged," said Vencillia Williams, 30, an account manager who has lived in New Rochelle for three years.
Anthony Jones, a 9-year-old with neat cornrows, who knew about the library's problems because his grandmother works there, said: "I think it's unfair, because it's a good, good education for kids here. I don't have a computer at home, but I come here and type." 
Some library users said they thought someone would appear at the last minute to save the day, a modern-day municipal Mighty Mouse."I have a good feeling that it won't happen, the library cannot be closed, it will never be closed," said A.C. James, 41, an immigrant from India and New Rochelle resident who was visiting the library with his two children. "Politicians can always find money," he added, optimistically.
But officials say there is no money for the library, from the city or anywhere else.
"I'd like Bill Gates or Santa Claus to come through the doors with a big sack of money, but that's not going to happen," said Mr. Leghorn, the library trustee.
Mr. Strome, the city manager, agreed. "Quite frankly, despite what people are saying," he said, "there is no more money if the vote fails." 
New York State library regulations compound the library's financial problems. A library in a city the size of New Rochelle must be open at least 55 hours a week, which means that the library can't economize by reducing hours. In addition, if the library cannot prove that it has a continuous and stable source of financing, from the city, a separate tax or elsewhere, the Board of Regents could revoke the library's charter and it would have to close. In that event, New Rochelle residents will not be able to borrow materials from neighboring libraries as they can now, or any other libraries in the Westchester Library System, which have already applied to refuse borrowing privileges for New Rochelle residents, Mr. Farrell said.
"If you decided you didn't want to pay your mortgage, would your neighbors pay for you?" asked Mr. Farrell. "I know it's harsh, but it's the reality of the situation." 
Finally, there is ultimate anathema: a city without a library is a city with declining property values.
"I've received a number of phone calls from people with children who say that if the vote doesn't come out 'yes' they are putting their house on the market," said Frances Eisner, a real estate agent for 40 years with Oshlag-Eisner Realty Corporation in New Rochelle. 
New Rochelle library trustees, employees and supporters are crossing their fingers.
"Can we afford a library?" asked Peter Rothberg, library board president. "The real question is: Can we afford not to have a library in New Rochelle?" 

Overdue Book Fines Don't Pay the Bills
THE New Rochelle Public Library is not the only library in Westchester that is beset with money problems. 
"Since the dot-com bubble burst, library use has gone up continuously," said Maurice J. Freedman, director of the Westchester Library System. "If we were a corporation showing this kind of productivity and growth, there would be enormous bonuses and more people being hired. But instead, our budgets are being cut."
Village trustees asked Susan Riley, director of the Mount Kisco Public Library, to cut her budget by 8 percent this year. The roof on the building is collapsing and athe heating system is so inadequate that the library had to close several times this winter for lack of heat. Ms. Riley told the trustees that if the cuts were made, she would have to lay off employees and cut back on the library's hours, now open 63 hours a week.
In April, the trustees relented and restored full financing to the library. Plans for a much-needed new building, however, are still up in the air after eight years.
The Briarcliff Manor Public Library may be shut by New York State because it does not meet the minimum New York State standards for a community of 8,000. The place has just eight chairs, a closet-sized children's room, no meeting room and no access for the handicapped. The library's director, Geraldine Mahoney, said the library has been granted a waiver from New York State for the last five years to defer the requirements, but now faces losing its charter unless it builds a 9,000-square-foot addition, at a cost of $3.8 million. Some of the money for that project is tied to development plans for a private retirement center, which has pledged $2.75 million toward a new library. The village board will make a decision on the retirement center early this summer, Ms. Mahoney said.
Ossining, which has a school district library similar to New Rochelle's, hasn't turned down a library budget vote in more than a decade, said its director, Edward Falcone. Early this fall, however, residents are expected to vote a $15.8 million referendum to replace the old library with a new building on an adjoining lot. The five-member board, all of whom are appointed by the school district, has said this will raise taxes about $106 a year, according to Mr. Falcone. 
Mr. Falcone said he plans to "get the facts out there and hope for the best." CARIN RUBENSTEIN

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Coming to America, Au Pairs Aren't Daunted

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
BRIGITTE EMILIA CROCOS had been a little concerned. Before she arrived in the United States last week to embark on her adventure as an au pair, Ms. Crocos, a 22-year-old German college student, called her host family in Bridgewater, N.J., to find out whether Germans are still welcome in the United States. She had also look up information about SARS on the Web site of the World Health Organization.
 "My house mom said Germans are still treated well here," said Ms. Crocos, who is in the United States for the first time. " And SARS? "There are not so many cases in America, and nobody has died from it," she said. 
 Despite the war in Iraq, which strained the United States' relation with many parts of the world, the economic woes and the galloping fear of SARS, au pairs from around the globe are still steadily arriving in the New York metropolitan area to experience a new culture. 
The au pair program at InterExchange, a Manhattan-based organization sponsoring international exchange programs including summer trips and camps, said that although their applications from au pairs dipped by 10 percent during the war, it has already picked up again. The organization receives more than 1,000 applications for au pair positions a year.
"We saw some hesitation," said Paul Christianson, the director of InterExchange. "It was more of wait and see. But we are now seeing a surge in au pair applications."
Applications from families requesting au pairs have remained constant, he said, explaining that the sagging economy can both deflate and inflate the demand for au pairs. Since the beginning of the year, InterExchange has received roughly 500 applications from families, a normal year, Mr. Christianson said.
It is true that some parents have become unemployed and thus no longer need au pairs to take care of their children, Mr. Christianson said, but some mothers have returned to the work force to maintain family income and now need live-in child care. Moreover, hiring an au pair is significantly less expensive than employing a full-time nanny, making sponsoring an au pair an attractive choice in hard economic times.
While having a full-time nanny can cost up to $500 a week, a host family pays an au pair $140 a week -- an amount set by the State Department, which regulates the au pair industry -- and a onetime fee of roughly $5,000 to cover the au pair's transportation to and from her home country, health insurance and orientation in the United States.
Other major players in the au pair business in the New York metropolitan area, like the Boston-based Cultural Care and Stamford-based Au Pair in America, also said they have seen little fluctuation in the volume of their applications this spring.
"For the most part, our au pairs know that the war is quite separate from their experience here," said Samantha Janney, a spokeswoman for Cultural Care, which receives about 4,200 au pair applications a year. "We haven't seen any unhappy au pair who wants to go home early."
Dabeth Faure, a 21-year-old French au pair living in Briarcliff Manor, was aware that French fries had become freedom fries and French toast freedom toast at some places in the nation. But for her, the war felt perceptible only when neighbors, half teasing, half serious, gave her well-meaning advice.
"People say: 'Don't say you are from France. Say you are from Italy,"' she recalled, chuckling. "I was, like, 'Sure, I'll say I am from Italy.' Nobody has asked me my opinions."
Ms. Faure said she supported the position her country took, but describing herself as rather apolitical, said she hasn't discussed the war with anyone, including her host family.
Florence Helin, another French au pair, has. "I agree with Chirac," said Ms. Helin, who lives with a family at Oyster Bay in Nassau, referring to President Jacques Chirac of France, "and my host family agrees with Chirac. The war felt far away."
But Ms. Crocos, the newly arrived German au pair, is not among those opposed to the war in Iraq. "Saddam had been a dictator for 20 years, and you simply had to do something," she said. "In the Second World War, if the Americans didn't do something, maybe Hitler would still be around."
When she called her host family to find out whether there is any backlash against French and Germans, Debbie Kulak, her host, gave the question serious thought.
"When I talk to people, I find there are some people who really don't like the French right now," she said. "I would have some question about whether a French au pair would feel entirely comfortable here. But Germany? No. It doesn't come up at all.
"I am not real pleased with what the French did," she added. "But I would not not like a French au pair because of that. Absolutely not. We are not prejudiced people."
For her part, Ms. Crocos, blonde with an easy smile, is making an effort not to hold any prejudice against Americans. She has brought with her a printout about erroneous stereotypes about Americans she found on the Internet. What's on the list?
"Americans are snobbish, superficial and wealthy."
Ms. Crocos chuckled, and upon discovering that she is a loyal fan of "Sex and City," the popular series on HBO, the coordinators from InterExchange warned her that not all Manhattan women have many boyfriends at the same time.
But on the warm spring day when Ms. Crocos arrived among two dozen au pairs -- most from Europe and a few from South America -- at the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan where they stayed for the first night, the war and SARS were not what was on their minds. Instead, it was which channel shows "Felicity," another popular television show, and whether any of the protagonists in "Sex and City" eventually gets married.
It was only when a reporter asked the group whether they were scared of SARS that the au pairs seemed to remember the contagious disease commandeering the news media around the globe.
"I am not afraid," Anne-Claire Roset, a French girl who will become an au pair with a family in Cheshire, Conn., said in hesitant English. "I have confidence in life."
Then, slowly but earnestly, she added, "I am a fatalist, so I am not afraid."
Most of her companions seemed to share her confidence, and Mr. Christianson, who has met thousands of au pairs, commented: "We deal with 20-, 21-year olds. When you are 21, you think you are indestructible."

Joanne Malkin conducts an orientation for au pairs at the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fund-Raisers Face A Drop in Dollars 

BYLINE:  BY CAROLINE B. SMITH

 BODY:
IN Nassau and Suffolk counties, local merchants, major corporations and not-for-profit agencies are searching for new ways to make charitable dollars go as far as possible. That's particularly important when there are fewer of those dollars to go around. 
 Maryann Slutsky, director of financial development for the Nassau County chapter of the American Red Cross, said donations were down 50 percent in the last 18 months, adding that while individual donations remain steady, corporations are cutting back. 
 "You have to be much more creative and tenacious in soliciting the donor," she said. "Especially on Long Island, because we have so many not-for-profits and a lot of the big corporations are no longer there, they're moving out. It's just become an incredible struggle." 
For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2001, the Nassau chapter raised $1.8 million. For the fiscal year ending in June 2002, it raised almost $1.7 million, not counting donations earmarked for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But in the current fiscal year, the fund-raising goal is only $1.1 million.
The decline is a reaction, she said, "to a very slowed economy, the war and the uncertainty in the world right now." 
She also said that the Red Cross had suffered what she called "negative branding" for a couple of months when people learned that money donated after Sept. 11 was not all going to victims of the terrorist attacks. 
In response to criticism of that decision, the Red Cross developed a program called Donor Direct, Ms. Slutsky said. It uses very specific language in fund-raising solicitations so donors know exactly where their gifts will go and the donor intent is reiterated in the Red Cross acknowledgment.
The Children's Medical Fund in New Hyde Park depends on fund-raising events for 85 percent or approximately $1.2 million of its annual revenue. The money is used to support Schneider Children's Hospital, part of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System. 
Talking about corporate donors, Valerie Schultz, the fund's managing director, said: "If they can only support a certain number of things, they will really look at the projects and evaluate which of these projects has the most impact on the community. It's only because of a few committed people that we have been able to maintain our numbers." 
Symbol Technologies in Holtsville is one of the corporations on the other side of the giving equation. Patricia Sileo, a company spokeswoman, said there had been a significant increase in requests for charitable donations since Sept. 11. She suggested that it would be helpful for not-for-profits to band together in support of one goal or program, and then approach corporations. "We want to make sure that the money goes to a specific program, so we're looking much more closely at earmarking our dollars for specific programs," Ms. Sileo said.
The consortium concept was echoed by Lisa Platania, a spokeswoman for Computer Associates in Islandia, who said the company had not reduced its donations but was allocating its resources differently. "We're giving fewer gifts of a larger amount to have more of an impact," she said. Ms. Platania said Computer Associates is working with organizations that have teamed up to address the issue of gang violence in Central Islip. 
At Cablevision, Bill Powers, director of media relations, declined to discuss the company's charitable contributions, but noted that the company provides free advertising to about 50 community groups each year. "That's a $1 million-a-year commitment by Cablevision on Long Island," Mr. Powers said. 
Along the Main Streets of the Island, local merchants say they will continue to contribute to their local community for as long as the economy permits. Rachel DeMolfetto, a co-owner of the Racine Salon de Beaute and Spa in Islip, says she supports local schools and charities with journal ads, gift certificates and donations ranging in value from $25 to $200. "You want to be able to keep fund-raising and give because it is important in terms of needy causes, but in financial down times, people may not feel as generous or could be as generous as they would like to be," Ms. DeMolfetto said.
Mona Margolis, owner of Sag Harbor Florist, said she gave about $10,000 annually in floral arrangements to organizations that improve the quality of life locally. "I may be forced to cut back because business is quiet out here right now. I'm going to try to keep donating as much as I have before. As long as the numbers look good, I'm not going to cut back," said Mrs. Margolis. 
Owners of the Book Revue, a bookstore in Huntington, say that despite the current economy, they give to 80 percent to 90 percent of the organizations -- most of them from the local community -- that solicit. "We've always tried to give to the ones that are the most important, most needy or closest to our heart, and have had to say no to those who can come up with money elsewhere," said Richard Klein, the store's co-owner. "It's hard to give money to a group that we feel has access to sources of income when you have groups like the homeless people and veterans organizations to give to."

HEADLINE: Stuck in Last Place 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY

DATELINE: NORTH AMITYVILLE 

 BODY:
WHEN Irwin and Delores Quintyne decided to move from their cramped apartment in a Harlem housing project to the suburbs in 1961, like many other blacks from the city they found their way to North Amityville.
 At the time, they say, they did not realize they were moving to a community that was more than 75 percent black, a segregated place that would in many ways be different from the rest of Suffolk County. 
 "We didn't see it at the time, but it became clear pretty quick that we wound up here by design," Mr. Quintyne said. "We didn't get service like other parts of town. Like if it snowed, we'd be the last to get dug out." 
Once it dawned on them that North Amityville, an unincorporated hamlet in the Town of Babylon, was separate and not equal to primarily white communities in Suffolk County, the Quintynes became local activists who pushed for more attention to North Amityville's concerns.
In the last 40 years, they have seen North Amityville go from a solidly middle-class community to an impoverished high-crime area so plagued by drugs and violence that in the 1980's a television network ranked the hamlet's main intersection as one of the nation's top 10 drug markets. The last 15 years have seen a slow reversal of the economic and social blight. But throughout it all one thing has remained constant: North Amityville has stayed a minority community.
"It's never bothered me being in a segregated community," said Mr. Quintyne, 76. "I just came in, made myself at home and I got involved. But it's been a long struggle to make things better for my community."
North Amityville is one of 13 "basic minority communities" that have existed on Long Island since 1960, according to Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. His review of census data shows that the same communities that county planners initially referred to as "racial ghettoes" with high percentages of Negroes in 1960 continue to exist today.
Despite the various federal and local laws that have been passed since 1960 to fight racial discrimination in housing, the patterns of segregation that took hold on Long Island in the first half of the 20th century remain unchanged. In addition to North Amityville, the minority communities include Wyandanch, Central Islip, Gordon Heights, Flanders, Brentwood, North Bellport and North Bay Shore in Suffolk County, and Hempstead, Freeport, Roosevelt, New Cassel and Uniondale in Nassau County.
The persistence of these communities reinforces the findings of a study released last year that accorded Long Island the dubious distinction of being the most segregated suburb in the nation. And while that study showed that Long Island overall is not quite as segregated as it was in the 1980's, the 13 communities show that in one important way, the Island remains as segregated as it was more than 40 years ago.
"There's been virtually no movement towards becoming a more integrated society," Dr. Koppelman said. "There's always going to be a certain amount of voluntary segregation. You find it in all ethnic communities. But with African-Americans it's been pretty much the result of basic racism and what you have is an almost enforced apartheid."
Dr. Koppelman said that once a neighborhood has been established as a minority community, even federal laws intended to discourage segregation "can't do anything to un-establish it."
David Rusk, the Washington-based consultant on urban and suburban policy who found Long Island to be the country's most segregated suburb, agreed that it was not unusual to find minority communities staying unchanged over time. He analyzed Long Island's segregation patterns for Erase Racism, a group sponsored by the Long Island Community Foundation. "There are only a very few instances where you would find significant numbers of white people moving into black neighborhoods," he said, adding that it would tend to happen in areas of gentrification close to cities and in historic neighborhoods.
Because most of the housing in North Amityville and other black communities on Long Island dates to the 1940's and 1950's, he said, "their housing stock is too old to be competitive and too young to be quaint" and therefore unlikely to attract white residents in large numbers.
Suburban minority settlements across the country follow similar patterns, according to John R. Logan, director of the Lewis Mumford Center for Comparative Urban and Regional Research at the State University of New York at Albany. "They are created very much as a result of the exclusion from most suburbs," he said. "Then once they're established, future minority migration is concentrated there because the mere fact that they are the few places where minorities are welcome makes them a magnet."
Despite the fact that North Amityville and the 12 other minority communities have changed little in their racial makeup, the communities have not remained totally static since 1960. Most have grown significantly, mirroring the Island's development and population growth in the last 40 years.
North Amityville has doubled in population from 8,366 in 1960 to 16,572 in 2000. In 1960, North Amityville was a largely middle-class community that was 76 percent black, the largest minority population in the county. The median family income was about $5,100 a year, significantly higher than the average for Suffolk County, which was only $4,653.
In 2000, the community's population was 86 percent minority, with a growing Hispanic community accounting for about 13.5 percent of that. The median family income was one of the lowest in Suffolk County, $49,901, compared to $72,112 for the county overall. 
Mr. Quintyne said he had been drawn to North Amityville by the ads that ran in local Harlem newspapers in the 1950's and 1960's and by word of mouth from friends. He also remembers that other growing Long Island communities, Levittown in particular, made it clear that they didn't want blacks.
"I didn't like the idea that we weren't able to go where we wanted to, especially after I came out of the service," said Mr. Quintyne, who was a Navy seaman during World War II. "But after we got here and got acclimated, we were satisfied." And why not? North Amityville gave the Quintynes their own slice of suburbia, a place where they could leave their doors unlocked and not worry about their children playing in the streets.
But in less than 10 years, the community started to go into serious decline. In 1968, county planning officials declared North Amityville a high poverty area and the regional planning board issued a report that described it as a place with failing businesses and an abundance of "once-sound homes" that had "become dilapidated beyond rehabilitation."
The planning board developed a plan that would turn North Amityville into a model suburban community, complete with a commercial center and a mix of new single-family homes and apartment complexes. But the plan remained just that, a plan. "Nothing came of it," Mr. Quintyne said. "The town just wasn't interested in doing anything that would benefit our community."
Leonard Canton, chairman of the North Amityville Community Economic Council, attributed the 20 years of decline that started in the late 1960's to an exodus of middle-class blacks. "When people feel affluent, they leave for wherever affluence will take them," he said. "Our community failed to thrive because we failed to stay." By 1970, the median family income in North Amityville, at $9,759, had become one of the lowest in Suffolk County, where the median was $12,084.
"Black flight" from changing minority suburban communities is a common phenomenon, said Hugh A. Wilson, a political science professor at Adelphi University who studies race and politics. "As soon as poor blacks started moving into these communities, middle-class blacks started moving out and moving into quasi-integrated communities," he said, communities that are predominantly white but have areas that are primarily minority.
By the late 1960's, North Amityville's main commercial zone, at the intersection of Great Neck and Albany Roads, had become an open-air drug market known as The Corner. Drug dealers plied their wares openly to drive-up customers in cars with license plates from as far away as New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. The drug trade thrived there through the crack epidemic of the 1980's.
"Drugs turned that corner into a pit," Mrs. Quintyne said. "And we had so many people die from there. It seemed like every week we were burying somebody who had been killed because of drugs."
Drugs took the Quintynes' eldest son, Irwin Jr., who died in 1986 after years of drug addiction, which his parents say he first developed when he was a teenager growing up in North Amityville. During the 1970's, the Quintynes and other community activists would sometimes march at The Corner with picket signs in a desperate attempt to take back their streets. Mr. Quintyne also started a drug rehabilitation program in one of the buildings at The Corner.
"We were threatened from time to time," Mr. Quintyne said. "But I would just say, 'You stay on your side and we'll stay on ours."'
The Quintynes and other community leaders attribute the hamlet's continued decline to the Republican-dominated town and county governments of the time, saying they paid scant attention to North Amityville's needs because most residents voted Democratic. 
"We had literally no representation in town hall when I first got out here 38 years ago," said the Rev. Robert Burgess, pastor of Grace Community Church. Despite community opposition, it seemed that factories and industrial businesses were allowed to build in the middle of residential areas, he said. 
Maxine Postal, the County Legislature's presiding officer, is a Democrat from Amityville, and she agreed that it wasn't until Democrats took control of town hall and county government in 1988 that North Amityville started on its road to recovery. The dilapidated shopping strip at The Corner was demolished in 1989, parks were refurbished and a new senior center was built. "The Republicans sat on their hands for years and their attitude was it wasn't worth it to work for these people because they wouldn't get their votes anyway," she said.
But Republicans who were in power in the 1970's and early 1980's said their administrations did try to improve conditions in North Amityville.
"I don't believe for a minute there was a concerted effort to not help North Amityville," said Harry Withers, a former Babylon town board member and Republican town leader. "But segregation and the economic problems that come with it have to do with societal problems that are way beyond the abilities of local government to change."
John V.N. Klein, a Republican who wasSuffolk county executive in the 1970's, said Republican leaders used to write off black communities as Democratic strongholds but have worked hard in the last 20 years to woo their support. "But it takes a long time to convince people who have felt that they have been neglected by a political party to turn that around," he said.
Mr. Klein also said that North Amityville's plight "was not a phenomenon limited to areas that lie under Republican control. To the contrary, many urban areas where these same problems exist have always been under Democratic control."
Mr. Quintyne and other community leaders have argued for years that the only way to avoid neglect is to turn North Amityville into an incorporated village. "If we want to control what comes into our community, we have to take our destiny in our own hands," Mr. Quintyne said.
An early attempt at incorporation in the 1970's failed for lack of support, but a new North Amityville Incorporation Committee was created in 1998 and recently completed a feasibility study.
"Incorporation would significantly improve the economic status of the community," said Ivan Young, the committee's chairman. Commercial tax dollars that now go to the town would instead go to North Amityville, as would state and federal grants aimed at helping areas of poverty, he said. "But the important thing is we would finally have more of a say in our community," he said.
Mr. Rusk, the consultant for Erase Racism, said, however, that incorporation might not be the answer to North Amityville's problems. "Considerable national research has shown that the more fragmented local government is, the more it is related to higher degrees of economic and racial segregation," he said.
Mr. Quintyne said incorporation might easily keep North Amityville a segregated community. "But we may well still be a minority community 40 years from now even if we don't incorporate," he said. "I just want North Amityville to become a full-fledged community and it would be nice if it could be one of the communities that people want to move into again."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Through Ink and Brush, A Melding of Traditions

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO 

DATELINE: Newark 

 BODY:
CHINESE artists are riding a full, frothy wave of enthusiasm across the United States. Museums everywhere are mounting surveys of their work, while commercial galleries, more than ever, are clambering to offer them shows. One or two sly patrons have even begun to build collections of contemporary Chinese art.
 Although this would seem to bode well for Chinese artists born in this country, or those who have lived here for some time, this loose-knit group is still a smallish blimp on the curatorial radar. Few, if any, have been included in surveys of contemporary Chinese art, while only a handful have commercial gallery representation. 
 In this context, it is good to see the Newark Museum staging a modest but timely exhibition of Chinese artists living in New York and New Jersey. "A Brush With History: Contemporary Artists and Chinese Tradition" presents the work of Er Tai Gao, Yun-Fei Ji, Zhang Hongtu and Nina Kuo, four artists who see themselves as Chinese-Americans. The show is about the broader meaning of this hyphenated existence.
Many Chinese artists have been inspired by the technically advanced but stylistically moribund tradition of ink-and-brush painting. Mr. Ji is one of them, his paintings blending imagery of graceful landscapes with helicopter crashes and ghoulish creatures engaged in gun battles and other violent acts. It is an exciting, surreal, mix.
Mr. Ji, born in China, has lived in the United States since 1986. He is probably the most successful of the artists in this show, having received many grants and prizes. He was recently honored with a solo exhibition at the Pratt Institute Gallery in New York, from which the Museum of Modern Art bought two of his paintings. Or at least that is the rumor going around New York. 
No painting in the show is more dynamic than his "The Move in Ba Don" (2002), which tells the story of the construction of a dam in southern China. Although difficult to see, careful inspection of this delicate painting reveals, at top, a building falling down and some villagers fleeing, while down below floats a group of spirit-like figures, perhaps officials. The suggestion is that creation of the dam will destroy a village. It's an allegory of modernization in China.
Nearby, Mr. Gao's paintings blend ancient Chinese Buddhist cave paintings with his autobiographical poetry. Writing and painting are tightly bound together in these works, the elegant, energetic characters of his calligraphy complementing the shadowy and almost meditative landscape imagery. These works are about memory and loss.
But Mr. Gao is more of a writer than a painter. In 1957, he published a book, with the seemingly inoffensive title "On Beauty," for which he was sentenced to hard labor at a prison camp in the Gobi Desert in northwestern China. He survived, only to be imprisoned again during the Cultural Revolution and then prohibited from writing. He escaped to the United States in 1992, where he was granted political asylum.
Comparisons have been made between the arrival of large numbers of Chinese artists and writers in New York in the 1980's and 1990's, and the mass migration of the European avant-garde before World War II. There are similarities, although not all the Chinese that came here during this period were fleeing persecution. Like other migrants, they were also seeking economic opportunity and a better life.
Mr. Zhang, 60, was one of the first artists of his generation to move to the United States. Trained in calligraphy, ink painting and socialism at the Central Academy of Fine Arts in Beijing, Mr. Zhang appears content to make a peacock-like show of his considerable artistic talents, painting zany mixtures of traditional Chinese landscape painting and the work of European impressionist and post-impressionist masters.
Mr. Zhang's daring collisions of painting styles and subject matter have the explosive energy of a pyrotechnic display, and just as much color. "Shi Tao Van Gogh" (1998) fuses elements from the work of Chinese master Shi Tao with the luridly colored cypresses and iridescent landscape of Van Gogh's "The Starry Night." Encrusted with familiarity, yet strange, the image exudes a comfortless beauty. Therein lies its power. 
Ms. Kuo is the one artist in the exhibition born in the United States. It shows, for her paintings are all about coming to terms with a displaced cultural heritage. This takes the form of painterly playbacks of exotic imagery of Chinese-ness once popular in the West, like pictures of girls with pigtails eating noodles. The idea's a bit lame, although there is a lovely effulgence of color to the paintings that I like. No, I like it a lot.
"A Brush With History: Contemporary Artists and Chinese Tradition" is at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, through July 6. Information: (973)596-6550.
