HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: REBUILDING; 
Top Employer Gone, Iraqis Scuffle for Jobs

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 4 

 BODY:
His job gone and his savings depleted, Saman Murad clung desperately to the 13-year-old letter that constituted his one thin hope for income-producing work.
 It was a severance notice from the American Embassy, written just a few weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, informing Mr. Murad "with great sadness" that his job as a receptionist had been suspended as a result of the "deteriorating political conditions" between Iraq and the United States. 
 Today, three weeks after Saddam Hussein's government crumbled, Mr. Murad is among the thousands of Iraqis here begging for work from the newly arrived American administrators. 
But like most of other applicants, Mr. Murad has awakened to the bitter realization that the Americans are hiring very few of those now unemployed.
On Saturday, hundreds of angry Iraqis swarmed into the lobby of the Palestine Hotel, which is home to most foreign journalists here, and protested for hours about their inability to get work from the American administrators, who now have their headquarters inside the marble halls of the Republican Palace.
"Don't try to persuade us that the U.S.A., after 40 days, cannot constitute a government that controls everything," said Younis Abbas Khamis, a 55-year-old government worker. "If this chaos lasts forever, there will be a revolution."
Many Iraqis have fallen victim to hucksters who sold them job applications, but who had no connection to the American administrators.
Even without the sting of local con artists, job prospects here are horrendous, and tempers are rising. By some estimates, as much as 75 percent of the Iraqi work force made a living from either the government or the military -- both of which have now collapsed.
Largely because of the trade sanctions imposed by the United Nations after the Persian Gulf war in 1991, manufacturing had all but halted by the time the United States and Britain attacked in March. Many urban Iraqis moved to the country and turned to subsistence farming for survival.
Meanwhile, prices for many basic staples are rising rapidly as shortages and growing demand collide with the incoming flood of dollars from big-spending foreign government officials, international organizations and journalists from around the world.
For the lucky few -- those who find work with foreigners as translators or drivers or technical specialists -- income has soared from about $40 a month to as much as $100 a day. But for an unlucky majority, the immediate postwar period means lost jobs and higher prices.
Adding to the unhappiness, most of Baghdad's five million residents remain without electricity and telephone service. Food is available, but refrigerators cannot keep it fresh. Buying gasoline, in a country with the world's second-largest oil reserves, requires waiting in lines that look like parking lots.
Not surprisingly, many Iraqis are focusing their frustrations on the country's new American bosses.
"We want to form a government that can restore civil employees to their jobs," said Sheik Jassim Muhammad Hassan, a deputy chieftain of tribal leaders in Baghdad. "We are having difficulty curbing our tribes from going into rebellion."
Outside the former Republican Palace, soldiers turned away hundreds of Iraqis begging to put in job applications.
Inside the palace, Iraqi tribal leaders waited patiently for the chance to meet with American military and civilian administrators and communicate the rising dissatisfaction.
"They suffer from hunger and they want jobs," said Hannash al-Musawi, head of the Musawi tribe, whose members are scattered through central and southern Iraq. "We have told them to have patience, to wait for the Americans for jobs. But people are very unhappy. You hear the same thing everywhere."
Some jobs are expected to come from American companies, like Bechtel, that have won reconstruction contracts from the United States government. Bechtel and other contractors have said they plan to hire many Iraqi companies as subcontractors.
But Bush administration officials are already worrying about how to handle the thousands of Iraqi government workers who will no longer be needed. The bankrupt Iraqi government has almost no cash to keep paying salaries, and the United States has not specifically budgeted money to make up the difference.
Jay Garner, the retired lieutenant general who heads the American administration here, has promised $20 to each civil servant as an emergency allocation, but details have not been worked out.
Foreign investors and Iraqi-born industrialists, who shifted most of their businesses to other countries over the past decade, say the country is still too chaotic and unstable to risk their own money.
Mr. Murad is still hoping for work with Americans. But his English is rudimentary, and his application for work is merely one of thousands on file at the Republican Palace.
Now 40, with a wife and three children, Mr. Murad struggled for years after losing his job at the American Embassy. Branded as a sympathizer to the United States, he was unemployed for four years after the war in Kuwait. Then he worked for the Sheraton as a plumber, but lost that job when the hotel cut staff. Finally he enlisted in the Iraqi Army, which he deserted just before American troops poured into Baghdad.
"I don't have any more money," Mr. Murad said as he stood among the protesters at the Palestine Hotel on Saturday. "What can I do to get an appointment for a job?"

HEADLINE: SOCCER; 
U.S. Is Eager To Step In As Host Of World Cup

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
The United States will most likely become the substitute host of the Women's World Cup if acceptable financial arrangements can be made between soccer's world governing body and American organizers, soccer officials said yesterday.
 The World Cup, the largest international sporting event for women, was scheduled to be played from Sept. 23 to Oct. 11 in China, but it was withdrawn by FIFA on Saturday because of the SARS epidemic. 
 "The logical choice is here," Dr. S. Robert Contiguglia, president of U.S. Soccer, said yesterday in a telephone interview. "The question is, can we work it out?" 
Chuck Blazer, an American representative to FIFA, soccer's world governing body, cited organizational difficulties in Australia, the other serious candidate, telling The Associated Press, "My guess would be that they'll wind up here."
American soccer officials will travel today to FIFA headquarters in Zurich to make a proposal. A decision could be reached this week or next. Time is urgent because planners would have less than five months to prepare for the 16-team tournament.
A number of football and soccer stadiums are being discussed as possible World Cup sites. They include the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., which was filled with 90,000 fans for the 1999 final between the United States and China, and which is available on Oct. 11. Also mentioned as potential sites are Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington; CMGI Field in Foxboro, Mass.; the newly built Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia; and Spartan Stadium in San Jose, Calif.
Soccer stadiums in Columbus, Ohio, and Carson, Calif., as well as a new football stadium built to soccer dimensions for the University of Connecticut in Storrs, are also possibilities.
American organizers made the 1999 Women's World Cup a spectacular success, but that was with two and a half years to prepare. The dramatic final, won by the United States on Brandi Chastain's shirt-shedding penalty kick, drew 40 million American television viewers, still the largest national TV audience for a soccer match. The tournament earned a profit of between $2 million and $3 million on a budget of $38 million and demonstrated emphatically that people would pay in large numbers to watch a women's sporting event.
"No one on the planet can duplicate what happened in '99," Contiguglia said.
That tournament ended in July, with little competition from other sports, while this World Cup would compete with the baseball playoffs, and college and pro football, as well as with youth soccer leagues. Still, organizers would ambitiously hope for sellouts, Contiguglia said, relying on a highly organized network of volunteers and youth programs.
Previously, American soccer officials were ambivalent about playing host to this year's World Cup, planning instead to make a pitch for the 2007 tournament. Once that was awarded to China as consolation, the national federation became much more receptive. The potential upside is significant. The World Cup could bring much needed attention to the Women's United Soccer Association, the fledgling eight-team American professional league, and American officials could be seen as rescuers of one of the world's most important soccer tournaments.
Also, if 90,000 fans are again attracted to a final at the Rose Bowl after such short preparation, it would serve as a remarkable example of the broad reach of soccer in this country. The pitch to this year's World Cup would be the quality of play and the last chance to see icons like Mia Hamm in the sport's grandest event, Contiguglia said.
Still, many financial details need to be settled with FIFA, which in the past has paid for team travel and hotel stays. Will that guarantee continue? Will other enticements be made to American organizers? What kind of local marketing opportunities will FIFA allow? Would the tournament be staged entirely in one part of the country to trim costs?
"If we can do it, we will do everything we can to make it work," Contiguglia said. "It can be a great event. But it's a huge economic risk. I can't put U.S. Soccer at risk unless we can find some way to make it reasonable."

HEADLINE: Who Wants to Be a Martyr? 

BYLINE:  By Scott Atran; Scott Atran, a research scientist at the National Center for Scientific Research in Paris and at the University of Michigan, is author of "In Gods We Trust: The Evolutionary Landscape of Religion."

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich. 

 BODY:
One given in the war against terrorism seems to be that suicide attackers are evil, deluded or homicidal misfits who thrive in poverty, ignorance and anarchy. 
 President Bush, at last year's United Nations conference on poor nations in Monterrey, Mexico, said that "we fight against poverty because hope is an answer to terror." Senator John Warner, the Virginia Republican, argued that a new security doctrine including wars of preemption was necessary because "those who would commit suicide in their assaults on the free world are not rational." A State Department report issued on the first anniversary of the 9/11 attacks said that development aid should be based "on the belief that poverty provides a breeding ground for terrorism." 
 As logical as the poverty-breeds-terrorism argument may seem, study after study shows that suicide attackers and their supporters are rarely ignorant or impoverished. Nor are they crazed, cowardly, apathetic or asocial. If terrorist groups relied on such maladjusted people, "they couldn't produce effective and reliable killers," according to Todd Stewart, a retired Air Force general who directs the Ohio State University program in international and domestic security. 
In the suicide bombing of a cafe in Tel Aviv last week that killed three bystanders, for instance, the bomber and the man accused of being his accomplice grew up in Britain, in relatively prosperous circumstances, and attended college. 
The Princeton economist Alan Krueger and others released a study in 2002 comparing Lebanese Hezbollah militants who died in violent action to other Lebanese of the same age group. He found that the Hezbollah members were less likely to come from poor homes and more likely to have a secondary school education.
Nasra Hassan, a Pakistani relief worker, interviewed nearly 250 aspiring Palestinian suicide bombers and their recruiters. "None were uneducated, desperately poor, simple-minded or depressed," she reported in 2001. "They all seemed to be entirely normal members of their families."
A 2001 poll by the nonprofit Palestinian Center for Policy and Survey Research indicated that Palestinian adults with 12 years or more of education are far more likely to support bomb attacks than those who cannot read. 
Officials with the Army Defense Intelligence Agency who have interrogated Saudi-born members of Al Qaeda being detained at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, have told me that these fundamentalists, especially those in leadership positions, are often educated above reasonable employment level; a surprising number have graduate degrees and come from high-status families. Their motivation and commitment are evident in their willingness to sacrifice material and emotional comforts (families, jobs, physical security), to travel long distances and to pay their own way. 
The body of research shows that over all, suicide terrorists tend not to have the attributes of the socially dysfunctional (fatherless, friendless, jobless). They don't vent fear of enemies or express hopelessness or a sense of "nothing to lose" because of lack of a career or social mobility as would be consistent with economic theories of criminal behavior. Suicide attackers don't opt for paradise out of despair. If they did, say Muslim clerics who countenance martyrdom for Allah but not personal suicide, their actions would be criminal and blasphemous.
A study of world attitudes toward America by the Pew Research Center in December 2002 and many other polls of Muslims from Algeria to Indonesia show ever-rising support for "martyrs." A United Nations report indicated that as soon as the United States began building up for the Iraq invasion, Qaeda recruitment has picked up in 30 to 40 countries. Recruiters for groups sponsoring terrorist acts tell researchers that volunteers are beating down the doors to join.
This allows terrorist agents to choose recruits who are intelligent, psychologically balanced and socially poised. Candidates who mostly want virgins in paradise or money for their families are weeded out. Those selected show patience and the ability to plan and execute in subtle, quiet ways that don't draw attention. Al Qaeda, especially, is rarely in a hurry. It can wait years and then strike when least expected.
It's the particular genius of the institutions like Al Qaeda, Hamas or Hezbollah that they are able to make otherwise well-adjusted people into human bombs. Intense indoctrination, often lasting 18 months or more, causes recruits to identify emotionally with their terrorist cell, viewing it as a family for whom they are as willing to die as a mother for her child or a soldier for his buddies. Consider the oath taken by members of Harkat al Ansar, a Pakistan-based ally of Al Qaeda: "Each martyr has a special place -- among them are brothers, just as there are sons and those even more dear." 
Brian Barber, a psychologist at the University of Tennessee, has interviewed some 900 young adults from Gaza and a comparison group of Bosnian Muslims who had also suffered through violence but had not become a source of suicide bombers. The Bosnians had markedly weaker expressions of self-esteem and less hope for the future. Faith was the largest difference: the Palestinians routinely invoked religion to invest personal trauma with social meaning, whereas the Bosnians did not consider religion significant to their life.
This overall pattern was also captured in a white paper by the Parliament of Singapore concerning captured operatives from Jemaah Islamiyah, a militant group allied with Al Qaeda: "These men were not ignorant, destitute or disenfranchised. Like many of their counterparts in militant Islamic organizations in the region, they held normal, respectable jobs. As a group, most of the detainees regarded religion as their most important personal value." 
Like the best Madison Avenue advertisers, but to ghastlier effect, the charismatic leaders of terrorist groups turn ordinary desires for family and religion into cravings for what they're pitching.
How do we combat these masters of manipulation? President Bush and many American politicans maintain that these groups and the people supporting them hate our democracy and freedoms. But poll after poll of the Muslim world shows opinion strongly favoring America's forms of government, personal liberty and education. A University of Michigan political scientist, Mark Tessler, finds Arab attitudes to American culture most favorable among young adults (regardless of their religious feeling) -- the same population that recruiters single out. 
It is our actions that they don't like: as long ago as 1997, a Defense Department report (in response to the 1996 suicide bombing of Air Force housing at the Khobar Towers in Saudi Arabia) noted that "historical data show a strong correlation between U.S. involvement in international situations and an increase in terrorist attacks against the United States." 
Shows of military strength don't seem to dissuade terrorists: witness thefailure of Israel's coercive efforts to end the string of Palestinian suicide bombings. Rather, we need to show the Muslim world the side of our culture that they most respect. Our engagement needs to involve interfaith initiatives, not ethnic profiling. America must address grievances, such as the conflict in the Palestinian territories, whose daily images of violence engender global Muslim resentment. 
Of course, this does not mean negotiating with terrorist groups over goals like Al Qaeda's quest to replace the Western-inspired system of nation-states with a global caliphate. Osama bin Laden seeks no compromise. But most of the people who sympathize with him just might.

HEADLINE: U.S. Hopes to Bridge Divide With Europein Trade Talks 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: MUNICH, May 3 

 BODY:
Europe and the United States clashed bitterly over the war in Iraq, but a senior American official is urging the two sides to use trade negotiations as a way to mend fences.
 Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, told German business executives in Munich today, "Here's an opportunity we can seize together, because it is in our mutual interest and the common interest." 
 In an interview, Mr. Zoellick said cooperating on free trade would allow Germany to do more than "wring hands" about its strained ties with Washington. Germany could reclaim at least a measure of its traditional role as a reliable partner. "I'm making it easy for them," he said. 
Mr. Zoellick was ending a weeklong swing through Europe, during which he met with finance and trade ministers in Berlin and Paris, as well as Europe's commissioner for trade, Pascal Lamy.
While Mr. Zoellick said there was still resistance to American proposals to reduce trade barriers, particularly in agriculture and particularly from the French, he was leaving Europe "with some slight additional optimism."
His choice of Munich to deliver this message was laden with symbolism. The last senior American official to come to this city was Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, not long after he dismissed Germany and France as "old Europe" for their opposition of the war.
Mr. Rumsfeld sparred with the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, during his appearance at a security conference, while protesters thronged outside to denounce the Bush administration.
There were no protesters at this economic conference, and Mr. Zoellick, after opening with "Gruss Gott," a traditional Bavarian salutation meaning "God's greeting," was applauded enthusiastically by the audience of German captains of industry.
Still, Mr. Zoellick's remarks underscored the depth of the divide between Europe and the United States in trade. He pressed the Europeans to reduce their $60 billion in subsidies to farmers to close a gap with the United States, which has proposed deep cuts in tariffs and subsidies.
European countries, particularly France, are resisting such measures. Unless the United States and Europe compromise on agriculture, it could scuttle the current round of trade talks, which began in 2001 in Doha, Qatar, and is supposed to yield an agreement by January 2005.
"We really are at a crunch point in the next couple of months," Mr. Zoellick said, noting that the World Trade Organization would hold a key meeting in Cancun, Mexico, in September to assess its progress.
Mr. Zoellick played down the threat by some American lawmakers that the United States would withdraw from the World Trade Organization if Europe did not back down on its farm policy. Earlier in the week, in Paris, he dismissed talk of trade sanctions against France.
Mr. Zoellick has deep ties to Germany, dating to his role as a State Department aide who helped develop the United States policy on German reunification in 1990. He made it clear that he and other White House officials still felt stung by Germany's strident opposition of the war.
"I'm not hiding the fact that there was disappointment and even hurt," he said. "In France's case, I was even more specific, because I think in France's case there was an active effort to work against the U.S."
Mr. Zoellick said Germany and France did not help matters by meeting recently in Brussels with Belgium and Luxembourg to discuss a new European defense structure that would, in effect, parallel NATO.
"In a way, that meeting was a parody," Mr. Zoellick said. "Does anyone really believe that Belgium and Luxembourg are going to be the nucleus of a new security force in Europe?"
While trade may be a less charged issue, some experts say the gulf between the United States and Europe is too wide to be bridged in time for a deal by 2005. "Very few people are optimistic that's going to happen," said J. Peter Neary, a professor of political economy at University College Dublin.
Still, Mr. Zoellick's remarks may counter a growing belief in Europe that the so-called Doha round is already doomed. People here said they were encouraged that Mr. Zoellick praised Mr. Lamy, a Frenchman, and avoided criticizing the French president, Jacques Chirac.
"It is a relief that there are still people in Washington who understand how Europe works," said Norbert Walter, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank, who was in the audience. "Zoellick can serve as a bridge."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Well, It Played In Peekskill. Will It in Iowa?

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
 JANUARY 2008. An interview with George E. Pataki:

Q. Mr. Pataki, Republicans in Iowa are about to give the country the first official insight into the popularity of candidates in this year's presidential race. You are from the Northeast, you went to Yale, and you live in Peekskill, N.Y., not rural Texas. You were governor of New York when it went from bust to boom to bust again. What makes you think you can be elected president?

A. I fought job-killing taxes.

Q. Governor, the religious right is so influential in Iowa that in 2000, George W. Bush, who had tried to plant himself in the center, moved to the right on abortion and emphasized his religious beliefs. You favor abortion rights and have not paraded your religion. How can you win in Iowa?

A. I will tell the people that just as I did in New York, I will fight job-killing taxes.

Q. There are other matters that concern Iowa voters. For instance, you favored gun control and antismoking laws as governor. Do you think those positions will sit well with Iowa Republicans?

A. The people of Iowa have a lot in common with the people of New York. I intend to explain to the voters of Iowa and the rest of the country that I will oppose job-killing taxes when I get to the White House, just as I did in Albany.

Q. As long as you have brought it up, your fiscal policies were somewhat controversial. You did try to hold the line on tax increases in that critical year of 2003, but conservative critics said the budget gap would not have been so large that year if you had been more prudent earlier.

A. I was not responsible for the national recession, the impact of Sept. 11, the collapse of Wall Street. I led the state to unprecedented prosperity before factors beyond our control hurt our budget, and when they did, remember, I refused to increase job-killing taxes.

Q. But, governor, the respected weekly journal The Economist wrote in April of that difficult budget year that after you won your first term running as a fiscal conservative and reduced the state budget in your first year, you let the budget grow faster than inflation every year after that.

A. As I have said, I did not raise job-killing taxes.

Q. Thank you for explaining that. The Economist also said, however, that the budget grew not only during affluent years, when you might have better prepared for leaner times, but also after that, when the state was already hurting from Sept. 11 and the national recession, and you continued to spend generously. Were your policies inspired by your campaign for re-election?

A. Well, my critics even thought politics inspired my trip to Vieques -- to demonstrate opposition to naval maneuvers on that Puerto Rican island. Would New York's taxpayers have paid for that trip if it was politically motivated? Polls never influenced my judgment about what my state needed. And New York did not -- have I made this point yet? -- need job-killing taxes.

Q. Mr. Pataki, detractors asked why, in your 2002 re-election year, you spent state dollars on wage increases for health care workers, teachers and other union members. Why, they ask, did you delay transit fare increases? And why did you expand Medicaid, the largest burden on New York's local governments?

A. As I always say, the polls go up, the polls go down. That in no way affected my policies. As governor, I made the tough decisions. Especially the decision to fight job-killing taxes.

Q. Yes, taxes. After the Legislature approved tax increases to help local governments close their own budget gaps, you continued to fight the increases. Some said that marked you as a weak leader, but others said it revealed your national ambition.

A. As I said, I ignore polls, which go up and go down. Job-killing taxes should never go up.

Q. Mr. Pataki, since most of the Legislature's tax increases went into effect in 2003 despite your opposition, and local governments still had to cut services and raise their own taxes, what was the practical impact of your hold-the-line strategy?

A. It showed that the governor of the Empire State would not go along with raising job-killing taxes. The people of this great state of Iowa can be assured that what I did for New York, I will do for the country. That is a promise.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 9, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The Metro Matters column on Monday, about Gov. George E. Pataki's opposition to "job-killing taxes," misidentified his place of residence. It is Garrison, N.Y.; Peekskill is the city where he was once mayor.

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: THE ASIAN ARENA; 
BUSH SHIFTS FOCUS TO NUCLEAR SALES BY NORTH KOREA

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., May 4 

 BODY:
Tacitly acknowledging that North Korea may not be deterred from producing plutonium for nuclear weapons, President Bush is now trying to marshal international support for preventing the country from exporting nuclear material, American and foreign officials say.
 Mr. Bush discussed the new approach on Saturday morning with Australia's prime minister, John Howard, after the two men were given a lengthy briefing at Mr. Bush's ranch by the chief American negotiator with North Korea, James A. Kelly, officials said. 
 For a decade, the United States' declared policy has been that North Korea would be prevented, by any means necessary, from producing plutonium or highly enriched uranium. President Bill Clinton ordered the Pentagon to draw up plans for a military strike when the North threatened to begin production in 1994, but a nuclear freeze agreement was reached later that year. 
Mr. Bush's new focus on blocking the sale of nuclear material to countries or terrorist groups reflects intelligence officials' conclusion that they cannot ascertain whether North Korea was bluffing when it claimed last month that it had already reprocessed enough spent nuclear fuel to make many weapons.
"The president said that the central worry is not what they've got, but where it goes," said an official familiar with the talks between Mr. Bush and Mr. Howard. "He's very pragmatic about it, and the reality is that we probably won't know the extent of what they are producing. So the whole focus is to keep the plutonium from going further."
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, in an appearance on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," insisted today that the administration's long-term goal was to force North Korea to dismantle all of its nuclear weapons programs. He vowed that it would get no international aid unless its government changed course.
"Everybody has now made it clear to North Korea that they will not find any assistance coming to them from the region in terms of economic development," he said, "unless they abandon their nuclear weapons programs." 
But in recent interviews, several American officials have said that it was becoming clear that the policy that Mr. Clinton described in 1994 -- when he warned that producing plutonium could result in an American attack to destroy the nuclear facilities at Yongbyon -- was probably not sustainable anymore.
South Korea's new president, Roh Moo Hyun, who will visit Washington for the first time next week, "has made it clear he won't consider military action of any kind," said one senior administration official. "It's a different atmosphere than in 1994."
Another official who has discussed the issue with Mr. Bush said his thinking was that the North Koreans "are looking to get us excited, to make us issue declarations."
"And his answer to them is," the official added, 'You're hungry, and you can't eat plutonium.' "
Still, Mr. Bush's approach is a major gamble -- one that depends on superb intelligence about North Korea's efforts to sell its weapons. So far, though, the nuclear program has been what one American intelligence official calls "the black hole of Asia."
American officials have apparently been unable to find new facilities they believe North Korea is building -- presumably underground -- to produce highly enriched uranium, a technology obtained largely from Pakistan in a trade for missiles. 
Unlike North Korea's missiles, which can be seen by satellites as they are loaded into ships and sent to Iran, Syria, Yemen and other nations, weapons-grade nuclear material is easily transportable. Experts say that material would be relatively easy to transport over North Korea's long border with China, part of the reason that Mr. Bush is working to engage the Chinese leadership in confronting North Korea about its nuclear program.
"It's a fantasy to think you can put a hermetic seal around North Korea and keep them from getting a grapefruit-size piece of plutonium out of the country," said Ashton B. Carter, a Harvard professor who worked on Korea issues in the Clinton administration, said today. "To allow North Korea to go nuclear is a major defeat for U.S. security."
The Bush administration has been deeply divided over how to counter North Korea's efforts to turn its nuclear program into cash, with some of the more hawkish members urging that talks be abandoned. They want the United States and its allies -- including China, if it is willing -- to enforce an embargo that could include the interdiction of North Korean freighters. 
Spanish forces intercepted a ship full of missiles headed for Yemen last year, though Mr. Bush decided to let the ship deliver its goods after Yemen's president protested.
Mr. Powell was asked today how the United States would react to the development of a large nuclear arsenal in North Korea, and he answered, "Their nuclear weapons are not going to purchase them any political standing that will cause us to be frightened or to think that somehow we now have to march to their tune." He made no suggestion, however, that the United States would take military action against the main nuclear facilities that Mr. Clinton considered attacking.
But when asked whether the United States would ever allow North Korea to sell or transfer nuclear weapons, Mr. Powell said, "Absolutely not."
Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he and other former defense secretaries had been briefed on the military plan in 1994 by the secretary of defense at the time, William J. Perry. But he declined to draw the same "red line" for the North Koreans, saying that any decision on military action would have to made by Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Howard said nothing about North Korea after their meeting on Saturday. Mr. Bush's aides say they hope to continue the low-key approach. 
But they are counting on growing aid from China, which was the host of the talks last week. To build support among Chinese leaders there is talk within the administration of letting China convene another meeting. "We might be willing to go to a second round," one senior administration official said. "The North Koreans have to come prepared to say what they will do, rather than bargain for what they can get."

HEADLINE: Bucking Bush, Senator Takes A Thorny Path 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4 

 BODY:
Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, is the woman who said no -- to her president, to her party's leadership in the Senate, to the House of Representatives. It has not been easy, she says.
 President Bush sought $726 billion in tax cuts over 10 years. House Republicans were willing to settle for $550 billion. But Ms. Snowe, an influential moderate and a pivotal vote on the Senate Finance Committee, has said, consistently and implacably, that $350 billion is as far as she will go. 
 So she had to look the president in the eye -- "a friend and somebody I admire and respect very much" -- and tell him that she could not be with him this time.
"Obviously, you'd like to work things out if you can," Ms. Snowe, 56, said in an interview. "But if you can't, because it contravenes what you believe in, it makes it very difficult. I'm just having a hard time with the fact that I'm looking at these deficits down the road."
The decision by Ms. Snowe, along with a handful of other moderate Republicans in the Senate who balked at the size of the original tax cut proposal, has tied the Republican Congress in knots. Some Democrats have long grumbled that Republican moderates inevitably cave to their party's conservative leaders in the end, but so far Ms. Snowe and the others have not.
Her vote will be crucial this week when the Senate Finance Committee takes up tax cut legislation. The committee has 11 Republicans and 10 Democrats, which makes it difficult to find a majority on such polarizing issues as the president's push to eliminate taxation of dividends.
Ms. Snowe, who came to the House in 1978 and was elected to the Senate in 1994, has come to symbolize the strains in her party between moderates and conservatives, deficit hawks and tax cutters.
Many supply-siders are furious that a popular president, coming off the war in Iraq, is being thwarted in his quest for huge tax cuts by Republicans like Ms. Snowe. The Club for Growth, a conservative group, has run television advertising in Maine asserting that the senator is "standing in the way" of Mr. Bush on the tax cuts, just as the French stood in his way on the war in Iraq.
The commercials clearly infuriate her. "I can only regard that, interpret that, as suggesting that I'm unpatriotic, and that did offend me," she said. In a state where many people are of French descent, the ads almost certainly did not hurt her politically, political analysts said.
Ms. Snowe has also had her Republican bona fides challenged by tax cutters like Grover G. Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform, who asked, "If you're not for tax cuts, and you're liberal on social issues, what's the difference between you and a Democrat?"
Ms. Snowe replied that it was a strange time when support for a $350 billion tax cut was considered insufficiently zealous. "I just think it's amazing that anybody would question my Republican credentials," she said. "New England Republicans represent the traditional roots of the Republican Party."
For those who remember the alienation and ultimate defection of another moderate New England Republican, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, who became an independent, Ms. Snowe said flatly that there would be no repeat. "I'm not going away," she said. "I like to remind them of our traditional roots, and part of that heritage is fiscal responsibility and accountability. That's a heritage we can't abandon, and that gets back to deficits. I don't want balanced budgets to be a brief fiscal interlude."
Ms. Snowe has indicated some flexibility on the tax cuts. She has said she would go somewhat above $350 billion, for example, if the costs are offset elsewhere in the budget by specific spending cuts or raising revenue through closing tax loopholes.
In fact, Ms. Snowe said, she is largely driven by her past -- by years of service on the budget committees of the House and Senate, by watching the deficits accumulate in the 1980's, the repeated attempts to eliminate them in the 1990's and then, finally, the appearance of not just balanced budgets but surpluses. Now those surpluses are gone, as the baby boomers head toward Medicare and Social Security.
"I see this collision between our current deficits, the cumulative deficits and the baby boomer retirement starting in 2013," she said. "Have I missed something? We're in the decade of the century when it matters -- what our financial standing is, our preparation to meet these financial obligations. The future is now. We're upon it."
The counterargument from conservatives is that the deficits are still quite manageable, that the economy badly needs the stimulus of a large tax cut, and that a robust and growing economy is the best long-term solution to deficits. 
Still, Ms. Snowe's stand is hardly unpopular back home: fiscal conservatism and social liberalism is the recipe for Republican victories in New England. She bucks the Bush administration on tax cuts, abortion rights and environmental issues like drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Those positions may not fit the prevailing conservatism among Republicans, but "Olympia Snowe is the best Republican the national party can get out of New England," said Darrell West, a political scientist at Brown University. 
"She's getting overwhelming support back home," said Representative Tom Allen, Democrat of Maine. "To have an outside group come in and run television ads against a senator who's doing exactly what people in Maine think she ought to be doing is a gift."
Ms. Snowe said she was weary of the current partisanship on Capitol Hill. "If you want to get something done, and get away from the 'all or nothing, my way or no way,' proposition, it is a very difficult environment, to say the least," she said.
But she says she is a survivor, above all. Her mother died of breast cancer when Ms. Snowe was 8. Her father died of heart disease when she was 9. Ms. Snowe went off to a boarding school in New York run by the Greek Orthodox Church. "You grow up quickly," she said. "You become very independent."
Ms. Snowe's first husband, Peter Snowe, a state representative in Maine, died in a car accident in 1973, and she was elected to his seat in the Legislature, where she served until she ran for the House in 1978. In 1989, she married John McKernan, a former colleague in the House and a former governor of Maine.
Mr. McKernan said those who think they can get Ms. Snowe to change her mind "are people who haven't met her, apparently."

HEADLINE: GOTHAM; 
At This Address, Not Everyone Starts on the Ground Floor

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
ON the second floor of 336 West 37th Street in Manhattan, a sign on the door of Regency Fashion says the minimum wage is $5.15 an hour. Someone has scribbled a 1 after the dollar sign. Inside, most of the sewing machines are silent. A Chinese deity looks over the factory floor from behind a mound of partly burned incense sticks. Several of the dozen workers have tied strips of red fabric around their noses to block the dust.
 "We are very slow this week," said Angela Ng, a worker. She considers herself lucky to have a steady job, 8 to 10 hours a day, five to six days a week. 
 Eight stories up, sunlight floods the spacious workshop of Christopher Spitzmiller, who makes expensive ceramic lamps. Seated at his potter's wheel, he can see a new luxury residential building nearby, as well as the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and the Hudson River. 
"When I rented it, it was like a fire had gone off in here," Mr. Spitzmiller said of his 2,700-square-foot studio, which had been a rundown manufacturing space. He renovated -- no, transformed -- the space and installed a kiln. He produces about 60 lamps a month for people like President Bush and Oprah Winfrey.
A 14-story building with a penthouse, on the western edge of the garment district, 336 West 37th Street not only reflects the economic and ethnic variety of New York's small businesses, but is also a barometer of their success. Within this 75-year-old building, the businesses literally rise and fall with the economic winds. Take the elevator up and, floor by floor, the windows let in more light. The paint in the hallways changes from dark gray to silver. Fabric carts give way to chandeliers. 
Some companies move up. Some move down. Others disappear. Philippe Ifrah, a partner at I.G.S. Realty Company, which owns the building, said he had a $4.5 million mortgage. He shepherds struggling businesses into smaller, cheaper spaces on the lower floors and reserves top-floor vistas for tenants who can pay the higher rents.
In the late 1990's, Regency Fashion, a clothing manufacturer, ceded its space on the sixth floor and now occupies a small space on the second floor. In 2001, Apparel Cutting, also a clothing maker, tumbled from the 11th floor to the 2nd floor. 
Another tenant, James Brady, has a catering and event planning company that took over the 11th floor in January 2001; two years later, he opened a party space in the penthouse. "After my cousin died at the World Trade Center -- he was a fireman -- it took the fear out of me," Mr. Brady said. "Failing is not an option."
Down at Apparel Cutting, failure is very much an option. Tony Hoti, who came to New York from Yugoslavia in 1969, founded the company with his brother, Dominick, in 1985. At its peak in the late 80's, Apparel had 14 full-time employees. Now, it employs two to four temporary workers. "I try to do it myself, really, with family help," Mr. Hoti said. "There is not much left." He said he paid his workers $12 to $14 an hour and cannot compete with cheaper labor overseas. "I'm just trying to buy time until I retire. I wish I was a cook."
The garment district, which stretches roughly from Fifth Avenue to Ninth Avenue, between 35th and 40th Streets, has been mostly overlooked by the big corporations that dominate the city's economy. According to the New York State Department of Labor, 90 percent of the city's 214,419 private companies had 19 or fewer employees in September 2002, the latest data that is available. But these small businesses employed only 24 percent of the city's 2.9 million workers. 
There have been some successful government initiatives designed to encourage the growth of small businesses in New York City, but mostly these owners have had to fend for themselves. After nearly three years of a bruising recession and more than two decades of skyrocketing real estate costs, many small businesses have settled in the garment district, which is in Midtown but is cheaper than other commercial parts of Manhattan.
The district was developed in the 20's and 30's to accommodate the booming women's fashion trade, and most buildings are unsuitable for large firms. 
"The garment center has older properties built at a time when major corporations weren't the norm in New York City," said Matthew Astrachan, an executive director at Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate company. "Therefore, they have smaller floor plates that aren't as attractive to the larger business owner."
THAT has helped to keep rents low. In the first quarter of this year, the average rent for office space in the district was $31.27 a square foot, according to Cushman & Wakefield, an amount much lower than the citywide average of $41.97. (The rents at 336 West 37th Street average $14 to $16 a square foot because the building is mainly industrial loft spaces.) 
In the mid-90's, Internet companies flocked to the neighborhood. Most have vaporized. Fashion businesses still dominate the area, making up two-thirds of rental tenants, but their presence is waning. From 1989 to 2000, the number of fashion-related jobs in the neighborhood fell 15 percent, according to a study commissioned by the Fashion Center Business Improvement District. Apparel manufacturers were hit especially hard. Meanwhile, photographers, graphic designers, theaters, nonprofit corporations, real estate companies, architects, accountants, insurance companies and small law firms have been moving in. These companies prefer the open factory floors that the district offers. 
Mr. Ifrah started managing 336 West 37th Street in the mid-90's. Then, all the tenants were garment manufacturers, he said, who paid an average of $7 a square foot for rent. Many of them, decimated by the steady flow of manufacturing jobs overseas, could not pay their rent. The building declared bankruptcy in 1995. By 1999, Mr. Ifrah and his partners refinanced and completed a $500,000 renovation. "We created a new image," said Mr. Ifrah, a native of Madrid. "From that point on, we started seeing the rents go up." 
Now, 16 of the 35 tenants are garment manufacturers. Others include photo studios, a kickboxing gym and the Art Party, a theater company managed by the actor Alan Cumming and Nick Philippou. Two art theaters, the Zipper and the Belt, occupy the ground floor, which once housed a zipper warehouse and a belt factory.
Mr. Ifrah, whose desk is a slab of polished marble propped on two sawhorses, said he gave many of his artistic tenants a break on their rent. Creative tenants lend cachet to the building, he said, and usually renovate their spaces beautifully. They tend not to mind the neighborhood's rough edges.
"I have had people complain, 'I can't bring my Park Avenue clients down here,' " said Mr. Spitzmiller, the lamp maker. But, he added, most of the decorators that he deals with appreciate the district's unruly quality. "Ninth Avenue has soul." Those seeking steel-and-glass towers, or bothered by the presence of a methadone clinic, know to look elsewhere.
Moreno Giannaccini, an Italian-born sculptor, rents space on the seventh floor. Everything except the bottles of grappa and Seagram's Extra Dry gin is splattered with white plaster. "I used to be on the 15th-floor" penthouse, he said. "Now they are the beautiful people."
Over the years, Mr. Giannaccini has traveled the city rooting out studio space that could be one step ahead of gentrification. "He probably is going to tell me in a couple of years: 'You get out. You can't afford it,' " Mr. Giannaccini said, gesturing to Mr. Ifrah. 
Mr. Ifrah just shook his head and blushed.

HEADLINE: GETTING STARTED; 
Big Mistakes! And Some Tips on How to Avoid Them

BYLINE:  By JULIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
THIS may seem like the worst of times to start a small business, but in some ways, a downturn is the best of times.
 "Bad times make you more focused," said Judith Gerberg, a career counselor in New York who started her own business 18 years ago. "You are going to be more conscious of what you are spending on. You'll be slower to expand and more cautious about hiring. Your expectations will be more reasonable." 
 A ready supply of talent, an abundance of office space and less competition for financing are other reasons to consider starting a business when the economy is lagging, experts say. But regardless of the economic climate, there are rules that apply to anyone embarking on an entrepreneurial venture, at any time. 
Of every 100 Americans 18 years or over, 6.2 are engaged in starting a business, according to a study funded by the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation in Kansas City, Mo., which provides education and information about small businesses. Unfortunately, new business failures are common. "Most new businesses fail, and they do so within the first three years," said Rebecca Macieira-Kaufmann, an executive vice president who specializes in small business at Wells Fargo, the banking company. 

Educate Yourself
Plug the words "starting your own business" into any search engine and you will be overwhelmed by the number of responses. Among them is My Own Business (www.myownbusiness.org), a Web site operated by a nonprofit group that offers a free online course on starting a business. There is also FastTrac (www.fasttrac.org), which offers classes in small business around the country. Rob Chernow, the senior vice president for entrepreneurship at the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation, which sponsors FastTrac, said: "The courses help people figure out if being an entrepreneur is for them. They are able to flesh out if they are likely to have a viable business."

Consider Moonlighting
"Who says we are obliged to quit our jobs when we start a business?" said Philip Holland, the author of "How to Start a Business Without Quitting Your Job." "I once did but only because at the time I didn't know any better." 
Assuming you do not have an enormous need for sleep, keeping your day job gives you income and something to fall back on if the new venture fails. If you are thinking of starting a business in a field that you are unfamiliar with, consider getting a second job in that field before taking the plunge. After you have been on your feet all day as a chambermaid-cum-waitress at a charming little bed-and-breakfast, you may not fantasize so much about opening one. You will also have a better idea of what is required.

Harness Your Passion
 Passion underlies the sweat equity that you need to start your own business. Amy Millman, the president of Springboard Enterprises, a Washington company that helps women entrepreneurs find investors, said, "Entrepreneurs underestimate the importance of passion to get them through the hard times." 
Then there is the cash commitment that lenders or investors usually want to see before they agree to back your business. Even the Small Business Administration, a federal agency that guarantees bank loans to small businesses, expects you to have equity in your business totaling 25 to 50 percent of the loan you are requesting.
Carolyn A. Minerich of Jacksonville, Ala., invested both sweat equity and cash in her business. She took the $250,000 in savings she and her husband had accumulated and in 1996 started Carmin Industries, a metal-fabricating company that uses a water-jet technology that can cut through as much as six inches of stone and metal without burning the edges. It took years for the company to get off the ground, but today Ms. Minerich has a business earning annual revenues of $1 million, a 30,000-square-foot factory, 20 employees and clients including Walt Disney World in Florida, which ordered a 50-foot Mickey Mouse hand.
Raj Khera of Rockville, Md., started GovCon.com in 1995 with his brother Vivek and another partner. The Internet portal enables contractors to learn about bidding opportunities for government projects. Mr. Khera and his partners were software consultants by day and worked on their business at night.
Four years later, GovCon was sold to VerticalNet, and Mr. Khera and his brother used their profits to start MailerMailer .com, a company that helps businesses organize and maintain e-mail lists.

Develop a Thick Skin
Get used to rejection because you will experience a lot of it. "I'm constitutionally unable to hear the word no," said Lorraine C. Scarpa, a co-founder of ImmediateFX, a software firm in Monroe, Conn. 

Stay Focused
Focus is the process of defining your business -- what your niche is, who your customers are and how you will serve them. "You need to find out what you can make money at, what customers would buy from you," Mr. Khera said. "You'll always have competitors, so is there something you can make that fits into a specific niche?" Also, when you are looking for financing, investors and lenders will want to know what makes you different from the others out there and how well you understand your market. 
Before starting ImmediateFX with James Friedman and another partner, Ms. Scarpa and Mr. Friedman used to meet for lunch to talk about problems in the marketing industry -- she from the perspective of a buyer of marketing data, he as the head of a company that provided it. 
"We had that 'Aha!' moment in a restaurant," Mr. Friedman recalled. "We realized we had a business." In 1999, they started their company, selling software to integrate marketing data, and now have a business with annual revenues of $5 million.

Keep It Simple
It is one thing to be flexible when you are starting a business; and another to lose your focus by taking on any -- and all -- business to bring in money. This was a temptation faced by Michael Kimelman and Sheila Baird when they started their investment advisory firm, Kimelman & Baird, in Manhattan in 1966. They began by focusing on undervalued securities and, despite pressure over the years to take a different approach, have remained that way. Now, they manage $300 million in assets.
Besides sticking to their core business, Ms. Baird said, they kept a strict eye on costs. She advised anybody starting a company to "spend your money on systems and personnel that you need to run the business, but don't let yourself get saddled with heavy costs because then you are tempted to do things away from your focus just to cover your costs."
Although they paid themselves salaries, the partners did not give themselves raises for the first 15 years. If there were profits at the end of the year, the partners shared them, "but we never increased our salaries," Mr. Kimelman said. "That would have meant more overhead."

Putting Success on Paper
"People tend just to dive in without thinking where they hope to get with their business," said Emily Swenson, a partner at Gansevoort Media, a financial consulting firm in New York.
Ms. Swenson said that entrepreneurs must always be able to answer questions like, How much money do you want to be making in three years? How many employees will you have? How will you be making your product? Where will you be selling it?
Having the answers in your head is not enough; you must also write them down in the form of a business plan. "All business owners should have a business plan," said Ms. Macieira-Kaufmann of Wells Fargo. "It is very hard to have a dialogue about financing without one." 
The thought of writing a business plan strikes fear in the hearts of many would-be entrepreneurs. It should not, though, because there is so much help available. For example, the book "Business Plans That Work," by Joan Gillman, consists of strategies that entrepreneurs have used successfully to raise money. Another useful and comprehensive guide can be found on the Small Business Administration's Web site (www.sba.gov). There is an outline that you can customize for your business, with thorough explanations of what should be included in each section.
"My advice is, don't make it too lengthy -- keep it simple," said Bonita Walsh, the senior managing director for the commercial markets group at Citibank. "You want to describe the business, how you are going to get customers, what the competition is and how the money will come in and go out."

Cash Is King
When small businesses fail, it is usually because of cash-flow problems. "There are very few businesses where the cash comes in equally throughout the year," Ms. Gillman said. As most entrepreneurs discover, customers do not always pay their bills on time. But business owners, unfortunately, have expenses like salaries and rent that have to be paid on a regular basis.
Managing cash flow is all about collecting from customers in a timely way without alienating them, and creating a timetable for paying suppliers without irritating them. Profit and cash are not the same thing, and a business that can show accounting profits can still fold. 
Remember the line, "Show me the money!," from the movie "Jerry Maguire"? Consider that no sale is real until you see the green.

HEADLINE: SNAPSHOTS; 
Flatiron Bistro Held Together By Family Ties

BYLINE:  By ANNA BAHNEY 

 BODY:
CYRIL RENAUD
BUSINESS: Fleur de Sel restaurant.
LOCATION: New York City.
NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES: 25.
ANNUAL REVENUE: $1.5 million.
 FORTUNATELY, Cyril Renaud can turn on a dime. And work on a shoestring. In October 2000, with the city's economy in the doldrums and just 17 days after signing the lease on his small Flatiron district space, Mr. Renaud opened Fleur de Sel, an elegant French restaurant. 
 "Everything we had to do ourselves," recalled Mr. Renaud of the restaurant's early days, when he took charge of the kitchen, his wife, Brigette, a lawyer, looked after business matters, and the dining room was a family effort. "We were coming in with our own glasses and dishes."
The tabletop jars that would hold the fleur de sel, the famous Brittany sea salt, arrived new from France, handpicked by Mr. Renaud's mother, Hugette, who lives in Nantes. Hisfather, Jean Michel, known to the family as Goldfinger because he can fix anything, arrived in person.
"I didn't even sign the lease yet, and my father was already in the space ripping things up," Mr. Renaud said. 
Some chairs, in a light-blond finish, came with the restaurant. Mr. Renaud, though, envisioned them darker, "for the image of things." He said: "My father took each one apart in my garden in Brooklyn. He had some varnish. But it wasn't the right color. So he took dirt and infused it with the varnish and passed it through -- how do you call it, what ladies wear on their legs? -- stockings. And made his own color."
Limited space was another issue, though that problem cut two ways, Mr. Renaud said. "Right now, we have 17 tables and 40 to 47 seats, depending on how the dining room is set up," he said. "I didn't want to go over that. I wanted to be able to control the food and the quality."
He has succeeded admirably. Mr. Renaud, who had worked at Bouley and La Caravelle, earned glowing praise for his "refined" and "imaginative" French cooking, as reviewed in The New York Times in 2000.
Opening the restaurant when the economy was sliding into recession was not easy, however. "We just have to keep the business afloat," Mr. Renaud said. "That's all."
The paintings that adorn the walls did not require a major expenditure. Mr. Renaud painted them, inspired by the raw materials in his kitchen. "I never painted in my life," he said. "But I wanted to use my creative energy. I started painting watercolors. 
"Then I started playing with acrylics. I didn't have time to experiment with oils because the restaurant opened."
 ANNA BAHNEY

GRAPHIC: Photo: EN FAMILLE -- Cyril Renaud and his wife, Brigette, at their restaurant Fleur de Sel. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON; 
The Little Guys Are Ready to Rumble

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ANYONE who doubts that small business has big political clout need only recall the truncated two-year career of Senator Jean Carnahan.
 A centrist Democrat from Missouri, Mrs. Carnahan was appointed to the Senate in 2000 after her husband, Mel, the governor of the state, was killed during his senate race but won the election posthumously. Within months, Mrs. Carnahan was bombarded by demands from small-business owners to join Republicans on a vote to permanently repeal the estate tax. 
 The letters came by the hundreds -- passionate, personalized and sometimes even handwritten on company invoices. "I'm going to be 74 soon and my two sons will get what I have when I die," wrote the owner of a printing company. "They should not have to pay taxes of 55 percent on the small business they own." 
When Mrs. Carnahan voted against the measure, she became a target for the National Federation of Independent Business, a nationwide lobbying group of 600,000 small businesses and a machine to mobilize them. "She is sucking the lifeblood out of your business," the federation charged in a flier picturing a hypodermic needle stuffed with money. Placards extolled her Republican challenger for the Senate in 2002, Representative James M. Talent, as a "proven friend" of small business.
Political organizers for the lobbying group in Washington attracted hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions for Mr. Talent, while members in Missouri organized events to promote him and attack Mrs. Carnahan, who had begun the campaign well ahead in the polls but saw her lead evaporate to go down in defeat by 22,000 votes. National Republican groups were also mobilizing to defeat Mrs. Carnahan. But political analysts say the small-business federation played a crucial role, as it did in more than 30 other Congressional races in which it was active.
"Small business has gone from being a player to being the dominant player in the business community," said Dirk Van Dongen, president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors and a longtime lobbyist in Washington.
"The big-business guys are more pragmatic, giving a 60-40 split in money to the two parties," he said. "The small-business guys are much more ideological."
As a bitterly divided Congress moves into the decisive phase of battles over President Bush's $726 billion tax-cutting plan, the small-business political machinery is again playing a major role. When the president began a campaign last month on behalf of his plan, he invited more than 250 small-business owners and lobbyists to show their support in a Rose Garden ceremony. When Congress convened for spring break, small-business advocates were waiting in states like Maine and Ohio to influence lawmakers through advertising, meetings and organized events. And the federation is not alone in its activism. Many big lobbying groups that represent small companies pledged their support for Mr. Bush's plan before they knew what was in it. They did so partly on the conviction that any package of tax cuts would be good, but also on the expectation that support for the president's top priorities would mean far more support for their own agenda.
Many admit they were surprised that the biggest element of the plan was the president's proposal to eliminate taxes on stock dividends, a proposal that has no direct impact on most small companies, which are overwhelmingly privately held and do not pay dividends.
"I've been in tax lobbying for 20 years now, and I never spent more than five minutes thinking about dividend taxes," said Mr. Van Dongen.
In justifying their no-questions-asked support for the Bush plan, including the dividend tax cut, small-business lobbyists say that other features will provide a huge benefit to their clients.
Mr. Bush's proposal to accelerate the reduction of individual tax rates, they say, will affect hundreds of thousands of small companies that report their profits through the individual tax returns of their owners. That population includes sole proprietorships, from family grocery stores to local dry cleaners, as well as hundreds of thousands of so-called S corporations. "About 85 percent of our members pay the bulk of their taxes on their individual returns," said Daniel Danner, senior vice president responsible for federal programs at the National Federation of Independent Business. "Their personal return and their business return is one and the same."
The other major enticement for small businesses is a seemingly mundane proposal to triple the amount of money spent on new equipment that a small business can write off as an immediate expense against profits. The proposal, which is of huge interest to mom-and-pop companies that are buying, say, computers or cars or dry-cleaning equipment, would raise the amount to $75,000.
Beyond the immediate issue, however, groups like the National Federation of Independent Business have cultivated their reputations as movers and shakers with easy access to the top echelons of the White House and Congress. One such player is Jack Faris, president and chief executive of the National Federation of Independent Business. "You can rest assured that Andy Card will return his phone calls," said one veteran lobbyist, referring to Andrew H. Card Jr., President Bush's chief of staff.
Democrats, of course, try to woo the small-business vote. John Kerry, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts who is running for president, unveiled a plan last month for tax cuts specifically aimed at small companies. But the Democrats face an uphill fight. There is no question that Republican leaders are more closely aligned with the agenda being pushed by small-business lobbies, and that they listen closely to small-business complaints.
For instance, small-business groups were enraged by regulations imposed in the waning days of the Clinton administration that protected workers against physical problems like repetitive-stress injury from computer keyboards. They amassed a huge coalition that ranged from restaurateurs to courier services, all arguing that the so-called ergonomic requirements would impose major costs and risks to small companies.
Largely by invoking the mantra "small business," a phrase with vague but deeply sympathetic resonance among voters, the Bush administration and Congressional Republicans brushed off intense opposition by labor unions and rescinded most of the regulations.
"What small businesses want most of all is to be left alone," said Frank C. Fillmore Jr., founder of the Fillmore Group, a technology consulting firm in Ellicott City, Md., that has five employees.
That mantra dovetails with the Bush administration's agenda. But the two agendas are not the same, and some veteran lobbyists worry that small-business groups run the risk of being shortchanged.
The most immediate concern is about the tax plan. When the Senate adopted a budget resolution last month that limited the tax cut to $350 billion over 10 years, compared with $550 billion embraced by the House, it greatly increased the probability that part of Mr. Bush's plan would be scrapped.
The question is, which part? President Bush and his top economic team are passionately in favor of the dividend tax cut, which would cost more than $350 billion over 10 years. Small-business groups, on the other hand, are adamant about the expensing provisions and the individual rate reductions.
John S. Satagaj, president of the Small Business Legislative Council, an organization of small trade associations, said the support of small business groups for the entire plan and their appearance in the Rose Garden could undermine their own priorities. "Where our influence is greatest is in the perception that this is what small business wants," Mr. Satagaj said. "When they are in the Rose Garden and the dividend issue is front and center, the message gets out that this is what small business wants."
Small-business lobbyists have been jolted before. After campaigning for Mr. Bush's tax-cutting package in 2001, the groups were stunned when their beloved expensing provision was dropped during Congressional negotiations.
Mr. Van Dongen, who organized the Tax Relief Coalition, a lobbying group of 1,000 companies and others, before Mr. Bush even announced his newest plan, said the risk was worth taking. "There are no guarantees in this game," he said. "But if that fact causes you to pull your punches because you're afraid of losing, you have in effect negotiated yourself out of the game."

HEADLINE: GOTHAM; 
Yet Another Beginning On Heartbreak Street

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
THERE are some hardships that most small businesses face -- a crumbling economy, cranky customers, sluggish suppliers, errant employees, annoying accountants and, of course, the Internal Revenue Service.
 Then there are the problems that have afflicted a relatively small number of unlucky entrepreneurs, like losing their businesses because of terrorist attacks. That has happened to Olga Diaz -- twice. 
 Ms. Diaz is a hairdresser who owned a beauty salon in the Marriott Hotel in the World Trade Center. It was completely destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001. 
Her previous salon was on the 44th floor of Tower 1 in the trade center; terrorists bombed the parking garage of the complex in 1993. Though the damage from that attack was less physically devastating than the subsequent one, it was nearly as bad economically, Ms. Diaz said recently. For one, all her employees quit.
Now, located a block from ground zero, she has once again reopened Olga's Salon and Spa, using her innate persistence and new skills like applying for loans and grants.
"I was determined that no one was going to knock me down," she said. "Plus, what else was I going to do?"
While her case is extreme, Ms. Diaz's journey has been similar to those of hundreds of businesspeople in New York City who are still coping with the aftermath, financial and emotional, of Sept. 11. Indeed, the shock waves from the attack on the trade center are still being felt at small businesses nationwide, especially in industries like travel and tourism.
"Nationally, small businesses are generally cautious in today's business climate," said Marc M. Goloven, an economist with J. P. Morgan Chase, the Wall Street bank and securities company.
New York, he said, is not terribly different from the rest of the country, except that the local economy is still contracting. For example, the city's unemployment rate is still rising sharply -- it just hit 8.8 percent, while the national unemployment rate increased slightly to 6 percent in April, from 5.8 percent in March.
Among the city's small businesses, Mr. Goloven said, the hardest hit have been those that cater to travelers and tourists and financial workers like stockbrokers, banking managers and insurance executives. All of those people were Ms. Diaz's major clients and had been so since she went into business in 1984. Born in Puerto Rico, she studied fashion in New York but relied on cutting hair to feed her family.
After a stint working at a barbershop in the trade center, she bought the salon on the 44th floor. The place was bustling. "A bar and restaurant on the same floor drew a lot of customers, and they had to pass by me," she said. Many became clients, and she eventually had seven employees.
That changed after the 1993 bombing, which killed six people and injured more than 1,000. "It really created a big problem for me, financially and emotionally," Ms. Diaz said. 
Her employees, who had to walk down from the 44th floor in heavy smoke, were too traumatized to return to the salon. Tight security made it impossible for casual customers to walk in, and it discouraged even longtime clients.
Though the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey found Ms. Diaz a better location in the trade center, her lawyers missed a crucial lease deadline, she said, and in 1995 she ended up working out of her apartment.
Then, through a friend, she heard that the hotel, at 3 World Trade Center, might be willing to house a salon. After much persistence and phone calls, a $20,000 loan and all her credit cards, Ms. Diaz opened her salon there in 1996.
It was a tiny little corner, almost a closet, she said, adding that after her renovations, "A lot of people used to call it a jewel box."
Customers included hotel guests, workers from the two towers and people who came to the hotel for weddings and other events, she said. It was going well and everything was paid for, she added. Her only concern was whether the hotel would renew her lease.
Then, once again, terrorists struck, this time with more catastrophic results. None of Ms. Diaz's employees were killed, but many customers died, and she cannot talk of them without weeping.
When she heard of the early morning attack while visiting her mother in Florida, she said: "I went on my knees and I cried. I knew my clients didn't have a chance."
She lost not only her chairs, equipment and etched mirrors, but also her records, licenses and client lists. And she was displaced from her apartment for three months. (She lives in Battery Park City, near ground zero.)
"Despite everything," she said, "I started looking for a new place right away. I was on a mission to survive."
But finding a spot was hard and paying for it harder. Her insurance on the salon had lapsed while she looked for a new broker. The United States Small Business Administration turned down her loan application. (Fewer than half of those who applied were accepted.) 
She eventually got a $25,000 grant from Seedco, a nonprofit assistance corporation in Manhattan, and a small but critical loan from the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation. In August, she reopened her salon on the second floor of a building on Cortlandt Street near ground zero, in a space she found herself. 
For the most part, Ms. Diaz is back to worrying about the things small-business owners worry about: that the signs on her building are so cluttered that passers-by will not see hers; that competition from less expensive nail places will put more pressure on manicure prices; that the poor economy will prompt more customers to pinch pennies.
There are still lingering 9/11 issues. One is that the grants she and others received have been declared taxable. And, of course, there is the possibility that not enough people will return to the wounded streets of Lower Manhattan to make her business a go. But she is optimistic. "Little by little, people are coming back," she said. "I see this thing as a long-term situation. I keep high hopes."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 17, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Small Business section on May 6 about Olga Diaz, the owner of a beauty salon near ground zero, misstated the taxability of grants received by her and other small business owners after the Sept. 11 attacks. Those from state and local government agencies have been declared taxable. But grants to injured businesses from private foundations, like Seedco, a nonprofit organization that gave Ms. Diaz $25,000, are generally not taxable.
