HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
Young Blacks Try Entrepreneurship

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
THERE is little official evidence to go by, but the anecdotes are pouring in: across the country, more young black professionals are stepping off the corporate ladder to become entrepreneurs. Joining a big company used to be perceived as the surest route to material success by many black professionals, but lately, owning a business has become as attractive, or more so.
 Four years ago, Billye R. Hill was on the old track. With an M.B.A. from the Georgia Institute of Technology in hand, she joined the interactive marketing team at Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati. She loved her job, and thought she would stay for at least five years. But, she said, "I knew going in the door I wasn't meant to work for someone." 
 Soon, Ms. Hill founded a Web site design company as a sideline. As the economy began contracting, Procter & Gamble started offering buyouts to employees as part of a downsizing plan. Ms. Hill, who is now 27, saw an opportunity: she took a payment of about $25,000 -- enough to keep her afloat for several months -- and turned all her attention to her small business.
Ms. Hill's story is on its way to becoming commonplace in Cincinnati, said De Asa M. Brown, the chief executive of the Greater Cincinnati Northern Kentucky African American Chamber of Commerce. The area is home to a large black population and several Fortune 500 companies. Downsizing during the economic downturn, Ms. Brown said, gave people like Ms. Hill the impetus to strike out on their own.
"They had an opportunity to get a great buyout, which was the income they needed to launch their dream," she said.
In the past, the decision Ms. Hill made would have been more difficult, said Barbara B. Lang, the chief executive of the District of Columbia Chamber of Commerce. The new entrepreneurs are "willing to take risks that 10 years ago, 20 years ago, African-Americans were not willing to take," she said. "It's an absolute change in attitude, and not having to feel that the corporate structure is the only way -- or the safe way."
One factor supporting that change is increasing education. Starting a business is "just a natural extension of the career trajectory from getting a degree -- a law degree, an M.B.A., whatever," said Timothy Bates, a professor of urban and labor studies and economics at Wayne State University in Detroit, who has studied black entrepreneurship for more than three decades.
Education has also improved access to capital, long an obstacle for black entrepreneurs. Traditionally, they obtained financing from family, friends and local banks on the strength of their reputations, said Steven S. Rogers, a professor of entrepreneurship at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. But not anymore.
"What we're starting to see are more and more African-American entrepreneurs who have M.B.A.'s," Professor Rogers said. "Now, you're seeing a new generation of African-American entrepreneurs who are looking to access capital from all the available resources."
Professor Bates at Wayne State recently completed a study, with William D. Bradford, a professor of finance at the University of Washington, of venture capital firms that specialize in investing in minority-owned businesses. "The minority venture capital industry has grown over time," he said. "Probably in the 90's it increased about tenfold."
The study, financed by the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation in Kansas City, Mo., which promotes education and entrepreneurship, started with venture capital investments made from 1989 to 1995 and tracked them through 2000. Just more than half the investments yielded a positive return, and most of the venture capital funds made money. The foundation will release the study in its entirety later this month. 
In terms of rates of return, Professor Bates said, the minority-focused firms may be "slightly outperforming" the venture capital industry as a whole.
The census bureau also compiles statistics on minority-owned businesses, but it is just now preparing a survey for 2002. The latest figures, which compare 1997 to 1992, show that the number of black-owned companies rose by 26 percent in that period while businesses overall grew by only 7 percent. Looking more deeply at the data, Professor Bates said, reveals other promising trends.
"When you're looking solely at the top-end firms, you'll see that the growth rate is more than twice as high as it is for black businesses generally," he said. "That's been going for a while." 
Between 1992 and 1997, the numbers of relatively small service-oriented businesses like barbershops and beauty parlors barely increased. "The growing firms," Professor Bates said, "are the types of firms that are selling to corporate customers, government customers -- the types of firms that are competing in the broader marketplace."
And in his own study of companies receiving venture capital, he added, "when you look at the profile of the owners, you're looking at people coming out of elite jobs in corporate America."
In Washington, corporate America means big law and public relations firms, more so than Fortune 500 companies. "A lot of lawyers either leave and go into a single-practitioner, or go into industries very different from their law training," said Ms. Lang of the District of Columbia Chamber of Commerce. "The law degree is just a credential for them."
Given the current state of the economy, it is not surprising that some of the new entrepreneurs left their old jobs involuntarily. But the dislocation can act as an impetus to strike out on one's own, Professor Rogers said, especially among people who are looking to guarantee their families' futures. "There's a generation of people that are more into pursuing wealth creation now, rather than just saying, 'I was dissatisfied because of the glass ceiling.' "
Nevertheless, the weak economy has made the road to small-business success more difficult for the new cohort of black entrepreneurs.
Michael L. Hines, 29, started a small marketing firm four years ago while working for Golin/Harris International, a public relations division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, the marketing and communications giant. "I ended up making more money in that company than I did in my full time," he said.
Now, Mr. Hines employs five people at Onemarketspace.com, a market research firm in Washington. But his industry sustained some of the biggest losses outside of investment banking in the economic downturn of the last few years. "It's obviously just a slow market," he said, where making money has become extremely difficult.
Despite the economic constraints, Mr. Hines views entrepreneurship among young black professionals as a robust trend. "Most young African-American men I know are entrepreneurs," he said. "Some are doing significantly well, but we all seem to be doing at least as well as our counterparts in corporate America, even now, even here."
Ms. Lang said she still believed, however, that black entrepreneurs faced special obstacles: "While access to capital is better than it used to be, there are still issues. The playing field has not been completely leveled. It's better than it was 10 years ago, but it's not where it needs to be."

HEADLINE: SECOND ACTS; 
Three Who Lost Their Job But Gained a New Business

BYLINE:  By KAREN ALEXANDER 

 BODY:
JACK GOGUEN sits in his sunny Los Angeles backyard in blue jeans and talks with a palpable sense of detachment about his previous life as a sales and marketing executive.
 His new work, as a one-man company called J R Home Remodeling, leaves him little time to dwell on the frustrations that confounded him when he was laid off from his job in the airline catering business a month after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks sent his industry spiraling. Letting go was hard, but starting over has been a dream. 
 Meanwhile, in New York, Mary Arda, a former bond trader and media executive, has not bought herself even a new pair of socks in a year. She puts everything she has -- financially and emotionally -- into Mary's Off Jane Bakery, the shop she opened last June on Eighth Avenue near Jane Street. It has been much harder than Ms. Arda expected, but she gets goose bumps when she talks about what it means to have her own business among her neighbors in Greenwich Village. 
And in Silicon Valley, Mae-Ling Tien was laid off from her job as a programs manager for a dot-com three years ago. She moved into a new house, became pregnant with her first child and planned to stay at home.
At first Mrs. Tien, 33, was consumed by the demands of parenthood. But then something happened. Drawing on her experiences as a parent, she saw an opportunity and pounced. About six months ago, on her son Kyle's first birthday, Mrs. Tien opened Keiki Place, a play center for toddlers and their parents in Cupertino, Calif.
Like so many people who have lost their jobs in the current economic downturn, Mr. Goguen, Ms. Arda and Mrs. Tien had to rethink their lives before starting anew. They have had mixed results, but each one said that the entrepreneurial experience -- creating and operating their own small business -- has been an opportunity to learn. 
Laid off suddenly after 30 years in the business, Mr. Goguen, now 62, was certain he could be an asset to one of the companies in his industry, despite the downturn. "That I couldn't convince someone else of that was very disappointing," he said.
Mr. Goguen, whose wife is nine years younger than he is, was not ready to retire. He gave himself six months to look for a job in his field or start something new. The right job never came through. 
He asked himself, "What am I capable of doing well?" His father was a builder, and Mr. Goguen had always enjoyed the remodeling projects he did for himself. But despite the fact that he holds an M.B.A., he did not trust himself to make an objective assessment of his financial situation. He consulted a financial planner before declaring himself open for business.
Mr. Goguen spent about $20,000 on construction equipment and a sports utility vehicle for hauling it around. He contacted realtors and mortgage brokers in the community to spread the word about his work, and the floodgates opened. Next thing he knew, Mr. Goguen was bartering part of a kitchen renovation in exchange for legal services that would incorporate his new company. 
His friends were flabbergasted that Mr. Goguen would trade in his business suits and dress shoes for a life of physical labor, but he said he felt liberated. For him, the most important thing was understanding and dealing with his new reality. The well-meaning people who continued to tell him how great he had been as a sales executive were not helping.
"As quickly as you can, you must cease to dwell on the past regardless of how good you were or how much you enjoyed your work and accomplishments," he said.
Mr. Goguen said he had lost inches off his middle, spent more time outdoors and delighted in the people he has met on his jobs. And his business is doing better than he could have imagined. After one year, he is earning almost as much as he did as an executive. Although he hates the paperwork, he said it was deeply satisfying to know that his job was done according to his own standards.
"Companies say they want 100 percent customer satisfaction, but they don't mean it," Mr. Goguen said. "Profit motive always comes into play. A sole practitioner must perform every day in order to survive and grow."
FOR Ms. Arda, a Wall Street veteran, starting a bakery has been an endurance test. "It's a lot more difficult than I thought," she said. "I have a business that's open 17 to 20 hours a day, 7 days a week. Coming from the corporate world, I thought, business-wise, this is going to be a piece of cake. But this is a whole different world."
After she switched jobs, Ms. Arda worked for about a year as the director of sales and business development for the Web sites of Univision Communications, the Spanish-language media giant. She realized in mid-2001 that she would soon be laid off. Instead of asking, "Oh, my God, what am I going to do?" she started thinking, "Maybe this is my time."
Divorced and in her early 40's, Ms. Arda had dreamed of opening a bakery that reflected her Cuban upbringing. She had tried the food business before as a caterer and food stylist and, briefly, as a restaurant owner in Miami. None of the jobs worked out well. 
Starting over again "had been in the back of my mind forever and ever, but I was really afraid of taking the risk," she said.
But Ms. Arda said she felt pulled toward the bakery business. She looked for a new job halfheartedly, knowing there was very little out there. "I had been making a quarter of a million dollars and I realized that was not going to happen again in this economy," she said. 
Finally, a nephew suggested she stop talking about it and get moving. "For me it was a wake-up call," she said. Soon she started looking for a location.
Ms. Arda has poured most of her savings, about $200,000, into the business. She has traded in her $210 salon visits for bottles of $7.99 do-it-yourself hair dye. If her friends want to see her, they come to the bakery late at night with a bottle of wine. The hours are crushing, and Ms. Arda said that she was a victim of embezzlement, making her wary of delegating much responsibility to anyone else. "An employee took a lot of money from me," she said. "My books were manipulated, and now I'm doing everything myself. 
"I've been humbled a lot," she added. "I'm coming from a place where I've been able to treat myself well and now I'm struggling financially. I didn't expect it to be that drastic and it is."
If she had it to do over again, Ms. Arda said, she would look for a business partner. Even so, she said she did not regret the decision to open the bakery. "Even those moments when I'm really scattered and frustrated and handling so many aspects of this business, 95 percent of the time I'm really happy," she said. "I love my customers." 
Though she is barely breaking even, Ms. Arda is thinking about opening a second location. "Maybe I'm an optimist, but I really think I'm going to be able to make some money by running this business," she said. "Maybe I won't make a quarter of a million dollars a year, but I can make enough to be happy."
When Mae-Ling Tien opened Keiki Place (keiki means "child" in Hawaiian) in a long-empty building that her father owns, she was optimistic, too. Now she is trying to be more realistic. 
Her original business plan has made way for a more sharply focused road map for the play center, which Mrs. Tien hopes will enable her to do the thing she imagined when she dreamed up the concept: work while spending time with her son. 
"I wanted to make sure I created a business that revolved around my life, and not have my life revolving around it," she said. "But a few months into my business, I realized that's not the business I had."
Now, instead of offering several hours of "open play," when parents could drop by with their babies and pay Keiki Place $7.50 a visit, Mrs. Tien is shifting her emphasis to special events: birthday parties for $250 and classes and springtime egg hunts that can be more tightly scheduled. She is cutting back the hours her staff members work, and hopes to find a better work-family balance even while she tries to recoup the $100,000 of personal savings that she and her husband poured into fixing up the property.
Running a business "is just like parenthood," Mrs. Tien said. "You know it's a lot of work, but you don't realize how tough it is until you do it."

HEADLINE: WEST COAST; 
A Swath of Enterprise Where Feng Shui Fits

BYLINE:  By BRADEN PHILLIPS 

DATELINE: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif. 

 BODY:
THE address of Valley Springs Industrial Center in this enterprising pocket of Los Angeles County is 168 Mason Way, which means nothing to the English-speaking world, except perhaps those named Mason, and everything to the Chinese tenants who fill all but 2 of the 14 units.
 "We came here because we wanted a new look for the company and because in Chinese the numbers on the address mean the business will continue to grow," said Barbara Choi, the founder of the Cosmobeauti Lab, a cosmetics and personal-care products manufacturer. 
 Ms. Choi was sold on the property because it was recently built and because of the address, the work of a feng shui expert who had suggested changing the numbers from 200 to 168. The expert was hired by the non-Asian owners of Valley Springs as part of its marketing strategy. Nina Kraut, who manages the property for the owner, Mason Way L.L.C., said feng shui, an ancient Chinese design system, was "a sign of the times." 
The signs of the times are everywhere in this industrial park, from the 20-foot China Shipping cargo container awaiting pickup outside to the scent of jasmine incense burning at the shrine to prosperity inside Ms. Choi's office. And then there are the feng- shui-inspired fountains, two situated at each end of the industrial park, that create some aesthetic interest in what is otherwise a compound of identical warehouselike buildings.
Valley Springs Industrial Center reflects a growing number and diversity of small businesses owned by Asians, not only in the City of Industry, located 25 miles east of downtown Los Angeles, but in the region of the San Gabriel Valley as a whole. With the Cosmobeauti Lab, the park has computer, cellphone and automotive-parts distributors, a consumer electronics company, shipping and warehousing businesses, a food importer and a manufacturer of spray booths -- enclosed units used by auto-body shops for painting cars.
The City of Industry is a 13-mile stretch of enterprise that is home to 2,200 companies, most of them small, of which 550 are Chinese and 135 Hispanic. Last year, of the 288 new businesses that opened here, 64 percent were Chinese. Many of these newcomers are from Shanghai, or are ethnic Chinese from Hong Kong, Vietnam and Myanmar. According to the most recent census in 2000, the San Gabriel Valley has the largest concentration of Chinese in the country, at least a half million in a population of 1.8 million.
The trend has put the City of Industry on a must-see list for the Chinese government, which has been sending two to three trade delegations a month for the last four years to meet with the chamber of commerce, although the recent threat of the severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, epidemic has cut back on that pace.
Many of the current entrepreneurs are bringing capital and the skill to go with it, starting businesses that go beyond the mom-and-pop enterprises of first-generation immigrants. Some continued the businesses they had run in their former country; others took up the role traditionally played by immigrants, filling niches.
Among those who are trying to develop such a market is C. I. Tsui, who came here from Hong Kong to start USA Spec, which imports CD changers and satellite radio receivers for automobiles. In Hong Kong, Mr. Tsui sold other kinds of consumer electronics.
"We decided we wanted to do business here, so we had to come up with a product specifically for this market," he said.
THANKS mostly to this Chinese influx, the San Gabriel Valley is becoming a critical economic engine in the region, winning some of the attention that has always gone to better-known San Fernando Valley in Los Angeles County.
"These people are not only running the retail facilities but building the buildings, the outlets, the malls," said Vance Baugham, the San Gabriel Valley regional manager for the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation. "We probably have more assembly of computer-related equipment here than any place else in the world, and the Chinese community is a large participant in that."
The City of Industry is basically one large industrial park -- all of its 14 square miles are zoned for industrial and retail use. Valley Springs is one of eight self-contained developments in the city that fit the traditional description of such a park. The city eliminated residential zoning in 1957, but allowed people living there to stay.
Today the population has shrunk to fewer than 700. With easy access to highways and two rail lines, the area is convenient for shipping and receiving goods -- one reason so many Chinese businesses are moving here.
Another factor in its favor is cultural. Jane Gao, the office manager at Zhongda Group USA, the marketing and distribution arm of the China-based manufacturer of spray booths, said the company's first choice was the City of Industry because of the tenant mix and proximity to Chinese residential areas.
"The company was going to buy a warehouse in Riverside, but it's not convenient," she said. "Our first choice is a Chinese area. We feel more comfortable here."
Generally, however, the companies based here tend to keep to themselves, suggesting that the feeling of community is more psychological than anything else. Mr. Tsui of USA Spec said he did not socialize more frequently among Chinese tenants than he did in the previous industrial park, where he was the only Chinese tenant.
"Everybody is too busy," he said.
Given the warehouse atmosphere and the lack of amenities nearby, the closest thing to a meeting place is the stack of mailboxes at the park's entrance, adding a somewhat rural touch to daily life.
"When people get their mail they might bump into each other and talk," Mr. Tsui said.
Still, he readily let his neighbor, Raidtronics, a computer hardware distributor, use space in his warehouse. And Ms. Choi of Cosmobeauti Labs, which sells to other businesses, opens her doors to park neighbors who are looking for cosmetics or personal-care products.
But this is the City of Industry, so the real action is inside.
An average day at Cosmobeauti Labs revealed a range of activity: the resident chemist was trying to create a reasonable match for an existing whitening cream; another employee was mixing hair gel to fill a 400-pound vat; a third worker was squirting antiwrinkle cream into jars; and three more were applying labels to small containers of a lubricating gel.
Born in China, Ms. Choi has been in the United States for 28 years and has a bachelor's degree in marketing. She said her company made as many as 50 different products in a month, some her own and others for clients. At the moment, 60 percent of her business is in the United States and the rest is in Asia.
"Even when I'm resting or eating with my kids or talking on the phone with my friends, I am always thinking of new products," she said.
At Zhongda, which makes its spray booths in Yancheng, China, and ships them to 60 countries, the staff has its mind set on overcoming obstacles in the American market. After five years, sales are starting to improve.
"It's very hard for Chinese to develop this business here," said Jack Ge, the company's general sales manager. "If it's not high technology, they think it's a toy. But gradually people are accepting that such things are made in China and are good quality. We want to make Zhongda a name brand."
Mr. Tsui of USA Spec said his business was only fair these days. "We will do better when the overall economy gets better," he said.
Meanwhile, Ms. Choi's shrine burns bright. Like many of the Chinese business owners at this park, all of whom are now leasing, she wants to own her own building someday. "Every day we burn incense for the gods to look after us and make us prosper," she said.

HEADLINE: INSURANCE; 
Finding Ways to Afford the Safety Net

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
FOR years, the hassle of dealing with taxes has been the No. 1 problem for small businesses. But late last year the rising cost of insurance edged ahead as the biggest headache, ranked in national surveys before taxes, the sluggish economy and poor sales.
 Prices for insurance on offices, factories, stores, cars and workers' compensation have jumped sharply in the last several years, and the cost of health insurance has been rising relentlessly even longer. Now there is a new coverage to consider: insurance against terrorist attacks. 
 As a result, small-business owners are combing through their policies, looking for coverages that can be cut or eliminated to help lower costs. 
For years, prices were relatively stable, and reviewing coverages did not seem worth the trouble. But Dale Huffman, an Allstate agent in Orange, Calif., near Los Angeles, says that when he talks with small-business owners now, "They're always asking, 'How can you save me money?' "
It turns out there are several ways insurance costs can either be cut or -- more likely -- kept from rising drastically.
One frequently mentioned solution is to cut overall property coverage. But slicing off, say, 20 percent of the coverage on a $300,000 building in suburban New York would save less than $500 in premiums and leave an owner with a shortfall of $60,000 in case of a disastrous fire. Cutting coverage for liability lawsuits is not recommended either, because the added risk far outweighs the benefits. In some packages, for example, in which $2 million in liability coverage is standard, giving up $1 million in coverage saves only about $150 in premiums.
Insurance companies generally refuse to underinsure. A far better tactic, experts say, is to raise the deductible, thus making it possible to reduce premiums up to 30 percent in exchange for paying the first $10,000 in losses. 
Owners of small businesses can also cut costs by removing themselves from their company's workers' compensation coverage. The coverage is not mandatory for them, as it is for employees. If they are hurt, owners can pay themselves. Or they can substitute disability coverage, which is usually more costly but provides higher payments when an injury or death occurs. And some owners have been shifting more of the cost of health insurance to their employees, as well as reducing benefits. 
In a survey of small businesses, the National Federation of Independent Business, an advocacy group in Washington, found that about 34 percent of respondents increased the share their employees pay for health insurance; 30 percent increased their deductible amounts on all kinds of insurance; and 17 percent reduced or dropped some coverage on all kinds of insurance.
"The important thing is to strike the right balance," said Dick McKenna, an Allstate agent in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. "You're courting disaster if you take a bigger deductible than you can comfortably handle. And for big losses you want to be fully covered."
Small businesses are not regarded as prime targets for terrorists. In a survey by the Hartford Financial Services Group, 42 percent of respondents said they were more concerned about natural disasters like hurricanes and tornadoes; and 28 percent ranked terrorism as a main worry. But because the risk is slight, prices for terrorism coverage for small businesses are low, and many are buying it. In some cases, terrorism insurance can add as little as $50 to a small business's insurance bill, said Mike Hughes, a senior vice president in charge of coverage for small businesses at Safeco, the Seattle-based insurer.
Another way to lower premiums is through safety programs. In Los Angeles, Uni World Tensuke, a seafood company that is a unit of True World Foods of San Francisco, began paying bonuses to the drivers of its 27 trucks and cars for maintaining clean records. At the same time, it doubled its deductible to $1,000 and stopped filing claims for most damage under $2,000. Claims have fallen sharply, said MacKay Holmes, a senior manager at True World, and premiums for the fleet have dropped by roughly two-thirds, to about $40,000 a year.
Jerry Ghinelli, the owner of Total Media, a video and audiotape distributor in South Hackensack, N.J., has not been able to keep his premiums with the Hartford from rising. They have jumped 50 percent in three years to about $27,000 a year. But he figured they would be even higher if he did not pay so much attention to safety. 
Mr. Ghinelli said he paid his driver a monthly bonus for avoiding accidents and tickets. In the company's building, he has nonskid mats in the hallways, deadbolts on the doors, security cameras and an alarm system that sends a signal to his personal beeper. He regularly gets his fire extinguishers and lighted exit signs checked. In 13 years he has filed one claim -- for about $5,000 for two fake checks. 
"I'd rather not have to call my agent and say, 'Alan, I have a problem,' " Mr. Ghinelli said. "If I had a lot of claims, the premiums would go up more and they may drop you."
A business owner can often get away with underinsuring because insurance companies do not inspect every property. But the more an owner shaves off the top of the coverage, the greater the financial danger. In most states, if the insurance coverage falls below 80 percent of the value of the property, insurers are allowed to cut back proportionately on what they pay in claims. If a building is insured for $150,000, but its real value turns out to be $300,000, the insurer is required to pay only 50 percent of any claim. After discovering this kind of deception, Mr. McKenna said, the insurer will be unlikely to renew.
These days, even insuring for the full value can be a risk. Until a few years ago, a standard property policy paid for the replacement of a shop or a factory. If a shop was insured for, say, $300,000, and the rebuilding cost was $360,000, the insurance company would simply cover the cost. But as losses rose, insurers cut back. 
Now, if the owner of a photography shop in a brick building in, say, Manhassett, N.Y., bought $300,000 in coverage from Allstate for a premium of roughly $6,700, the payback in a total loss would be $300,000. If the reconstruction cost more, the owner would have to pay the difference. 
But for an extra $100 per $100,000 of coverage, or $300 for the photo shop, the money available for replacement would rise 25 percent to $375,000. On these policies, the basic insured amount automatically rises annually to match inflation in construction costs. The premium also rises.
Some of the steepest price increases have been for coverage of building contractors. Many insurers have dropped the coverage, saying they lose money on it. Those who still provide it have raised their prices. Big contractors, faced with higher insurance costs, have increased their deductible amounts and begun demanding higher coverages of subcontractors working for them. 
John Gregory, the president of Summit Tile and Marble, a company in Woodinville, Wash., with 10 employees, including Mr. Gregory and two other owners, said his company was forced to double its liability to $2 million. His insurance bill with Safeco jumped 40 percent to $10,000 this year, he said, even though he cut the company's auto insurance "to the bare minimum."
The three owners are considering dropping workers' compensation coverage for themselves. When they started 14 years ago, they went without that insurance, but Glenn Cooper, one partner, said they were hesitant to drop it. 
"When you start out," he said, "you have only a wife and maybe a kid. Now when you have a wife and maybe two or three kids, you've got a lot more responsibility. Hence, you need to take less risk. We're looking for some kind of alternative, something that would be less expensive."
Part of the reason insurance is such a concern for small businesses is that "you've got to have it," said William J. Dennis Jr., a senior research fellow at the National Federation of Independent Business Education Foundation.
"The alternative is to go bare," he said. "If you've got any kind of borrowed money, you can't do that because of the lenders. And if you have any kind of assets, you don't want to do that. Because of the economic situation, small businesses can't raise prices. So they end up eating the increased costs. All the alternatives are bad."

HEADLINE: Special Registration 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Pakistani, 18, Wins Fight Against Order to Leave U.S." (news article, April 30): 
 Mohammad Sarfaraz Hussain, a Queens high school student, is not the only registrant for whom the new policy of special registration makes "no sense," to use the characterization by Representative Gary L. Ackerman. 
At the Arab-American Family Support Center, we have seen many equally heart-rending cases. We have worked with many people for whom any other country would be a foreign land: They have grown up here, created roots here, and their hard work is contributing to the American economy. 
While its goal of catching terrorists is just, special registration has become a blunt instrument overturning the lives of scores of well-meaning individuals and their families. 
The many anonymous people whom we and others try to assist may likely not share the same lucky fate as Mr. Hussain.

JOHANNA HABIB
Brooklyn, May 1, 2003

The writer is staff attorney, Arab-American Family Support Center.

HEADLINE: THE ECONOMY; 
A Few Bright Spots, and Lots of Hanging On and Hunkering Down

BYLINE:  By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
HARRY DUNCAN is the president of a mortgage banking company in Sacramento. John Chua is the president of a company, also in Sacramento, that develops Web sites for the Internet. Iris Shokoff has a direct marketing media buying agency in New York. And Carolyn Brinkmeyer is a travel agent in Centennial, Colo.
 All are entrepreneurs. With fewer than 500 employees each, they operate companies that are considered small businesses, insofar as that term is defined by the United States Small Business Administration. 
 How are they doing? For Mr. Duncan, business is better than ever. Mr. Chua has chopped his work force by a quarter, but is hanging on. Ms. Shokoff is doing all right, as other companies' troubles produce bargains for her customers. Ms. Brinkmeyer is going out of business. With the exception of Mr. Duncan, every company is doing its best to cut costs and wait for the economy to rebound.
The state of small business, in other words, depends on the business. 
Given the sour economy, the health of a business nowadays is "all about sector and location," said William C. Dunkelberg, the chief economist of the National Federation of Independent Business, an advocacy group in Washington.
Mr. Dunkelberg, who conducts a monthly survey of small-business owners, said that lately there was a lot of pessimism among the companies polled. But he does not ascribe that to the companies' sizes, he said; in difficult times, smaller enterprises "suffer through the same kinds of problems as big businesses that are in the same field."
On the other hand, most small businesses are also service companies. These days, such companies are generally having an easier time than those in manufacturing, the sector that has been hardest hit in the downturn, Mr. Dunkelberg said.
Even in the service sector, however, the health of a business is shaped by broader economic forces, and what Mr. Dunkelberg calls the "subset of services" that a firm provides. 
In retail, store margins are in general being squeezed by fierce price competition. But some retailers are being hit harder than others, like merchants at airports, who are among those most drastically affected, said Randall S. Eisenberg, the chairman of the Turnaround Management Association, a trade group of bankruptcy professionals, and a senior managing director with FTI Consulting in New York. That is not just because of lower prices, he said, but because of another outside force: the precipitous drop in air travel.
Meanwhile, although a poor economy means that merger and acquisition lawyers may be in a slump, it also means that bankruptcy lawyers are doing quite well, said Leonard Z. Eppel, a turnaround specialist at Financial Resource Associates in Cincinnati. So are businesses that deal with residential real estate.
TAKE Vitek Mortgage Group, the company in Sacramento founded by Harry Duncan and a friend 16 years ago. Nowadays, Vitek's business is better than ever. It wrote $730 million worth of mortgages last year, according to Mr. Duncan, and grew from 75 employees to 110. This year, "we had the best first quarter ever," he said, even though he had been afraid that interest rates might rise and that the company's volume would go down.
"It just hasn't happened," he said.
For Carolyn Brinkmeyer, the travel agent in Colorado, the opposite is true. Although she concedes that hers has always been a tough industry, it has gotten infinitely worse during the five years she has operated her business, Serenity Travel. Between the rise of direct ticket sales by airlines, online ticket services and the dropoff in travel, "it felt like a constant battle," Ms. Brinkmeyer said. "When I calculated how many hours I was working versus what I was making, I thought I needed my head examined."
So, like thousands of other travel agents nationwide, she has given up. Earlier this year, she closed her business and is now only handling existing bookings.
Iris Shokoff's company, Iris Shokoff Associates, offers direct market media services to other businesses. Her customers include book and record clubs, a gourmet food business and Guthy-Renker, a telemarketer. Though "things are not necessarily fabulous," Ms. Shokoff said, she is predicting "a good year."
Her company negotiates for newspaper and magazine space and radio and television time for clients' advertisements, and it has benefited from a softness in media markets, especially among print outlets. "We can cut deals," she said. "Costs are less now than they were in the dot-com era, when prices were outrageous." 
But although the Internet bust has been advantageous to Ms. Shokoff, it has not done much for John Chua, the president of Digital Gear, a Web site development company. Most of Digital Gear's customers are "big to medium-size companies that are having challenges," Mr. Chua said. Because the main issue for these companies is cash flow, Mr. Chua said that he also had to become more flexible about pricing and payment.
The company, which began feeling the effects of the dot-com meltdown in 2001, has shrunk from about 20 full-time employees to 15, and it no longer uses expensive independent contractors. Instead, Mr. Chua said, he often hires temporary workers, who can be hired for less.
"We are very careful to watch expenses," he said.
If there is one common feature, after size, that most small businesses share today, it is a bunker mentality. If growth was the mantra in the 90's, prudence and restraint are the watchwords now.
"Small firms have to be more responsive and more nimble than ever," said Barbara Beck, the executive vice president of United States and Canadian operations for Manpower, the temporary-employment company. Her company provides interim staffing to numerous small businesses, Mr. Chua's among them.
Manpower also conducts a quarterly employment outlook survey, polling thousands of companies, big and small. Its most recent report indicated that in 8 of 10 categories, hiring intentions were softer for the current quarter than they were three months earlier.
Small companies, Ms. Beck said, are assessing their hiring needs more carefully than ever before, and that is unlikely to change soon.
That is a conclusion that dovetails with the results of small business surveys recently conducted by Mr. Dunkelberg. And it sounds pretty accurate to small-company owners like Mr. Chua.
"My feeling is that we will be all right in the end," Mr. Chua said. "We just need to hunker down for the next couple of years."

HEADLINE: VENTURE CAPITAL; 
Money for Start-Ups: Tight, Getting Tighter

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif. 

 BODY:
IN March 2000, it took only 10 days for Thomas E. Rowley, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur for more than two decades, to raise $27 million for Counterpane Internet Security, his eighth start-up company. Mr. Rowley's next round of financing was completed in January 2003 -- after eight months and 102 pitches that raised $20 million. 
 And most of his fellow entrepreneurs would consider him lucky. 
 "This is an awful time for companies looking to recapitalize," Mr. Rowley said. 
It is not that the boom times, when venture capitalists often avoided performing due diligence on companies in their rush to close deals, are gone. And it is not that entrepreneurs must once again show that they have proven business models, strong customer prospects and experienced management teams. That, after all, was how venture capital always worked, until the bubble. The big problem for new companies now is that even when they do everything right, there is precious little money to win.
The amount of money that venture capitalists have sunk into privately held technology companies has declined every quarter since the start of 2000, according to the MoneyTree survey, a study of venture capital investment activity compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers, Venture Economics and the National Venture Capital Association. The survey's figures for the most recent quarter, ending March 31, had the smallest number of venture capital deals, 623, since the summer quarter of 1996. 
Moreover, there has been one public stock offering for a venture capital-backed company since January, down from 262 for 2000, the MoneyTree survey reported.
Last August, Jonathan Abrams, a 33-year-old software engineer, began a start-up business, Friendster, an online dating and networking service. He said that he was "bootstrapping" the business, running it from his apartment in Sunnyvale, Calif. "I'm not even bothering to schmooze with venture capitalists right now," Mr. Abrams said.
Mr. Abrams is more fortunate than many technology entrepreneurs. He said that he was able to raise some money -- an amount he only said was less than $500,000 -- from friends and former colleagues. 
Raising capital from "angels," wealthy individuals who invest in start-up companies, has long been an avenue for brand-new technology businesses, but the competition for this financing has become tougher. Ian Sobieski, who coordinates the activities of one such Silicon Valley network, the Band of Angels, said that the group had always heard pitches from entrepreneurs who were turning an idea into a company. Lately, however, he said they were seeing more venture-backed technology businesses that have been around for a few years and need another round of financing, but cannot raise the full sum from venture capitalists. 
Many young companies, unable to raise money from angels or venture capitalists, are financing their dreams themselves. Their owners are taking the maximum on their credit cards, cashing out I.R.A.'s and acquiring second mortgages. A multimedia software designer at one Bay Area business, who asked not to be identified, was helping to support his two partners and paying for the lawyer to patent their work by spending all his time composing music for electronic games. 
In a big shift, many entrepreneurs here are turning to the government as a financing option. Workshops on obtaining government grants and contracts have become as common in Silicon Valley in 2003 as they were rare during the boom.
For those who find venture capital financing, the investments are smaller, and the venture capitalists expect that money to last years, not months.
Matt Glickman, the chief executive and a co-founder of Merced Systems in Redwood City, Calif., raised a first round of $3.5 million in venture capital financing at the end of 2001. As part of the pitch for the company, which sells software to monitor call centers, Mr. Glickman said he presented testimonials from two customers, including a division of the General Electric Company.
Since raising the money, Merced Systems has gone 17 months without seeking another round, quickly increasing its sales while pinching every penny. That was different a few years ago, when Mr. Glickman was running an online retailer, BabyCenter .com, which is now a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson. During the late 90's, BabyCenter raised new rounds of venture capital every nine months. "Merced Systems has to be focused on reaching sustainability," he said. 
There are still a few instances of the go-for-broke mentality. WildBlue, a communications company in Greenwood Village, Colo., which is trying to develop a system to deliver wireless broadband access to the Internet through new satellite technology, closed a $156 million round of financing last month. The deal included new investors, Intelsat and the National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative, in addition to previous investors -- Liberty Media Corporation and Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm. 
Although WildBlue raised more than $300 million before 2001, it had run out of cash one year later and suspended the development of its network. "We then spent all of our time tryingto raise money," said Thomas Moore, WildBlue's chief executive.
The company also had to wait for rivals to die. "It took two years to let that play through," said Russell Siegelman, a partner at Kleiner, Perkins who sits on WildBlue's board of directors. 
David Cowan, a partner at Bessemer Venture Partners in Menlo Park, Calif., said that in addition to new wireless technologies, he saw only a few other niches still attracting venture capital. One is computer network security, he said, which is why he invested in Mr. Rowley's company, Counterpane. Counterpane sells systems to monitor computer networks of businesses. 
But Mr. Cowan, who has invested in Counterpane's previous rounds of financing and is on its board, also took into account how Mr. Rowley and others on the company's executive team managed start-ups through hard economic times. "The prevailing metric now is capital efficiency," Mr. Cowan said. 
Howard Clowes, a lawyer at Gray Cary who handles venture capital deals, said he told first-time entrepreneurs not to bother venture capitalists until they hooked up with an experienced manager. 
Mr. Rowley said that such demands are a sign that the venture capital business was returning to normal. As a result, Counterpane was given a lower market value in its last round, he said, declining to specify the amount. Although that was painful to accept, he added that it was better than the alternative: no money at all.

HEADLINE: The Enigmatic Empire of the Vitamin King of Mexico 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH MALKIN

DATELINE: GUADALAJARA, Mexico 

 BODY:
As a child, Jorge Vergara Madrigal used to hang around the sets of the low-budget action films his uncle produced, featuring the Mexican classic wrestler superhero, El Santo. Mr. Vergara and his cousins helped with special effects, operating cars without drivers and concocting spider webs from glue. 
 To outsiders, there can be a similar blue-smoke-and-mirrors quality to Mr. Vergara's business empire -- full of bold coups and flashes, but highly unorthodox and hard to weigh. 
 At its center is Omnilife, which sells nutritional supplements through direct marketing in Latin America, Spain and the United States. The company is privately held and says little publicly about its finances, but it has clearly given Mr. Vergara ample resources for his forays into other fields. Film production, for instance: his production company's first feature, "Y Tu Mama Tambien," became an art house hit in 2002 and was nominated for a screenwriting Oscar. 
Then there was the $100 million he spent on a hostile takeover of one of Mexico's most popular soccer teams last November. And the huge development project that he hopes will draw millions of visitors each year to Guadalajara, a sprawling, leafy city that ranks as Mexico's second largest: Mr. Vergara has a dozen of the world's leading architects at work on the plans.
He first attracted attention in world financial circles when he opened talks to buy the British retail chain, the Body Shop. The discussions ended without a deal. 
Throughout his rise, Mr. Vergara, 48, has challenged Mexico's clubby business culture, centered in Mexico City and in the industrial area around Monterrey. Many of Mexico's leading executives run venerable companies built by their fathers and grandfathers and travel in narrow circles of wealth and privilege. Mr. Vergara, on the other hand, prefers the more bohemian company of designers and film directors, and mingles happily with his working-class sales representatives, firing them up with new-age self-help philosophy.
"I like to base myself on what you would call the principle of plenty," Mr. Vergara said in a lengthy interview in his glass-walled office. "If you generate plenty around you, and you share it, then you create a cycle of plenty, and money just follows you."
Omnilife sells its products through 1.2 million representatives in a multilevel marketing operation organized along lines similar to those of Herbalife or Amway. Of the $800 million of sales the company recorded in 2002, Mr. Vergara said that about two-thirds of total revenue was paid to sales representatives. 
"We reinvest 100 percent. That is why the numbers grow geometrically," Mr. Vergara said. 
Because it is not public, the company does not release any profit figures, nor does it publish audited financial statements. Mr. Vergara sees no need to do so. "I'm not interested if people believe me or not or if they understand me or not," he said.
At daylong rallies for the sales force, Mr. Vergara often speaks with evangelical fervor for hours, stopping only to call on representatives in the audience to stand up and give testimonials of new health and wealth. And Omnilife appears to reward those who get with the program: Feliciano Mendoza, who assembled a network of 150 part-time workers to sell for him in Mexico City, said he now makes $2,000 a month largely from commissions on their sales, a comfortable middle-class income in Mexico.
Mr. Vergara, who did not attend college, was himself a sales representative for Herbalife, the Inglewood, Calif., maker of nutritional supplements, before founding Omnilife with $10,000 in 1991. 
He describes his business mission in terms much grander than merely selling vitamins to the masses. "We integrate health, economic development and personal development," he said. "We think that success comes when you understand that money is a tool, and you have to prepare yourself personally to grow."
To those who have crossed business swords with him, Mr. Vergara's quick fortune and sweeping ambitions are cause for suspicion. "I think he is a shady man, and he does business in a shady way," said Francisco Cardenas, the former president of Chivas, the Guadalajara soccer team that Mr. Vergara bought.
Uncharacteristically for Mexico, where business deals are often struck with a handshake by old school friends, Mr. Vergara acquired Chivas out from under Mr. Cardenas by persuading about 150 of the 196 shareholders in the team, then a financially troubled nonprofit company, to sell to him. Mr. Cardenas is challenging the sale in court.
Mr. Vergara carries his self-improvement theme to all his projects, including his film production company, Anhelo Productions, which he founded with the Mexican director Alfonso Cuaron. Mr. Cuaron, who is directing the third "Harry Potter" film, was the director and screenwriter of "Y Tu Mama Tambien."
"Film is a great medium where we can make movies that help people to think, question and change," Mr. Vergara said. Made on a shoestring, "Y Tu Mama Tambien" has taken in $30 million.
"I reinvest and generate money for the next movie or for three movies, and those three will generate more, and so it multiplies, just like multilevel sales," he said. Anhelo and its Los Angeles offshoot, Monsoon Entertainment, have plans for 18 films. 
Mr. Vergara inspires strong loyalty in his staff and his circle. "He is one of those visionary people who is always three steps ahead," said Enrique Norten, a Mexico City architect who has played a networking role in Mr. Vergara's Guadalajara development project, connecting him with other architects.
Known as the JVC Culture, Convention and Business Center, the $670 million complex is intended to include a shopping mall, a university, a hotel, a theater, a children's museum and an art museum. 
Mr. Norten, who designed the project's convention center, helped line up names like Daniel Libeskind, Philip Johnson, and Jean Nouvel to handle other elements. 
"If I surround people with 11 architectonically balanced buildings of impressive beauty, then people will be attracted to come," Mr. Vergara said.
So far, though, the project consists of little more than a sheaf of drawings and an empty field. Mr. Vergara hopes to break ground by October, but there are still permits to obtain and parcels of land to acquire.
And it is not entirely clear where Mr. Vergara will get the financing. Asked about the arrangements, he said, "The money is very simple -- we put one part ourselves and the other part we get from selling the marketing rights." He gave no details. 
Mr. Vergara's grand plans do not always bear fruit. An example was his interest in Body Shop. One person briefed on the situation said Mr. Vergara proved unable to raise the capital for a bid. 
But Mr. Vergara said that financing was not the problem; he had $450 million in credit available at two banks. Rather, he said, he called off the bid when he concluded that Body Shop did not live up to its progressive image and its stated environmental and social ideals. 
"I don't make decisions based on numbers," he said.

HEADLINE: Italian Investor Is in Talks for Vespa Motor Scooters 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: PARIS, May 5 

 BODY:
The Italian investor Roberto Colaninno said today that he was making a bid for the unprofitable company that makes the Vespa, the perky little Italian motor scooter. But he tried to dispel speculation that his bid might be the opening move in a plan to consolidate the whole Italian two-wheel-vehicle industry. 
 Mr. Colaninno, 59, has had a considerable cash pile since an investor group led by Pirelli, the tire and cable maker, bought control of Telecom Italia from him in 2001. He had startled European markets two years earlier with his successful $30 billion hostile takeover of Telecom Italia, the country's dominant phone company. 
 Mr. Colaninno made headlines earlier this year by putting around the word that he might be interested in bidding for control of the Fiat industrial group. But the bid was spurned by the Agnelli family, which controls Fiat, leaving Mr. Colaninno to look for opportunities further afield. 
Mr. Colaninno's investment company, Immsi, informed the Italian stock exchange in Milan today that it was in talks to acquire a controlling stake in Piaggio, the company that makes the Vespa scooter. Piaggio is now controlled by Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, a unit of Deutsche Bank, which bought an 86 percent stake in 1999 for $753 million. At the same time, the Texas Pacific Group of Fort Worth acquired 10 percent of Piaggio. The remainder of Piaggio is now held by a Spanish equity fund, Mercapital-Rabasa. 
Details of Mr. Colaninno's bid today were not disclosed.
But at a meeting of Immsi shareholders, Mr. Colaninno, who is being advised by Lehman Brothers, said he hoped to conclude the deal by June, and that it would probably be achieved by having Piaggio issue new shares expressly for Immsi.
Italian newspapers have speculated that Mr. Colaninno's long-range design is to unite several manufacturers of two-wheel vehicles, perhaps including Ducati and Agusta, two domestic rivals.
In April, Texas Pacific, which controls Ducati, said in a statement that no talks were under way for its sale. An executive close to Texas Pacific said today that nothing had changed and that Mr. Colaninno denied he had such plans.
Christopher Spira, a Ducati spokesman in Bologna, said, "We are basically finding out in the newspapers what Colaninno is planning." 
Texas Pacific took control of Ducati Motor Holding, the icon of Italian motorcycle making, in 1996 and brought in new management to overhaul the company, modernize its factories and rebuild its line of powerful motorcycles. 
Piaggio bought a 20 percent stake in Agusta, which makes Husqvarna motorcycles, in 2001. In the late 1990's, the market for two-wheel vehicles was booming, most notably in Europe, and both Ducati and Piaggio thrived, though with very different products. But the downturn in the industry since 2001 has been harsh. 
Piaggio, to be sure, has had some successes. Its entry into the United States market, never known for embracing scooters like the Vespa, has been relatively fruitful.
Last year, Piaggio sold 5,000 Vespas in America, and it hopes for 7,000 this year. 
But over all, the company has flagged. Global sales of Piaggio's scooters contracted by 10 percent in 2002, to 360,000 units. Revenue slipped just 4 percent, to 950 million euros ($1.1 billion), in part because of a shift to higher-priced scooters like Piaggio's new Granturismo, a reproduction of the original Vespa. 
Stiff competition from Japanese rivals like Honda and Yamaha and the high cost of servicing its heavy debts have pushed Piaggio into the red. The company has not released profit and loss figures for recent years, but Mr. Colaninno said Piaggio had been unprofitable in both 2001 and 2002. 
Texas Pacific had consolidation in mind in 1999 when it bid for all of Piaggio. The plan then was to create a group covering the whole range of two-wheel motorized vehicles from tiny 50-cc Vespa scooters to Ducati's huge motorbikes. 
Piaggio, which is based in Pontedera, Italy, near Pisa, made aircraft engines until 1946, when it introduced the Vespa (the name means wasp) as an economical way for Italians to get around in a country just emerging from wartime destruction and fuel shortages.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Fort Lauderdale; 
Booming Economy With a Resort Feel

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is home to a growing number of small businesses and technology start-ups and is a popular center for business conferences. Shipping and tourism are flourishing, and the real estate market, driven in part by foreign investment in high-end coastal property, is booming.
 Yet for all the economic activity, the city retains its old seaside resort feel. Downtown, Las Olas Boulevard stirs early in the morning when sprinklers snap on to mist the flowers and shrubs. A little before 8 a.m. in the GRAN FORNO bakery (954-467-2244), workers in white T-shirts shovel flour-dusted loaves of dough into ovens by the window. Not far away, chairs scrape the sidewalk under the tricolor awnings of LE CAFE DE PARIS as waiters prepare for the brunch crowd. 
 At the FLORIDIAN DINER, known to patrons as the Flo, the regulars drift in, some to grab a bite and trade gossip before heading off to the courthouse or the offices nearby, others to cap off a night of partying before heading home to bed. Hunched over a table up front, while a technician checks the microphones, a local talk-radio host, Norm Kent, glances over some notes to get ready for the show he broadcasts every weekday morning from 8 to 9. "Everybody has breakfast here," said Mr. Kent, a local lawyer and publisher of a gay and lesbian newspaper. "I'm never going back to the studio."

AIRPORT
FORT LAUDERDALE-HOLLYWOOD INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT was once derided as a glorified bus station, but after extensive renovations it is a spacious airport with modern concourses lined with shops. There are shuttle buses downtown and to the beach. The taxi fare downtown is about $15.

HOTELS
Built in the 1930's as a small-town resort to house people for deep-sea fishing excursions, the RIVERSIDE HOTEL (954-467-0671, $150 to $600) has 217 rooms and suites, many in a new tower. Popular for business conferences, it has a private wine room for corporate dinners, two restaurants, one of which spills out into a sidewalk cafe, and a busy piano bar. "The Flo is the heart of Las Olas in the morning, and the Riverside is at night," Mr. Kent said.
You can walk eastward on Las Olas to trendy Ocean Boulevard, which is Fort Lauderdale's version of Miami's South Beach, without the haughty attitude and price gouging. Joggers and in-line skaters have miles of paths to use by the ocean. Among dozens of beach-area hotels are the PIER POINTE RESORT (954-776-5121, $60 to $169), set back amid tropical gardens.
The HYATT REGENCY PIER 66 (954-525-6666, $185 to $279) sits beside a yacht marina on a causeway, has 380 rooms and 8 suites amid 22 acres of gardens and cascading fountains. There is a full-service spa and aquatic center, as well as 22,000 square feet of corporate meeting space.

RESTAURANTS
Near the airport, ANTHONY'S RUNWAY 84 (954-467-8484, $160 for dinner for two with wine and tip) "is where you take somebody who's in town from New York or L.A.," said Sam Velez, the fitness director of the Firm, a fitness club.
Mr. Kent, the radio talk-show host, swears by the Floridian for breakfast and lunch (954-463-4041, $10 to $12 a person), though Las Olas is lined with enticing bistros. "More business deals are consummated at the Floridian over breakfast or lunch than in any law office in town," he said. For dinner, he recommends JACKSON'S STEAKHOUSE (954-522-4450, $110) or either of the two restaurants at the RIVERSIDE HOTEL (954-467-0671) -- the GRILL ROOM ($100), which features steaks and chops, or INDIGO ($75), with its Indonesian-inspired cuisine. Locals also like the BLACK ORCHID CAFE (954-561-9398, $85) on Ocean Boulevard and LE CAFE DE PARIS (954-467-2900, $70) downtown on Las Olas.
At the GOLDEN LYON piano bar in the Riverside Hotel one recent night, the pianist, Dr. Robert M. Campos, a physician who moonlights as a musician so he can play Gershwin and popular tunes from the 1940's and 50's, confided that his family in Montreal nearly disowned him when he took his first piano-playing job at a Montreal brothel to help support himself in medical school. "I just like to do my job and play the piano a little," he said. "In Fort Lauderdale, I can do both without causing comment."

LOCAL LORE
Once-sleepy Fort Lauderdale burst on the cultural map in the 1960's, as jet air travel enticed college students for spring-break revelry celebrated in such movies as "Where the Boys Are," starring Connie Francis. The partying peaked in 1985, when 350,000 students descended on the resort, and then declined sharply as local officials clamped down on the general mayhem. Though the town has a vibrant nightclub life, said one restaurateur, "Now the spring breakers all go to Cancun or Fort Myers, bless them."

PERSON: Suzy Parker 

HEADLINE: Suzy Parker, Willowy Model And Actress of 50's, Dies at 69 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Suzy Parker, the willowy, red-headed beauty whose elegant poses on scores of magazine covers defined glamour in the 1950's and paved the way for the supermodels to follow, died on Saturday at her home in Montecito, Calif. She was 69.
 Her husband, the actor Bradford Dillman, said she had suffered from a number of serious ailments over the last six years. 
 In the period just after World War II, models were becoming celebrities. Fashion's influence was inexorably expanding from high society to society at large, and Suzy Parker, along with other models like Dovima and Lisa Fonssagrives, signified a postwar world of stylish promise for all. When Miss Parker posed in one of fashion's first bikini shots, America noticed. 
Miss Parker was the first model to make more than $100 an hour and $100,000 a year, said Eileen Ford, the doyenne of modeling agents. She also worked as a professional photographer and editor, and she appeared in lead roles in movies with Cary Grant and Gary Cooper.
Ms. Ford said she was simply staggered when the famed model Dorian Leigh, Miss Parker's oldest sister, introduced her to Suzy, then 15.
"She was the most beautiful creature you can imagine," Ms. Ford said. "She was everybody's everything."
Miss Parker's trademark in photographs and later on the movie screen was icy sophistication, often likened to that of Grace Kelly, but in person she exuded a girl-next-door prettiness and a sort of wacky loquaciousness. Audrey Hepburn's role in "Funny Face," as a fast-talking beatnik who somewhat unwillingly becomes a world-famous model, was inspired by her, and she made a cameo appearance in the film, her first movie role.
Miss Parker adored slouch hats of the sort favored by Garbo and collected Coco Chanel's classic designs for herself. Richard Avedon, the photographer, called her "my most challenging and complicated of muses."
Cecilia Ann Renee Parker was born in San Antonio on Oct. 28, 1933. While still in high school in Jacksonville, Fla., she modeled in the summers for Ford Models, and after graduation went to work full time for the agency. In a silent profession Miss Parker was outspoken.
"Suzy Parker didn't stop talking when I first tried to take her picture," Horst, the photographer, said. "I said, 'You keep talking,' and I left. When she got into the movies, I joked that maybe she would do for the movies what she would never do for me -- hold still."
She publicly condemned drinking and smoking and said marriage killed romance. The New York Daily News reported her lecturing a French economist about the French economy. She said she talked too much for most men.
Her often-quoted remark that she could love a man more when she was not married to him exploded in headlines when it turned out she was secretly married. 
That marriage, to Pierre de la Salle in 1958, was actually her second; she had been briefly married to a high school sweetheart. She and Mr. de la Salle, from whom she was later divorced, had a daughter, Georgia, of Paris, who survives her.
In 1963 she married Mr. Dillman, who survives her, along with their daughter, Dinah Kaufman of Irvine, Calif.; their sons Charles, of Los Angeles, and Christopher, of Encinitas, Calif.; and four grandchildren.
Her sisters Dorian Leigh of Paris and Florian Boice of Annapolis, Md., also survive her.
Miss Parker said she looked in the mirror each day and thanked God for her cheekbones. But she insisted that she modeled only for money and had other professional ambitions. In the mid-1950's she temporarily abandoned being a cover girl for several years to be a photographer herself, apprenticing with Henri Cartier-Bresson in Paris and working for the French edition of Vogue.
It was through Mr. Avedon that Miss Parker parlayed her modeling fame into a movie career. As visual consultant in the movie "Funny Face," Mr. Avedon selected her for a brief but conspicuous appearance. Written by Leonard Gershe and directed by Stanley Donen, the 1957 film depicted a high-fashion photographer not unlike Mr. Avedon, played by Fred Astaire. Miss Parker was the inspiration for Audrey Hepburn's character in the film, a somewhat kooky intellectual and free spirit.
Hepburn, in turn, became such a cheerleader that Miss Parker called the actress her "Hollywood press agent."
Miss Parker was cast opposite Cary Grant in "Kiss Them for Me" in 1957, getting bad reviews. She appeared with Gary Cooper the next year in "Ten North Frederick." This time, Bosley Crowther in The New York Times said she underplayed her part "neatly."
She appeared in 1959 in "The Best of Everything," based on Rona Jaffe's novel. In 1961 she played opposite Mr. Dillman in "A Circle of Deception." They wed in 1963. 
Miss Parker was in several more movies and became a sought-after television guest in the 1960's. Her most famous television appearance was in a 1963 episode of "Twilight Zone" in which she played six different parts.
She retired from acting in the mid-1960's and moved with Mr. Dillman to the Santa Barbara area. 
In his book "Cover Girls and Supermodels, 1945-1965" (Marion Boyars, 1996), the French journalist Jean-Noel Liaut said Miss Parker had escaped the unhappy outcomes of other stellar models.
He wrote, "She became a perfect housewife, even to the extent of baking her own bread."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS; 
Drop in Foreign Investment Is Greasing Dollar's Slide

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar continued its slide against the euro and the yen yesterday, as new data indicated that the foreign appetite for United States stocks and bonds was slowing.
 Recent data from the Treasury showed that net purchases of United States stocks and bonds by foreigners slowed to $23.8 billion in February, the third consecutive monthly drop in foreign purchases. The decline in February was 31.2 percent. It came after an 8.1 percent decline in January and a 46.1 percent fall in December, when the dollar's current slide began. 
 "The dollar is suffering from a two-prong situation," said David Puth, global head of foreign exchange and commodities at J. P. Morgan.
First, he said, the United States' current account deficit has grown to about $500 billion with the rest of the world, and the flow of investment from abroad has to continue to cover that gap. So the slowing of that flow hurts the dollar. (The current account deficit includes profits on investments as well as trade in goods and services.)
Second, interest rates in the United States are low, and higher yields abroad are attracting investors away from the dollar. "We are a world searching for yield," Mr. Puth said, which is taking investors to higher-yielding currencies, including the Canadian dollar, the South African rand, the Australian dollar and the euro.
If Federal Reserve policy makers, who are meeting today, reduce the federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks, which is now 1.25 percent, that could put further downward pressure on the dollar. The consensus among Wall Street experts, however, is that the Fed will leave the rate unchanged.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the euro was valued at $1.1280, up from $1.1231 on Friday. The dollar traded at 118.63 yen, down from 118.93 on Friday.
Ashraf Laidi, chief currency analyst at the MG Financial Group, noted that the three-month slowdown in foreign purchases of American stocks and bonds was the first since November 2001 though January 2002, after 9/11. This is good evidence, he said, that "global investors are putting money into other currencies because of the higher yield."
After the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the dollar fell at first but then rose at the end of the year as the stock market rallied sharply. The main difference from then and now is that American interest rates were rising at the end of 2001 and were higher than they currently are, helping make the dollar a more attractive investment.
United States interest rates are now below those offered by many foreign countries except Japan.
In 2001, the yield on the two-year Treasury note rose to 3.23 percent near the end of the year from 2.30 percent in November while the yield on the 10-year note rose to a high of 5.20 percent from 4.18 percent. The yield on the two-year note has fallen close to 1.5 percent now, while the yield on the 10-year note is hovering just below 4 percent.
The yield is 4.61 percent on an Australian two-year note, while the yield in Germany is 2.40 percent. The two-year yield is 3.69 percent in Canada and 11 percent in South Africa.
Many forecasters are expecting the drop of the dollar to continue, partly because they expect the economic rebound in the United States to be modest at best. But J. P. Morgan expects a nice dollar rally in the summer because its forecasters expect the pace of economic growth to pick up to a 4 percent annual pace in the third quarter, from 1.5 percent in this second. This would push the euro down to about $1.08 and the dollar up to about 123 yen. But because growth will slow a little toward the end of the year, the dollar will fall again, finishing the year around where it is now, J. P. Morgan said.

HEADLINE: Teachers' Union Sues Klein, Claiming Bias in Layoffs of Aides 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The union representing New York City teachers sued Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday, accusing him of racial discrimination and saying his plan to lay off nearly 1,000 classroom aides disproportionately affected black and Hispanic workers. 
 Randi Weingarten, the union president, said the layoffs were "an unconscionable choice" because two-thirds of classroom aides, known as paraprofessionals, were black and Hispanic, and because they were among the school system's lowest-paid employees. The 17,000 paraprofessionals are paid an average of $23,000 a year, she said. 
 The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in the Bronx, seeks to block the Education Department's plan to send pink slips to 864 paraprofessionals. It questions why Mr. Klein would lay off paraprofessionals just as he is creating more than 130 supervisory jobs as part of his reorganization of the school system. 
Most of those hired as supervisors are white and earn six-figure salaries, according to the lawsuit. They include 10 regional superintendents who are replacing district superintendents, their deputies, 108 instructional supervisors and 6 regional operations managers. Mr. Klein has insisted that the reorganization is needed to tame the bureaucracy.
The paraprofessional layoffs are supposed to save at least $22 million, while the reorganization will cost $250 million over two years.
"The fact that two-thirds of our paras are black and Latino and that the executives who have just been hired are not makes this a clear violation of the state's and the city's human rights laws," Ms. Weingarten said at a news conference at the Manhattan headquarters of the union, the United Federation of Teachers. 
Mr. Klein's office referred inquiries about the lawsuit to Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott, who predicted that it would have no standing in court. "It's unfair and really quite sad that they are injecting race and discrimination into the conversation," Mr. Walcott said. "Discrimination is something this administration will never practice."
After Ms. Weingarten's news conference, she received a memo from the Education Department saying the layoffs would go into effect on June 16. She said Mr. Klein had assured her before that they would not take effect until after the school year ends on June 26.
Paraprofessionals have been a fixture in the schools since the 1970's, when the position was created in response to pressure from minority residents who wanted more control over local schools. It was hoped that many paraprofessionals would become teachers, diversifying the overwhelmingly white teaching force.
While 7,000 paraprofessionals have become teachers, the teaching force is now 62 percent white and only 21 percent black, 14 percent Hispanic and 3 percent Asian.
Paraprofessionals are also more likely than teachers to live near the schools where they work, which Bertha Lewis, the executive director of New York Acorn, a community advocacy group, said was another reason not to lay them off.
"The laying off of these black and brown women who spend their money in the neighborhoods and live in the neighborhoods is tantamount to writing off low-income black and brown students in our school system," she said at the news conference.
The paraprofessionals who are to be laid off include 194 of the 4,000 who work in elementary and middle schools and 670 of the 900 who work in high schools. Most of these paraprofessionals work in a single classroom or divide their time among several, helping the teacher by working with small groups of students who need extra attention.
The school system also employs about 11,000 special education paraprofessionals, who work solely with disabled students. Those paraprofessionals cannot belaid off, because their numbers are regulated by a 1980 court decree. 
Chancellor Klein also intends to lay off about 1,400 school aides, most of whom work part time in lunchrooms or school offices or as hallway and playground monitors. Those aides are represented by another union, District Council 37. 
All the layoffs are part of $178 million in cuts that Mr. Klein says he must make to the school system's $12.4 billion budget to help address the city's $3.9 billion budget gap.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asked the city's labor unions for $600 million in productivity savings to avert layoffs and other cuts, but he rejected the unions' offer. 
Many paraprofessionals work in overcrowded classrooms, where parent and student advocates say their presence would be most acutely missed. Their numbers are always shifting, since paraprofessionals are among the first to be laid off during budget crises and hired during flush economic times. 
This would be the largest layoff of paraprofessionals since at least 1991, school officials said.
