HEADLINE: Filming the Dark Side Of Capitalism in China 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 6 

 BODY:
Li Yang has spent most of the past decade and a half in self-imposed exile in Germany, and it must have been there, certainly not in the unadventurous filmmaking climate of today's China, that he decided to treat compromise as a dirty word.
 His first feature film, "Blind Shaft," spares nobody in its devastating portrait of murderous grifters in the poor coal mining region of northwest China. It skewers mine owners, who returned the favor by hounding him with security agents and threatening him at gunpoint when he filmed on location. 
 It jabs at the hypocrisy of the Communist government with thinly veiled barbs, ensuring that the film will enrage Chinese censors. 
"Blind Shaft," which is being shown at the TriBeCa Film Festival Wednesday and Thursday, will probably never make it beyond art houses in the West and will certainly not be released in China. But the film offers an unleavened look at the underside of Chinese-style capitalism that was previously available only in print.
"Many of the films made in China today are like government press conferences: they do not reveal anything about the real situation," Mr. Li said in an interview here on Monday. "People compromise a little to get a license, and compromise a little to get an audience, and before too long there isn't much left."
His film, adapted from the novel "Sacred Wood" by Liu Qingbang, is a psychological thriller that does not claim to be based on real incidents. But it is based on the misanthropic culture of China's coal mining industry, where death is so prosaic that it loses its power to shock. By official count more than 5,000 miners die every year in explosions, shaft collapses and floods. Many more deaths go unreported by private mine owners who operate without proper licenses or safety equipment.
Mr. Li, 43, said the setting struck him as an ideal metaphor for what he viewed as the loss of values in today's China. He left his country in 1987 to study in Germany and was trained in Cologne as a documentary filmmaker. On his return trips, he said, he was impressed by the rapid pace of economic growth but dismayed by what he saw as China's increasing inhumanity.
"Some people now have mafia values," he said. "They can't find a normal way to make money. Violence pays."
Mr. Li's shaggy hair and provocative speech are not out of place in Beijing, which has an irreverent side despite the heavy hand of the government. He studied here and considers it a second home. But he is also a misfit. He said he had grown uncomfortable with the spread of bourgeois values among the city's once thriving counterculture. For example, he said, city dwellers benefiting from the new economy tend to look down on the migrant workers from the countryside who clean their homes and serve their food.
"Blind Shaft" portrays the cutthroat culture of an anonymous mining town, where what limited wealth there is goes to those who treat death with the greatest detachment. 
The film opens as two itinerant swindlers, Song Jinming (Li Yixiang) and Tang Zhaoyang (Wang Shuangbao) lure a hapless fellow migrant, whom they persuade to pretend that he is Tang's brother, to join them for a gig at an illegal mine. In a darkened shaft they beat him to death and then stage a roof collapse to make the killing look like a routine accident.
The dark brilliance of the murder is quickly apparent when the mine owner schemes to avoid an investigation. After Tang fakes an emotional reaction to the supposed loss of his brother, the owner comes up with a $4,000 death payment and gives it to Tang and Song, no questions asked, provided the two leave town without demanding an official inquiry.
At a local labor market Tang and Song spot their next target, a 16-year-old, doe-eyed boy named Yuan Fengming (Wang Baoqiang). While seeking employment, they pretend that he is Song's nephew.
As they negotiate their next grift, a portly mine owner warns them caustically that safety is their own responsibility. "China lacks everything," the mine owner says. "The only thing it doesn't lack is people." He takes them on but demands that they work for a period without pay or death benefits until they prove themselves worthy.
Much of the film details the three men's interactions as they work together during this trial period, with Tang, Song and Yuan acting like a family of a sort. The older men even take Yuan to the local whorehouse out of a warped filial sense that they should make him a man before they kill him. All this plays on Tang's and Song's emotions, however hardened, and sets up a twist at the end.
The film was shot in dusty mining towns in Hebei and Shanxi provinces. The cast and crew were frequently forced to move when mine owners threatened them to avoid exposure, Mr. Li said. Most of the actors are first-time performers, recruited locally.
Mr. Li has succeeded in making a movie that provides an uncompromising look at China's social problems, though he has paid a price. Unless the film is widely pirated, very few mainland Chinese will see it. "It's a huge regret," he said. "But the fact is that you can't make a real movie about China if you worry too much about whether it will be seen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Chinese director Li Yang, holding awards his mining drama "Blind Shaft" won in March at the Deauville Asian Film Festival in France. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Savoring the Chemistry Of Southern Cooking 

BYLINE:  By ALEX WITCHEL 

DATELINE: DECATUR, Ga. 

 BODY:
IT was in 1990 that Scott Peacock, the 27-year-old chef at the governor's mansion in Georgia, went to meet Edna Lewis, the 74-year-old doyenne of Southern cuisine, at an Atlanta train station. She was to cook at a fund-raising dinner for the American Institute of Food and Wine, and he was assigned to help her. There she was, on the platform, dragging a huge cardboard box by a rope. She knew she wouldn't have time to do things properly, so she had brought what she needed: 100 pounds of pie dough, packed in ice.
 As they began their work together, neither realized that they were embarking on one of the most unusual, yet enduring relationships ever forged in a kitchen. On the professional side is their new cookbook, "The Gift of Southern Cooking: Recipes and Revelations From Two Great American Cooks" (Alfred A. Knopf, $29.95). But it is the personal side that is most compelling. During the seven years in which they wrote the book, their friendship deepened and they moved in together here four years ago, to a quiet garden apartment. 
 During the last year, however, Miss Lewis, now 87, has become increasingly forgetful and confused. After living a bohemian life -- married briefly, she had no children, traveled extensively, never lived in one place for too long -- she had no home base. Mr. Peacock, now 40, single, and the acclaimed chef at Watershed, a restaurant in Decatur, an Atlanta suburb, has assumed responsibility for her care. This gay white man and this elderly African-American woman have forged a genuine family, with a devotion too rarely seen among blood relations.
"Would you like something to drink, Miss Lewis?" Mr. Peacock asked as he sat beside her on the couch in their tiny living room last week. It was an unexpectedly hot afternoon, and the air-conditioning was most temperamental. She shook her head and smiled. Though she calls him Scott, he still calls her Miss Lewis, though he says that "Edna Mae" and "Old Woman" are alternatives. Miss Lewis has always made an elegant appearance and she was perfectly turned out, as usual, in a batik dress of her own design and her trademark dangling earrings. Her smile was warm, though she didn't participate much in the conversation. Sometimes she seemed to listen, more often she just seemed preoccupied, looking in another direction, thinking other thoughts.
If she was reflecting on days gone by, she had plenty of material. She was born in 1916 in Freetown, Va., a community established by former slaves, one of them her grandfather. She moved to New York City, where she ironed shirts, dressed windows at Bonwit Teller and in the late 1940's became the chef and a partner at Cafe Nicholson, a restaurant on East 58th Street. She was an unapologetic member of the Communist Party, wrote three cookbooks before her collaboration with Mr. Peacock and was the chef at Gage & Tollner in Brooklyn. Although her ingredients of choice included buttermilk and lard, she became just as celebrated as more worldly chefs; in 1999 she was named Grande Dame of Les Dames d'Escoffier International. And on Monday, she was inducted into the James Beard Foundation's Cookbook Hall of Fame.
Miss Lewis doesn't cook much these days, although she does go three times a week to a program for seniors, where she helps serve them food. And, Mr. Peacock noted, she shelled the peas for the soup he made for lunch that day. 
"I guess there are a lot of obvious differences between us," Mr. Peacock said, looking at Miss Lewis fondly. "But there's a lot alike, too. We're both loners and we're both basically shy. We've both struggled with depression and we're both Southern, though being from Hartford, Ala., I didn't realize Virginia was even in the South.
"I lived alone for 15 years before this," he continued. "But we definitely wanted to be together."
Mr. Peacock has been the chef at Watershed since 1998. Before that he made a name for himself at the Horseradish Grill in Atlanta, having left the governor's mansion in 1991 after two administrations. Full of the fervor Miss Lewis instilled in him for the rich heritage of Southern regional cooking, he once prepared a dinner at the mansion of grilled veal chops served over grits cooked with cream and veal stock. Governor Zell Miller's wife, Shirley, was horrified by the idea of serving such lowdown food to company, Mr. Peacock said, and made him switch to mashed potatoes.
"I never had the courage to walk away from the governor's mansion," he said. "But when the state was faced with huge budget cuts and layoffs, it was great press for the governor to give up his chef."
He didn't find work for a full year, though Miss Lewis was unwavering in her support. Their friendship grew slowly, through notes and phone calls. "In the beginning, of course, I was in awe," he said. "I was smitten. And a mutual friend told me, 'Miss Lewis is smitten with you, too.' " At that moment, Miss Lewis looked straight at Mr. Peacock and raised her eyebrows mockingly.
"Yes she told me that, and it better be true," he said, as she smiled, amused. "Anyway," Mr. Peacock went on, "for a young cook, that kind of validation is a very powerful thing."
He visited Miss Lewis in New York. "We talked for hours about Southern cooking," he recalled. "I had been reading in all the magazines about how Italian food was so wonderful because of the short distance it travels from field to table. Well, my father came from a family of poor farmers, and when we were growing up he rented a small space for us to plant okra and greens. We would take what we grew to the IGA and sell it, though I found out later that my dad would pay the man to buy that okra, which was everywhere and very cheap. Anyway, talking with Miss Lewis, I had an epiphany of seeing the obvious. I had grown my okra, I knew about what Alice Waters was doing. Miss Lewis said, 'We need good cooks to stay in the South.' I didn't need to be an Italian chef. I could be a Southern chef."
During Mr. Peacock's unemployment, his father, Franklin, who owns an auto parts business, helped out. "It was kind of amazing of him," Mr. Peacock said. "I think he was always disappointed that he had a son who couldn't shoot a gun or play football. On Christmas, when my sister got pots and pans, there's a picture of me crawling away from the toy trucks toward them, as my parents wept in the background." He grinned. "And the same thing happened the next year when she got the Easy Bake oven."
Although he remains close to his father, he says his relationship with his mother, Dorothy, is more complicated.
Is Miss Lewis maternal toward him? "No," he said quickly. "What I found in Miss Lewis was someone who understood." His eyes filled. "It was about being seen -- as a cook, as a person. After the first article came out about the two of us, calling us the odd couple of Southern cooking, I remember Miss Lewis saying, 'People write about all the things that are different about us, but I never met anyone I could relate to creatively with such synchronicity.' "
Judith Jones, a senior editor and vice president at Alfred A. Knopf, who edited this new cookbook as well as Miss Lewis's "Taste of Country Cooking" and "In Pursuit of Flavor," said by phone: "When Edna met Scott she felt a total connection. She was her wonderful, girlish self again. This is not about Edna wanting a son. If anything he's the one who's paternal now that Edna is forgetful.
"When they were writing this book they would go on what they called retreats to some place in the mountains with their plantation cookbooks and cook together for days, just loving it. And the way Scott has made that apartment cluttered with all the things that Edna loves -- he's trying to delight her."
Recently, Mr. Peacock said, he has thought about trying some romance. He has dated less since he stopped drinking in 1996. "I was charming when I drank, my inhibitions fell away, but without it I became shy," he said. Had Miss Lewis disapproved of his drinking? "She never passed judgment," he said, looking at her, though she didn't respond. His tone was gentle. "It's happened so slowly and in stages," he said. "I remember the first time someone used the word caretaker with me. I was frightened. I didn't see that then, though I do now. It really is that thing drunks say, one day at a time." He went into the kitchen to put lunch on the table.
Is Scott a good roommate? Miss Lewis smiled shyly. "I guess so," she said. She seemed uncertain, being with a stranger. She heard Mr. Peacock in the kitchen. "He's real careful about what he cooks and how he does it," she said. "His restaurant is always jammed." Her voice was proud.
"Do you want me to help you up, Miss Lewis?" Mr. Peacock had returned. "No," she said, trying it herself, though the couch wasn't cooperating. He made a steady stream of conversation, all about the book, so she wouldn't realize he was helping her, anyway. Once she was standing, he entwined his hand in hers, then led her to the kitchen amid a continuing tumble of words about not very much at all, but they lulled and comforted, and assured her that they were going to sit at their table together.
He spooned the minted soup of English peas, a recipe from their book, into large white bowls and served their crusted yeast rolls, still warm in their cast iron skillet. On most days, their meals come from Watershed, though Mr. Peacock said, "Sometimes that fried chicken I bring home is from Popeye's." 
As the last year has grown more difficult, Mr. Peacock started hiring companions for Miss Lewis when he is at work. "Finally letting other people in has been helpful," he said. "When I first saw the writing on the wall, I didn't want to accept what was going on. But the greatest gift is coming to terms with things, facing something instead of running away. It's such a Southern thing when you don't want to expose yourself toothers. You don't want people to see the cracks in the wall or in yourself."
He cleared the soup plates and because it was so hot, skipped the baked chicken in favor of asparagus with cucumber dressing. After two bites, he was up, whipping cream for the angel food cake, which he sliced onto plates next to sugared strawberries.
Did he and Miss Lewis ever sit down and talk about her situation? He nodded: "Right at the beginning when she got confused a number of times, she realized what was happening. And she just looked at me and said, 'Oh, Scott, I'm so sorry.' " 
He turned toward her, but she continued to gaze out the window. "We have days that are brilliant and you'd think nothing is wrong," he said. "I guess at 87 it could be a lot worse. We're not privy to what tomorrow is going to hold, but that thing about being in the moment is so true. I'll be washing a soup bowl after dinner and see her and feel that sacred quality. I feel so grateful."
He reached over and touched Miss Lewis's arm. Her expression had clouded, and it took her a moment to focus on him. But once she did, her face brightened and her smile was suffused with gladness. As was his. "There is something so sacred," he said, "about loving someone."

ANGEL FOOD CAKE
Adapted from "The Gift of Southern Cooking"
by Edna Lewis and Scott Peacock (Alfred A. Knopf, 2003)
Time: 1 hour

1 cup cake flour
1 1/2 cups sugar
12 large egg whites, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract.
1. Heat oven to 375 degrees. Combine flour and 3/4 cups sugar and sift twice onto wax paper or a plate. Set aside.
2. Put egg whites into a large mixing bowl and beat on low speed until frothy. Add cream of tartar, salt, vanilla and 1 tablespoon water. Continue beating, gradually increasing speed until egg whites begin to increase in volume. Sprinkle remaining 3/4 cup sugar over whites 1/4 cup at a time, and beat until incorporated. Do not overbeat. Egg whites should be just firm enough to form soft peaks. 
3. Sift 1/4 of the reserved flour and sugar mixture over beaten whites and fold in. Repeat until entire mixture has been added, making sure each addition is fully incorporated into whites before adding more. 
4. Spoon batter into an ungreased 10-inch tube pan. Use a long spatula or butter knife to draw a deep line through center of batter following circumference of pan; this will release any large pockets of air.
5. Bake 35 to 40 minutes or until cake is golden brown and springs back to the touch. Remove from oven and invert onto a plate; cool completely in pan. When cooled, use a long straight-edged spatula to loosen cake from sides of pan. Store tightly covered. 
Yield: 10 servings.

F1); LINKED BY FOOD -- Edna Lewis, 87, and Scott Peacock, 40, live together as a family, each smitten with the other's creativity in Southern cooking. (Albert Trotman for The New York Times)(pg. HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
For U.S., Bargain Wines, Not French Ones

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
FRENCH wines have experienced problems in the American market before: complicated labels, unpopular wine styles, unfavorable exchange rates. But they haven't encountered difficulties as tough as the ones they are now facing since Prohibition. 
 Already battered by the economic downturn, the French are suffering from a boycott in protest of the Chirac government's outspoken objections to the American-led war against Iraq. According to Impact, a trade publication, some polls show that as many as 30 percent of "core wine drinkers" are boycotting French wines. Then, too, the dollar has dropped almost 19 percent against the euro over the last year, making price increases on imports all but inevitable. 
 Although the net effect of the boycott on this year's wine sales cannot yet be fully determined, Impact's figures show a continuation of the pattern of declining sales of French wines over the last decade. France's share of the imported wine market in this country has slipped from almost 30 percent in 1992 to 18.4 percent last year. 
Impact's annual report, in its April issue on the best-selling wine imports in the United States in 2002, listed only one French producer in the Top 10, Georges Duboeuf, the Beaujolais specialist who also markets popular lines of inexpensive wines from the Languedoc-Roussillon region. Duboeuf, sixth in 2001, fell to eighth last year, a 3 percent drop in cases imported by the United States. Impact also noted that Duboeuf is not likely to appear in the top group at all next year. 
Americans who concern themselves with top-end wines, whether from California or anywhere else, are rarely familiar with the best-selling wines in America, which often cost less than $10 a bottle. The most popular label continues to be Concha y Toro, from Chile, with Riunite of Italy in second place. These labels sell a lot of wine here, some 2.1 million cases of Concha y Toro and just less than 1.8 million of Riunite.
Despite the weaker dollar, 2002 was still a banner year for imports. They were up just under 16 percent to 55.3 million cases from 2001, Impact reported. It's an impressive figure when compared with some of the much-fussed-over California cult wineries doing maybe 800 cases, but perhaps a bit less so when one considers that Gallo alone produces 60 million cases every year. 
Riunite made its name in the 1980's with Lambrusco, which was for many years the No. 1 wine import in this country. After a brief eclipse, Riunite came back strongly last year, with fruit-flavored wines with unforgettable names like Peach Chardonnay, Raspberry Cabernet and Strawberry White Merlot. Oh yes, there is a White Lambrusco, too. The base wine is Italian even if the names come from Madison Avenue. Banfi, the company that virtually created these, er, products, says they are for "entry-level drinkers."
If you are one of the legion of chardonnay fans who has fled to pinot grigio in recent years, you probably helped propel another Italian label, Cavit, to third place on the Impact list. Cavit offers a full line of varietal wines, but many of the 1.925 million cases it sold in the United States last year were pinot grigio.
The fourth and fifth import leaders were Australians, Rosemount Estate and Lindeman's. Australia's winemakers put on the heat last year; their total imports were up more than 50 percent over 2001. Both the Italians and the Australians are a good bet to edge past the Chileans for No. 1 in next year's numbers. 
Some interesting action in the lower end of the market came from the other Top 10 producers, particularly from Casella, a winery in Southeastern Australia that produces wine under the Yellow Tail label. While Yellow Tail has not had the astonishing rise of Charles Shaw's $1.99 wine known as Two-Buck Chuck, its debut has been spectacular for a more serious wine. In 2001, 200,000 cases of chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon, merlot and shiraz were imported into the United States. In 2002, the figure jumped to 1.4 million cases, much of it in 1.5-liter bottles. William J. Deutsch, the importer, said the Casella winery could produce five million cases of Yellow Tail a year if demand continues to rise. 
Yellow Tail was the sixth-biggest import last year. Bolla, from Italy, was seventh and Duboeuf eighth. The last two on the list are Bella Sera and Ecco Domani, both E.&J. Gallo wines made in Italy. Both labels offer the ubiquitous pinot grigio along with the Italian staples: merlot, cabernet, sangiovese and Chianti. Bella Sera sold 1.12 million cases and Ecco Domani 900,000. Based on Impact figures, the two wines put Gallo close to the two-million-case level, making the company a major contender in he imported wine business.
Many Top 10 wines are priced under $10, and except for the Riunite wines, most represent value. They are not meant for connoisseurs, collectors or most other serious wine drinkers. At the same time there are many wines here that represent true bargains. It just might be that the Two-Buck Chuck phenomenon, drinkable wine at surprisingly low prices, will capture the public imagination. If it does, a lot of wine drinkers are going to find that they have been missing out on some good, affordable wines right under their noses. 
The Europeans and the South Americans, the Australians and the New Zealanders must be doing something right. In a year when retailers and restaurants raced each other to drop wine prices, Americans bought 16 percent more foreign wine than the year before, most of it at the lower end of the price scale.
I have always contended that when it comes to wines in the $15-a-bottle-and-under category, imports have it all over the native product. For my money, Italy is making some of the best low-priced wines in the world, and the last time I looked, nobody around here is mad at the Italians.

HEADLINE: A Mass Transit Tax 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Mass transit riders may wish for extra services in exchange for the extra 50 cents coming out of their pockets, but "a little snack, a mint on the way. 
And a better smell" -- as one rider joked (news article, May 3) -- are not the answer. What straphangers need is a vast improvement in mass transit capacity and efficiency. (Where, oh where, is the mythical Second Avenue subway?) 
 This straphanger wishes for a mass transit tax that would come out of the pockets of the employers whose employees hang on the straps to and from work each day. This tax could be based on the number of workers employed. Such a tax could be justified by the countless work hours and productivity lost because of mass transit inadequacy and inefficiency. Surely a better mass transit system enabled by this revenue would improve the city's economy.

G. W. KELLY
New York, May 3, 2003

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Niche Markets Dominate Boston's Office Scene

BYLINE:  By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 6 

 BODY:
Even as office vacancy rates for Boston are exceeding those of the early 1990's, development in some significant niche markets -- life science research, academia and hotels -- is flourishing.
 In greater Boston, 23.3 percent of the offices are available for lease or sublease compared with 5.5 percent in 2000, according to Spaulding & Slye Colliers, a real estate services concern here. In 1991, the low point of the last severe economic downturn, that figure was 16.9 percent. The availability rate in Boston's prime financial district is now 18.9 percent, up from 16.7 percent at the end of 2002, 4.1 percent in 2000 and 16 percent in 1991. 
 But development in niche markets is going full tilt. In Boston and Cambridge, 8,689 hotel rooms have recently opened, are in construction or have been authorized by building permits. Colleges have about six million square feet of classrooms, dormitories and administrative offices in development and are planning millions more square feet.
Last month, Harvard University, the region's largest academic property owner, with 18 million square feet of space, agreed to purchase 91 acres of land adjacent to its business school in the Allston neighborhood of Boston. That purchase -- now being challenged by government agencies -- would bring to 341 acres the property it has gradually acquired in Boston, dwarfing its 216-acre campus in Cambridge, which has 12 million square feet of space.
Construction is under way in the two cities on about seven million square feet of life science laboratories, at a cost of $300 to $600 a square foot, with an additional four million square feet being planned in Boston alone.
Each of these niche markets is modest when compared with 56-million-square-foot office market in the city of Boston. But as a whole, they are a solid underpinning for the wobbly commercial property market and fortify the economic foundation for future growth. 
Boston itself now has about 5 million square feet of labs and 25 million square feet of academic space. By 2007, when the current hotel projects are completed, Boston and Cambridge will have 22,700 rooms, a 50 percent increase, officials in bothcities estimate.
Hotel development took off in 1997 when the city and state agreed to finance a new convention center if at least 4,800 new hotel rooms were built to accommodate conventioneers and generate tax revenues to help pay for the center. Of the 8,680 new rooms, 4,191 have opened, in 22 new hotels and 4 expansions. Seven hotels are under construction, with 914 rooms. Permits have been issued for construction of another 3,584 rooms, said Matthew Arrants, director of the Pinnacle Advisory Group, a hotel consulting company, who added that declines in occupancy rates and average room prices might delay some projects.
For the life science labs, the city's teaching hospitals and schools have been growth catalysts. Many hospitals are linked to universities that have huge endowments to use as collateral for loans or to finance construction. Boston and Cambridge researchers have also benefited from federal grants, including $1.6 billion last year from the National Institutes of Health. 
Potential tenants for the lab space, in addition to the hospitals and researchers, are businesses that rely on them, like pharmaceutical, biomedical or biotechnology companies. As its entry to Boston, Merck is building a 300,000-square-foot lab in the Longwood Medical Area.
The Longwood Medical Area itself is mushrooming, with two million square feet of labs in eight buildings -- including 1.1 million square feet of speculative space -- under development, said Owen Donnelly, a consultant for the Boston Redevelopment Authority, the city planning agency. In addition, the various Longwood Medical Area entities are planning at least another four million square feet of new labs, said Eric Buerhrens, the Harvard Medical School executive dean for administration and finance.
By fall, when Harvard Medical School completes a $260 million, 530,000-square-foot lab, it will occupy 2.25 million square feet in 16 buildings, almost three times its space in 1996, Mr. Buerhrens said.
For strongly endowed institutions, a down economy can be a good time to develop. Costs have fallen for construction, and professional services and permits can be faster. Of the medical school's new research building, Mr. Buerhrens said, "We may bring this in under budget." 
Cambridge, where much life science research is related to biotechnology and information technology, has had a spike in lab availability to perhaps 28 percent versus zero in 2000, said Joseph T. Maguire, director of real estate for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Of M.I.T.'s three million square feet of labs for rent, Mr. Maguire said, 15 percent is now available.
Some of the new Cambridge lab projects were started when the real estate market was stronger; some are already leased. But unlike Boston, where many labs focus on biomedical research, Cambridge's biotechnology companies are more reliant on the venture capital and securities markets, where investors have been cautious lately.
It may be bleak now, "but the demand for science will rebound when capital markets bounce back," Mr. Maguire said.
According to Scott Morrison, United States life science leader for Ernst & Young, "Over the long term, the Boston area will continue to be a center of excellence."
The surge in academic growth seems to buttress that view. M.I.T., which owns and occupies 10.3 million square feet in 142 buildings on its Cambridge campus, has 2.24 million square feet under development in 9 buildings, a $1 billion investment, a spokeswoman said.
A few weeks ago, city officials approved a new master plan for Boston University, which owns and occupies 13 million square feet. It is building three projects with 518,000 square feet for $335 million: a lab, 220 units of housing and a sports complex. In the next three years, it hopes to develop more labs and a new law school, said Richard J. Towle, a university official.
Harvard is developing about 1.1 million square feet in nine buildings, according to university and city officials. City and state officials are trying to keep the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority from selling to the university the 91-acre freight rail yard adjacent to the Harvard Business School. The state is trying to take back a portion of the property. 
Some smaller institutions like Emerson College have made significant contributions to the downtown commercial property market here. Since 1992, Emerson has invested $225 million to move its entire campus from the residential Back Bay to the long-derelict theater district. The school injected vitality into the neighborhood, and major commercial development followed. Now, it hopes that its last big project, a $75 million dormitory, will be well timed.
"If we can start building during the next academic year, we can save about 20 percent on the cost," said Robert A. Silverman, Emerson's vice president for finance and administration. "This opportunity won't last."

HEADLINE: Even With Glut, Shrimp Farmers Want StillMore and Others Balk 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA

DATELINE: MAHACHAI CITY, Thailand 

 BODY:
Holding a plate of freshly cooked shrimp, Wichan Maungchanburi, a 41-year-old shrimp farmer, asked what price they would fetch in the United States.
 "I cannot sell these here," he said gruffly, sitting in front of his simple stone house in southern Thailand. "We have too many shrimp in Thailand. And now they say these are too small. These are the ones they rejected." 
 It is not just Thailand; there are simply too many shrimp worldwide.
After decades of growth brought about by the creation of giant, man-made shrimp ponds throughout Asia, and with other countries stepping up production, prices have collapsed. On top of that, the industry faces criticism from environmentalists for clearing forests and destroying wetlands, and American fishermen accuse Asian producers of illegally dumping shrimp below cost.
One industry response to the glut is a prediction that with modern production methods and costs falling, shrimp consumption will soar. But that optimism is tempered by diseases that have invaded ponds in some areas.
No company feels these pressures more than the Charoen Pokphand Group, the world's largest exporter of frozen shrimp.
In good times, the Bangkok-based CP Group, as it is known, racked up fat profits and fed America's growing appetite for shrimp. Now it is under attack on many fronts. For one thing, environmentalists blame it for destroying wetlands.
With its profits slumping, the value of the company's shrimp exports plummeted 25 percent last year. Wholesale shrimp prices are down nearly 50 percent over the past few years, to about $5 a pound.
"This is a very challenging time for them," said Komsun Suksumrun, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in Bangkok.
In response, the CP Group is trying to move up the value chain, analysts say, by marketing ready-to-eat shrimp dishes and strengthening its more profitable shrimp feed business.
Yet problems remain. CP Group executives say that demand began to slide after Sept. 11, 2001.
The company is being hurt by tighter European Union restrictions on antibiotic use. Earlier this year, the E.U. rejected some Thai shrimp after tests showed residue of banned antibiotics.
It also faces stiffer competition from China and Latin America, where shrimp production is booming. Last year, China became the world's largest shrimp producer, a title Thailand had held since 1993. And while demand continues to grow in the West, the pace has slowed.
"There's just too much shrimp out there," says Charles Woodhouse, a columnist at Fish Farming International. World shrimp farm production jumped to about 1.5 million metric tons in 2002, up from about 600,000 in 1990, according to Shrimp News International.
Angered by the drop in prices, American shrimp fishermen along the Gulf Coast are considering an antidumping lawsuit.
"It seems the shrimp are coming in here at a faster pace than they can be consumed," says Eddie Gordon, president of the Southern Shrimp Alliance, a trade group in Louisiana.
Meanwhile, the CP Group, to compete with lower-cost producers in China and Vietnam, is moving some shrimp farming production to India, Vietnam, Malaysia and Indonesia. Among other things, experts say the moves could help the company avoid the effects of viral diseases that have ravaged parts of Thailand in recent years.
Here in the Mae Klong region south of Bangkok, once a thriving shrimp-growing area, abandoned farms line the small roads off the highway. Weeds cover old footpaths, and former shrimp ponds are now hollow pits of dried, cracked earth.
Residents say many farmers have returned to the salt-drying industry that dominated the region before people learned how to dig giant holes and fill them with thousands of gallons of South China Sea water to create shrimp ponds.
Surviving farmers say they work harder each year only to harvest fewer shrimp. "These are real tough times," said Sopun Kalljain, a shrimp farmer in the southern town of Lampo.
Even though Thai shrimp production reached record levels last year, experts say many regions are being slowed by disease. Some fear the industry could be destroyed by the kinds of viruses that wiped out the shrimp industry in Taiwan in the late 1980's.
As a solution, many Thai farmers are abandoning the traditional black tiger shrimp and experimenting with white shrimp, a variety that costs less to produce and has been bred to be immune to certain diseases.
To bolster production and lock out carriers of disease, the CP Group is also experimenting with new farming techniques. In Yisarn, a village 19 miles south of Mahachai, it has developed indoor shrimp ponds with temperature and water-quality controls.
"This is our future," said Sujit Kaewchum, general manager of the Yisarn research center. "Here we can harvest five times a year rather than two times. And indoors we can get more consistency, more production."
Indoor ponds could also help eliminate some of the environmental problems that have long plagued the industry, experts say. Since the 1960's, environmentalists have criticized shrimp producers for clearing mangrove forests and destroying wetlands to build shrimp ponds.
"This is basically a cut-and-kill system," said Isabel de la Torre, an environmentalist working for the Industrial Shrimp Action Network, an advocacy group. "They dig up the land, create dikes, use chemicals and kill everything off. Then, when they're done, they leave and move up and down the coast, looking for a new spot."
Even today, World Heritage sites in Bangladesh and the Philippines, meant to be preserves, are being cleared of mangrove trees to create ponds, environmentalists say.
Some industry officials concede that the creation of giant ponds -- often 100,000 square feet and five feet deep -- have resulted in environmental ruin. But they insist recent shrimp farm development has been more environmentally friendly.
"We're doing a lot better job managing the growth," said George Chamberlain, president of the Global Aquaculture Alliance, an industry group. Industry officials believe, however, that consumption growth will soon recover and that new techniques will be needed to produce even more shrimp. Poor farmers in India, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Vietnam are now clearing forests and digging deep, wide holes for new ponds.
Some experts say that because of cheap labor and new techniques, the cost of producing shrimp is plummeting. "They're making it at an amazingly low price and will eventually put all commercial fishermen out of business," said Bob Rosenberry, editor of Shrimp News International.
Chingchai Lohawatanakul, chief executive of Charoen Pokphand Foods, the flagship unit of the CP Group, says that as prices fall, consumption will grow even more. Shrimp, he said, will no longer be seen as a luxury item, but will take its place as a staple, like beef, chicken and pork.
"Our competitor is not India or Vietnam," Mr. Lohawatanakul said. "Our competitor is pork."
How will the world produce what some industry officials expect to be 10 times more shrimp to meet the growing demand over the next 20 years? On what land?
No one knows. But CP is counting on it.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Japanese Company Buys Into U.S. Shop

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Hakuhodo in Tokyo, a large agency company, said yesterday that it had acquired a minority stake in Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising in Los Angeles for undisclosed terms.
 Tomokazu Jimbo, corporate executive officer at Hakuhodo, confirmed a report of the deal in Adage.com. 
It has generally been rare for Japanese agencies to make acquisitions overseas, but more such deals are expected as the Japanese economy struggles to grow. 
 Mendelsohn/Zien has billings of $202 million from clients like BMW North America and Hardee's Food Systems.
Jordin Mendelsohn and Richard Zien will continue as managing partners.
In December, Hakuhodo bought 49 percent of a London agency, Mustoe Merriman Levy. Later this year, Hakuhodo and two other Japanese agencies, Daiko Advertising and Yomiko Advertising, plan to merge.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dollar Drops and Treasuries Gain After Fed Statement

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar plunged and the bond market rallied after Federal Reserve policy makers said yesterday that the economy faced a risk of further weakness in the months ahead and, possibly, a sharp fall in inflation. The stock market gave up some gains but still finished the day in the black.
 The Fed's policy makers, as expected, left the central bank's benchmark federal funds rate at 1.25 percent. What surprised bond and currency markets was the Fed's concern about prices falling further. 
 In the current weak economic environment, concern about a big drop in inflation can be taken as a worry about the threat of deflation, although policy makers did not use the word. Falling inflation means smaller price increases. Deflation means a general, widespread price decline, which could bring the kind of economic troubles that have plagued Japan for more than a decade.
While the dollar was already falling against the euro and the yen before the Fed acted, the decline accelerated after the 2:15 p.m. announcement. On the day, the dollar fell 1.2 percent against the euro, which was valued at $1.1417 in afternoon trading. For the year, the dollar is now down 8.1 percent against the euro, which is approaching a value of $1.1667, which was the price of the euro when it became the currency of 11 European countries on Jan. 1, 1998. The dollar was at 117.67 yen, down 0.8 percent.
The bond market, which rallies on economic weakness and low inflation, did an about-face after the announcement. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was around 3.91 percent just ahead of 2:15, up from 3.89 percent Monday. The yield then plunged to 3.78 percent, as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 27/32 , to 10024/32 . The yield on the two-year note dropped to 1.43 percent from 1.53 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up almost 110 points before the announcement, finished with a gain of 56.79 points, or 0.7 percent, to 8,588.36. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.84 points, or 0.9 percent, to 934.39, while the Nasdaq composite index climbed 19.67 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,523.71.
The question for equity investors is whether the Fed's concern about the threat of economic weakness should worry them. Both the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500-stock index are at new highs for the year and the Dow is close to one. But while corporate earnings for the first quarter have beaten expectations, analysts expect earnings growth to slow in the second quarter.
Joseph T. Keating, chief investment officer for AmSouth Asset Management in Birmingham, Ala., said he was not worried because the central bank's statement also said that the decline in oil prices, the jump in consumer confidence and the rise in stocks since the end of the war in Iraq "should foster an improving economic climate over time."
Still, the Fed statement also said that the upside and downside risks of attaining sustainable growth over the next several quarters were "roughly equal."
Then it added the warning on inflation: "In contrast, over the same period, the probability of an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation, though minor, exceeds that of a pickup in inflation from its already low level."
Paul Poldolsky, chief foreign exchange strategist at FleetBoston Financial in Boston, said he thought currency traders now believed that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, "thinks that deflation is a risk to the economy."
"And if that is true," Mr. Poldolsky said, "there is no reason for foreign investors to increase their dollar holdings because the dollar is very vulnerable."
David Gilmore, a partner in Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn., said the dollar faced even more problems than the threat of deflation. Global investors are souring on the dollar because interest rates here are lower than those abroad, he said, and the Fed statement is a signal that policy makers could cut interest rates in the future.
Further pressure could come later this week if two other major central banks, the European Central Bank and the Bank of England, decide to leave their benchmark interest rates unchanged, bolstering the attractiveness of interest rates abroad.
In addition, the dollar is sinking under the weight of the United States' $500 billion current account deficit, which includes profits on investments as well as trades in goods and services. To offset this deficit, the United States must attract offsetting investment from abroad.
"The textbook question is, Are large current account deficits sustainable over time?" said Mr. Gilmore, who said they were not. The dollar's decline, he said, is one expected response as flows from abroad slow. But the second expected response, a rise in interest rates to attract money from abroad, has yet to occur.
Here are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a four-week bill and a three-year note:

PERSON: George Kozmetsky 

HEADLINE: George Kozmetsky, 89, Dean And a Co-Founder of Teledyne 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT

 BODY:
George Kozmetsky, co-founder of the conglomerate Teledyne and a lifelong educator who used his work and philanthropy to bring industry and academia closer together, died last Wednesday in Austin, Tex. He was 85.
 The cause was a heart attack, his son, Gregory, said. 
 Over the course of his life, Dr. Kozmetsky repeatedly moved between boardrooms and business schools. Known for 18-hour workdays that began at 4 a.m., Dr. Kozmetsky was active to the end, his son said, meeting with representatives from Mexico's government on the Friday before he died and holding conference calls from his apartment over the following few days.
Teledyne, his best-known business venture, was started in 1960 as a $550,000 joint investment with Henry E. Singleton, a colleague from Litton Industries, then a small electronics company. With Dr. Kozmetsky as executive vice president, Teledyne grew into a conglomerate of some 130 companies, making everything from stereo speakers to airplane parts. 
After six years at Teledyne, Dr. Kozmetsky left to become dean of the business school at the University of Texas at Austin, a position he held for 16 years. 
His move from Teledyne to Texas, he said at the time, reflected his lifelong philosophy that the academic and business worlds needed to work in better concert. He envisioned "a cross-breeding of engineering and the humanities to bring about the complete man -- the so-called Renaissance man that was the strength of the 16th century," he said in an interview.
At about the same time, he and his wife, Ronya, established the RGK Foundation, which now has assets of about $103 million and has awarded $20 million over the last three years. 
Last month, the couple donated $6 million to set up a technology alliance between the University of Texas and Stanford University.
Born in Seattle to Russian immigrant parents, Dr. Kozmetsky graduated from the University of Washington at the age of 20 and subsequently served in the Army Medical Corps during World War II. He then earned an M.B.A. and doctorate in commercial science from Harvard. His academic career included teaching positions at Harvard University and Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. 
In 1952, he joined the Hughes Aircraft Company, where he spent three years before moving to Litton. 
At the University of Texas he also served as the executive associate for economic affairs. In 1977, Dr. Kozmetsky founded the IC2 Institute, a center for technology entrepreneurship and research.
Over the years, more than 100 technology companies received Dr. Kozmetsky's assistance in their development, and he served on the boards of Dell, Gulf, Heizer and La Quinta, among others. 
In 1993, he was awarded the National Medal of Technology by President Bill Clinton.
In addition to his son, Gregory, of Austin, and his wife of 59 years, Ronya, Dr. Kozmetsky is survived by his daughter, Nadya Scott of Santa Monica, Calif.; seven grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. Another son, George, died in 1972. 
Gregory Kozmetsky said of his father: "I think my dad always felt that, first and foremost, he was a teacher, and his legacy is his students across the world."
He added that his father would want those students to appreciate the connections between business and academia, technology and philanthropy. "Everybody that he met automatically got his respect, and they had to work to lose it," Mr. Kozmetsky said. "He honestly felt that the world could be a much better place if everybody could work together and listen."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 8, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An obituary headline yesterday about George Kozmetsky, co-founder of the Teledyne conglomerate, misstated his age. He was 85, not 89.

HEADLINE: BUDGETS IN CRISIS: ALBANY; 
Pataki Says Legislators' Budget Is Sure to Unravel

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 6 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today continued his assault on the budget the Legislature passed in defiance of his veto threat, saying it would not reduce local property taxes as lawmakers maintain because they failed to revamp the Medicaid program.
 Also today, the State Senate gave final passage to a $1.9 billion aid package for New York City that allows the city to address its fiscal crisis by increasing its sales tax and imposing a surcharge on residents with high incomes. The bill was sent to the governor, who has not committed himself to signing it because he opposes the tax increases. 
 The city aid package, legislators said, includes enough new revenue to cover $270 million for the second year of a teachers' contract and to forestall about 10,000 layoffs in city agencies. Still, several senators from the city complained that the plan contained too little direct aid from the state.
"All we are doing here really is allowing New Yorkers to bail themselves out," said Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat. "If that's a bailout, that's a new one on me."
Nonetheless, the package was unanimously approved by the Republican-led Senate.
The governor, in denouncing the Legislature for passing its $92.8 billion budget, said today that the plan was sure to unravel later this fiscal year and cause enormous deficits in the future. He again promised to veto parts of the budget before the May 14 veto deadline. A final budget was due on April 1.
Like the city package, the Legislature's budget plan increases income taxes slightly on people in high-income brackets and raises the state sales tax a quarter of a percentage point. 
Those changes will be used to restore about $2 billion that Mr. Pataki cut from education aid and medical services to help close an $11.5 billion budget shortfall.
The governor maintains that the Legislature's plan will cause a $1.5 billion hole in this fiscal year's budget and a $5.3 billion shortfall in next year's plan. 
Mr. Pataki also challenged legislative leaders' argument that restoring the school aid and Medicaid would keep local property taxes down. He said that unless the Medicaid formulas were revamped, local governments would still have to shoulder a higher burden.
The Legislature's plan, Mr. Pataki said, would burden local governments outside New York City with $174 million more in Medicaid costs than would his plan. The state and local governments pay a quarter of Medicaid costs apiece, while Washington pays half.
"One of the saddest false promises is the promise that property taxes are not going to go up," he said at a news conference. 
The governor, who is often unavailable to reporters for days, has been holding frequent news conferences to attack the Legislature's budget.
Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate, and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, said the governor ignored the Legislature's restoration of more than $1 billion in school aid. Many school districts were considering raising property taxes more than 20 percent to make up for the lack of aid, they said.
Later in the day, Senator Bruno put out a statement disputing Mr. Pataki's claims. When school aid and other streams of aid are counted, the Legislature's budget would give county governments $145 million more than the governor's plan would have, he said. 
The leaders also continued to dispute the governor's assertion that the budget passed last week was out of balance and contended that it helped address a deficit expected for next fiscal year. 
By enacting new taxes, the leaders said, they were helping the governor begin to solve that shortfall as well.
"We think it's a balanced budget," Mr. Bruno said.
Later, Mr. Silver appeared at a news conference with most of the state's most powerful union leaders, all of whom are supporting the Legislature's budget plan. 
"There is nothing in what the Legislature did that would make the state deficit any bigger than it would have been under the governor's budget," Mr. Silver said. "I don't believe we create a deficit next year."
By his side were labor leaders who had played a critical role in the days before the budget was passed by paying for millions of dollars' worth of advertising attacking the governor's budget and advocating an income-tax surcharge on the wealthy. The news conference seemed calculated to notify the governor that organized labor was backing the Legislature's plan to the hilt.
"Those who stand by us, we will be supportive of them," said Dennis Rivera, the president of 1199/SEIU, the powerful health care workers union, who supported Mr. Pataki last year.
Mr. Pataki planned to take his campaign against the Legislature's budget on the road Wednesday, addressing business leaders in Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse. He maintains that the Legislature's budget will spend about $95 billion and is not balanced despite tax increases he believes will kill the economy.
"We are not going to have the resources to run the government," the governor said, "and we certainly are not going to have the resources to run it next year."

HEADLINE: BUDGETS IN CRISIS: VOICES; 
Rising Costs Give New Yorkers Sticker Shock

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
You can be forgiven if you had the impression yesterday that New York had suddenly turned into a city of self-taught accountants, nervously computing number after depressing number.
 So it was with Frank T. Cervatini, a 77-year-old retired shoemaker who lives in the Bronx. He calculated that he would have to pay an extra $60 a month because of recent increases in subway fares and other assorted fees, taxes and surcharges, and a likely rent increase. "It's ridiculous," he said. "Everything in this city is getting expensive. How are you supposed to live? Thank God I'm nearly dead." 
 So it was, as well, with Gloria Thomas, 32, a single mother who lives in Manhattan. She figured that she would have $50 less a month if rents rose. But she wondered whether she could recoup that money by allowing her son's membership at the local recreation center to expire this summer, as unpleasant as that was. "You have to always calculate everything, because it's raining taxes, and there's no relief in sight," she said. 
Little by little, New Yorkers are paying a lot. There is the tentative increase of up to 8.5 percent on rent-regulated apartments, which represents the biggest rise since 1989, adopted Monday night by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board. There is the 5.5 percent increase in annual water fees for homeowners adopted by the City Water Board, also on Monday, which translates into an average of $27. There is the 50-cent spike, or 33 percent increase, in the subway fare to $2, which took effect on Sunday.
There is also the recent 18.5 percent surge in property taxes, higher cigarette costs, more expensive parking tickets and higher income taxes for the wealthy. And do not forget the proposed rises in taxi fares and tuition at the City University and the State University of New York, among other items.
During moments of introspection, some New Yorkers say they truly understand that the city, not to mention the country, is going through an economic crisis, and that it is incumbent upon everyone to share the burden. They understand, too, that politicians have held fees in check for years.
Still, many New Yorkers say that they are angry, frustrated and despondent about how all the stars of bad financial tidings seem to have ominously aligned, multiplying the effect of sticker shock over and over. And it is a tale of angst that can be told by people at every stage of life, from new parents to retirees, and is directed at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki.
"You pay to live in the city, but it seems like they're turning the screws a little tighter all the time," said David Thalberg, a book publicist who lives in Manhattan. "Haven't they done this enough? You say to yourself, 'They're taking more out of our checks? Why don't they just take it all?' "
Mr. Thalberg, who is 37, has been obsessed with checkbook details and local news for the last few weeks, in a sharp departure from his usual sports-page reading habits. He and his wife, who is an executive at a home furnishings company, take the bus frequently. They have a 2-year-old daughter cared for by a nanny. The nanny has to take the subway to shuttle their daughter to play with friends and go on museum trips and to classes. "You add $4 or $5 a day more over a year, it really begins to hurt," Mr. Thalberg said.
Meanwhile, the Thalbergs have not had time to digest how much more economizing they will have to take on if a proposed increase in city and state income taxes for married couples making more than $150,000 takes effect. To compensate, Mr. Thalberg sometimes rides his bicycle to work, in the best Bloomberg tradition. He gently encourages his nanny to invite his daughter's friends over to their apartment, to save on commuting costs. 
Also, the family did not renew their $75 annual membership to the Wildlife Conservation Society. "It's no zoo this year," Mr. Thalberg said.
If the Thalbergs have an experience that young parents can relate to, Christopher Case has a story that resonates with aspiring college students. 
Mr. Case, a 26-year-old Guyanese immigrant, left the Navy last year as a petty officer so he could go to college and become a teacher. But after struggling to find work for months, he finally landed a job in March as a security guard for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which pays $13.50 an hour.
He wants to study at Queens College but does not have enough money to cover his bills, especially with tuition costs at city colleges rising. So he has adjusted his ambitions and may settle on studying criminal justice at a two-year college. But the higher subway fares -- which he estimated would cost him $5 more a month -- do not help.
At 27, Rick Fine is a year older than Mr. Case, but he is at a different stage in life. He is a financial aid representative who makes a bit more than $30,000 a year, and he is preparing to marry. But an increase in the sales tax would affect the cost of an engagement ring and his everyday purchases. And because he would like to buy a home, higher property taxes worry him, too. "My girlfriend is trying to convince me to move to New Jersey," he said.
Marisa Redanty, 48, is a veteran actress who lives in the theater district and has had roles on "Law and Order" and other shows. She is, in many ways, the typical artist: work is intermittent, and she must be prudent in her financial planning. And retirement, she says, is not that far away.
Still, if she had not changed her routine of taking the subway and taxis, and buying items that were more convenient than economical, she would probably be paying an extra $150 a month. As a result, she takes her shopping cart on the subway to load up on toilet paper at Costco, where it is 40 cents a roll, versus 65 cents a roll in grocery stores. She buys her cigarettes online from American Indian reservations, saving about $4.50 a pack.
And she also walks to auditions all the time, thereby saving on her subway expenses. But this means that she probably has to buy a new pair of sneakers to take the pounding.
"I wasn't always like this, but the first thing I think about is money," she said. "I sit down with my calculator and say, 'O.K., what should I do?' "
Then again, this being New York, some people say that they lead lives that have been relatively untouched by the whirlwind of surcharges and fines, as if they had managed to deftly avoid a multiple-car pileup on the highway.
Randy Schrade, 41, a music teacher on the Upper East Side, may fall into this category. While he and his wife (who had a baby three weeks ago) say that they are dining out less and plan to be more careful in their shopping, he also has the fortune of being insulated from many of the increases. He does not smoke. He does not own property. He does not make six figures. He does not own a car that could be ticketed. And he is not too happy about the proposed increase in taxi fares, even though he walks to work.
As for the water taxes, Mr. Schrade said, "We drink bottled."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Randy Schrade, a music teacher, is relatively unaffected by many recent tax increases. He does not smoke or own property. And he does not own a car that could be ticketed. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Connecticut Governor in an Unfamiliar Role: Damage Control 

BYLINE:  By PAUL von ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 6 

 BODY:
Teflon John is a nickname that Gov. John G. Rowland appeared to enjoy earning during the last eight years, when his popularity seemed immune to controversy. 
 Whether it was the $2,000 fine he paid for improperly accepting free box seats for a Jimmy Buffett concert in 1997, or the conviction of his hand-picked state treasurer on federal corruption charges in 1999, or the loss in 2001 of nearly $200 million in public money in Enron's collapse, no scandal seemed big enough to crack Mr. Rowland's self-confidence or his public standing. 
 Now, however, the Rowland veneer of invincibility seems to be growing thin. 
Since the year began, Mr. Rowland, a Republican who has spent half of his 46 years in elective politics, has struggled to contain damage caused by a worsening state economy and the emergence of several new state and federal investigations into his actions and his administration's. His public approval ratings have plummeted to their lowest point since he took office in 1995. According to a poll of 508 registered voters taken two weeks ago by the University of Connecticut, only one in four thinks Mr. Rowland is doing a good job. 
The negative publicity and his declining popularity have also taken a toll on Mr. Rowland's typically poised public persona. Always quick to defuse criticism with a dismissive quip, the governor has made several public remarks recently that ended up embarrassing his colleagues, unnecessarily angering his adversaries and alienating the Capitol news media.
"He certainly is having a bad few months," said Morton Tenzer, professor emeritus of political science at the University of Connecticut. "He doesn't seem to be handling things as well as he has in the past. He's behaving uncertainly, instead of with his usual aplomb. It's almost like a basketball player who is used to making his shots, and then misses a few and starts to lose confidence, which makes him miss even more shots." 
While Mr. Rowland insists he is unfazed by the recent flurry of bad news, legislative Democrats worry that his low approval ratings will hinder attempts to compromise on budgetary matters. 
Michele Sullivan, Mr. Rowland's spokeswoman, said, "He is accountable and is confident in his leadership, and sometimes being accountable does not mean being infallible." She added: "He is addressing each issue as it comes up. Unfortunately, they are coming up one after the other, and people are combining them instead of looking at them apart."
Political insiders from both parties also said Mr. Rowland has seemed less than the dominating figure who crushed his Democratic opponent in last year's election by a double-digit margin, and certainly not the same college-boy governor who celebrated his inauguration in 1995 by standing on his head and chugging a beer.
Even Republican supporters flinched last week when, during a live radio interview, Mr. Rowland mocked leaders of a clerical workers' union for supposedly failing to demand in recent negotiations that the state rehire workers it had recently laid off. 
In fact, the union had raised the issue, unsuccessfully. The governor's press office released a statement apologizing for his misstatement, but the damage was done. Furious, the union backed out of a contract agreement, dealing a severe blow to Mr. Rowland's efforts to reach a compromise with many of the other unions representing 47,000 state workers. 
Other missteps have left Capitol Democrats and Republican scratching their heads. On Thursday, Mr. Rowland called a news conference to publicly, if cynically, urge the Democratic-led Legislature to pass a 2004 budget with $700 million in tax increases so that he could promptly veto it. "Vote this plan up, allow me to veto it, and let's get down to business," he said. Democratic lawmakers, who have no plans to vote on a budget soon, quietly fumed.
In March, Mr. Rowland, parrying reporters' questions about his former co-chief of staff's recent guilty plea to federal bribery charges, embarrassed his new Department of Correction commissioner, Theresa C. Lantz, during a news conference when he suggested that he could not prevent any state official, including Ms. Lantz, from breaking the law. "If a year from now she does something wrong, how do we know that?" he said, gesturing to Ms. Lantz. 
Mr. Rowland, whose former close adviser and co-chief of staff, Peter N. Ellef, is an object of a federal corruption investigation, has also been dogged by personal ethics issues. 
Last month, the State Ethics Commission began an investigation into the unusually generous prices the governor paid to rent vacation homes owned by a large Connecticut developer and major contributor to Rowland campaigns over the years. In March, Mr. Rowland was forced to admit that he had used a credit card issued to the State Republican Party to pay for a vacation at a New Hampshire resort, and to reimburse the party for the nearly $2,000 expense. 
Ken Dautrich, director of the Center for Survey Research and Analysis at UConn, whose polls have tracked what he called Mr. Rowland's "nose-dive" among voters, said a significant decline in popularity was not surprising. 
"A lot of the drop has been at least partially due to the artificially high rating because of the rally effect after 9/11," he said. 
Kevin B. Sullivan, president pro tem of the State Senate, said Mr. Rowland's recent troubles present not an advantage for Democrats, but rather more problems as the governor seeks to win back support from his Republican base. "I think you're going to see short term, a bit more orchestration of John Rowland the tax killer," he said. "It makes it harder for us to get back to business."

HEADLINE: A Renoir Shines as the Spring Art Sales Begin 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
An 1882 Renoir portrait of a French gentleman's wife sitting in her garden, deemed too daring by the husband who commissioned it because of its bright colors, is heading for Las Vegas.
 Stephen A. Wynn, the casino owner and art collector, bought the painting, "In the Roses (Madame Leon Clapisson)," for $23.5 million last night at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art. It was the most expensive painting in the sale, bringing just over its $20 million low estimate, and it is to go on view at his gallery in the lobby of the old Desert Inn until Mr. Wynn opens his new casino, Le Reve. 
 At Sotheby's viewing over the weekend, art dealers speculated on what the painting would have fetched in the heady days of the 1980's, when the Japanese snapped up pretty Impressionist paintings like this one for perhaps three times what it brought last night. But the price came as a welcome relief in the auction world. Obtaining property for the important spring evening sales, which began last night, was tough, experts said, because of the war in Iraq, the rocky economy and a general uncertainty as to whether anyone was in the mood to buy art these days.
Even so, the sale had many bumpy moments. Of the 39 lots, 11 failed to find buyers. The auction totaled $65.6 million, below its low estimate of $70 million.
In recent seasons modern art has been the most sought-after, but Impressionist works tended to fare best last night, in part because the better works were Impressionist. One of the stars of the sale was Pissarro's "Road to Rocquencourt" (1871), which captures a slice of rural life at the time the artist had settled in Louveciennes, a middle-class suburb southwest of Paris. It was expected to fetch $3 million to $5 million. Three bidders went for the painting, which eventually sold to Nancy Whyte, a private dealer in Manhattan, for $5.6 million.
(Final prices include Sotheby's commission: 20 percent of the first $100,000 and 12 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston was one of the most important sellers. In an effort to raise $17 million to buy an 1876 Degas that is considered his last important early oil left in private hands, the museum was selling two Degas pastels of dancers and a Renoir painting.
"Dancer" (circa 1885-90), the cover art of the sale catalog, depicts a single dancer about to take her bow. Two bidders vied for the work, which finally sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $10.6 million, above its low estimate of $9 million.
"Dancers in the Wings" (circa 1888) shows two women, one holding a fan and the other leaning against the stage set. Estimated at $2.5 million to $3.5 million, it sold to another unidentified bidder for $3.9 million. Until recently the painting hung on the walls of the Philadelphia Museum of Art as part of its "Degas and the Dance" exhibition, and it's not going back.
The third work the museum was selling last night was Renoir's "Gabrielle and Coco Playing Dominos" (circa 1905-06), which shows the artist's third son playing dominos with one of Renoir's favorite models. Four bidders went after the painting, which ended up selling for its high estimate, $1.6 million.
The buyers, a couple sitting in the second row of the salesroom who bid on many works of art last night, roused much curiosity during the sale. These days, when conspicuous consumption is out of fashion, most collectors either ask a dealer to bid for them or sit in a skybox above the salesroom, bidding by telephone through an expert below.
The couple identified themselves as Stewart Rahr, president and chief executive of Kinray Inc., a Queens distributor of pharmaceuticals, health care and beauty products, and his wife. Carol. "We've been buying for about five years now," said Mr. Rahr, who also bought Max Liebermann's "My House in Wannsee With Garden" (1926) for $1.5 million, far above its high estimate of $950,000.
Sculpture has been a particularly strong area of the market in recent years, but last night the results were mixed. One evening's casualty was "The Clearing (Composition With Nine Figures)," conceived in 1950, a bronze consisting of nine gaunt female figures on a rectangular base. Despite its estimate of $8 million to $10 million, bidding never went past $7.2 million and it failed to sell.
Tonight Christie's is to auction another cast of the same sculpture, but with a painted surface, which is rarer and thus expected to fetch a high price.
Another high-end work that remained unsold was Malevich's "Suprematist Painting, Rectangle and Circle" (1915). Even though the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is opening a retrospective of the artist's work next week, nobody wanted the abstract painting, consigned by the artist's heirs, in which a black circle and a blue rectangle are starkly painted against a pure white background. The problem was that it had been shopped around for months, and everyone knew it. Sotheby's estimated the painting would bring $5 million to $7 million, but not a paddle was raised.

HEADLINE: Stone Harbor Journal; 
Endangered Bird Finds Friends in High Places

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: STONE HARBOR, N.J., May 1 

 BODY:
Pity the poor piping plover.
 The rare and fragile little shore bird, protected by federal law, has been caught in the middle of an expensive and nasty legal crossfire in this pleasant coastal town about 20 miles south of Atlantic City. 
 On one side are town officials, boaters and many taxpayers. On the other are the United States attorney for New Jersey and two other federal agencies determined to protect nesting plovers on a barren peninsula at the southern tip of town. 
The issue involves tens of thousands of cubic yards of sediment that the town dredged from six bays here in late 2001 and early 2002 and pumped to the peninsula. The bays are lined with lovely summer homes, some worth more than $1 million. Just about everybody has a powerboat or sailboat, and many owners had pressed town officials to remove the sediment, which had formed shoals that damaged propellers and keels.
In January, the United States attorney, Christopher J. Christie, said that the dredging was illegal and that the town violated its permit from the Army Corps of Engineers. The town was accused of dumping too much sediment (79,258 cubic yards instead of the allowed 65,342 cubic yards), refusing to document the origins of the sludge, and reneging on an agreement for complex tests to determine if the sediment contained metals harmful to piping plovers.
Before dredging, the town had assured authorities that the sediment was 75 percent sand, with some traces of toxic mercury. But in his complaint, Mr. Christie called the sediment a very unsandy, puddinglike mix with a crusty top. Before the lawsuit, his aides pressed the town to abide by its earlier agreement for metal tests.
Mayor Suzanne Walters said the town resisted because the tests cost $250,000 and the town's environmental expert had said the sediment had only tiny, nonharmful amounts of metals.
The lawsuit by Mr. Christie's office called for fines of tens of thousands of dollars for each day the violations persisted.
In February, Stone Harbor relented and agreed, in a court-approved settlement of the lawsuit, to remove the sludge by pumping it through a snaking pipeline hundreds of yards away to a trench on nearby Sedge Island.
That work is about to start.
The challenge is to complete the excavation without hurting six pairs of plovers spotted by government biologists in mid-April. The federal Fish and Wildlife Service has been zealous in protecting any of the plovers spotted along the Atlantic Coast since they were placed under the safeguards of the United States Endangered Species Act in 1986. In 2002, 138 pairs of the birds were seen along the Jersey Shore.
Stone Harbor's fight with federal authorities is a rare one.
Anne Hecht, director of the wildlife service's plover-protection program along the Atlantic, said her staff relies on persuasion to help the bird. United States attorneys are rarely used, she said.
Before helping the plovers, Mr. Christie focused on fighting corrupt officials. The plover case offered a chance to protect the beauty, vitality and wildlife of the Jersey Shore, he said.
So far, the matter has cost taxpayers here about $2.75 million, town officials say. The original dredging cost about $1.5 million, and the excavation contract is worth $1 million. The town spent $100,000 for sand to build a court-ordered 4.4-acre nesting site for the birds in March.
And it faces $150,000 in penalties for missing deadlines to finish the excavation by March 31 and April 30.
Many residents are incensed about the costs. Some offer bitter jokes. One heard often is: "Piping plovers are wonderful -- prepared in garlic."
Grumbling abounds.
"This is absolutely a circus, and I don't know who is really to blame," said a resident who lives on Golden Gate Road.
Ellen Vaughn, 80, lives across a narrow waterway from Sedge Island and worries about a summer of odors from sludge.
"I'm sick of the whole thing," she said. "I don't know what's going to happen when they start dumping that muck."
Joan Paulson, of Sunset Drive, said: "The town goofed. It's just very, very sad they wasted so much time and so much money."
John and Ruth Rosser, residents for 50 years, blame federal bureaucrats.
"These people are the Mafia," Mr. Rosser said. "The nonelected officials have gone berserk in this country."
His wife agreed. "They're not willing to listen to anybody but themselves, and there's no way to get rid of them," Mrs. Rosser said.
Tim Keane, manager of the Stone Harbor Marina, said state and federal coastal regulations harm the coastal economy.
The New Jersey Audubon Society disagreed.
"If you lose piping plovers, you lose an essential component of the beach community that people spend millions of dollars a year to enjoy," said the society's vice president for research, David Mizrahi. 
The society's vice president for conservation, Eric Stiles, said the number of people who visit the shore to watch wildlife in the spring, summer and fall is growing, and their presence helps motels and restaurants. Shore towns can help their economies by cooperating with conservation groups, Mr. Stiles said.
Lately, federal authorities seem in a compromising mood. The local office of the wildlife service will permit some disturbance of nesting plovers during sludge removal "as long as it's minimized," said Annette Scherer, an agency biologist.
Michael A. Chagares , chief of the civil division of the United States attorney's office, said no more penalties were being sought for excavation delays, but he refused to rule out contempt-of-court motions.
He said the town was required to use its "best efforts" to finish the work. "We're watching what they're doing very carefully," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Part of the area at Stone Harbor where the plovers nest and dredged sediment from six bays was deposited by the town in 2001 and 2002. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times); The town of Stone Harbor, N.J., learned that the piping plover, an endangered species, has legal clout with the federal government. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SPRINT, UNDER COMPETITIVE PRESSURE, IS CUTTING 575 JOBS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 The Sprint Corporation will eliminate 575 jobs after competition caused revenue to decline. 
Employees were notified yesterday of the cuts, which amount to less than 1 percent of Sprint's work force of 72,000, a spokeswoman, Melinda Tiemeyer, said. She declined to detail any charge or cost savings. About 100 of the jobs being eliminated are in Kansas City, Mo. The cuts are in Sprint's local- and long-distance phone unit, which has had nine consecutive quarterly sales declines as business customers pare spending and rivals take residential customers.
