HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
World Cup in U.S. a No-Brainer

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
WHAT'S your team? Do you root for your locals or do you reach out for one of those legendary teams that defy regional boundaries -- the Yankees, the Montreal Canadiens, the Miami Hurricanes? 
 Some fans even show imagination by rooting for not necessarily glamorous teams from other parts of the country. There are New Yorkers who like the Detroit Tigers, the Cleveland Browns, the Los Angeles Clippers -- just because. 
 As a licensed practitioner of sportswriting, I am legally barred from actively rooting for any team. Since developing a major soccer jones in the last two decades, however, I now indulge myself in rooting for a few teams outside North America, just to feel what fans go through. 
I am currently heavily involved in the fortunes of West Ham, from the Dickensian tidal flats east of London, which will try to avoid relegation on the final weekend. And despite its being owned by Silvio Berlusconi, A.C. Milan has been a favorite of mine ever since I witnessed Franco Baresi, Ruud Gullit and Frank Rijkaard wearing the handsome red-and-black uniforms a decade ago.
Jealous as heck that we do not have ancient soccer teams like that in my home country, I have followed both teams' soap operas this season on the Internet and on cable television and in the foreign papers available in the big city.
To further pursue this addiction, yesterday I was sitting in my favorite Greenwich Village cafe, L'Angolo on Houston Street, watching good old ESPN2 as Real Madrid beat Juventus, 2-1, in the first leg of their Champions League semifinal. 
My friend Massimo, who loves his team from Florence, had no problem rooting for Juventus of Turin. But my friend Riccardo has rooted for A.C. Milan all his life and could not bring himself to root for striped Juve, the Yankees of Italy. And Pino, the proprietor, roots for Inter, which plays A.C. Milan in the other semifinal today (although not on ESPN2, the dogs).
It is a grand time of year to be a soccer buff. Too bad one cannot take a trolley out to the match. The MetroStars are home in New Jersey this Saturday and the Power is home on Long Island this Saturday, however, as the two American leagues roll into high gear. 
There are, bless 'em, a loyal cadre of fans of both Major League Soccer and the Women's United Soccer Association, even if the two leagues still seem raw and impermanent. You can't even work up a good disdain for individual owners because the leagues practice socialism.
The success of the United States men's team in last year's World Cup made modest heroes of appealing young players like Clint Mathis, Landon Donovan and DaMarcus Beasley. The caliber of the league is rising, but attendance is not taking off, and our locals, the MetroStars, have been a pretty awful franchise, rattling around in Giants Stadium. They're not A.C. Milan yet. They're not the Hammers. 
The women's league, in its third season, is even shakier. In this weak economy, there isn't much tolerance for good intentions. The Power has gone from mediocre to dreadful, and it has already jettisoned two coaches and one general manager.
For all the problems, the W.U.S.A. is the best paying and highest level of women's soccer in the world. The game itself is attractive (they're not as big or fast as the men; get over it) and the players are skillful, charismatic, smart and friendly. 
The league carries the hopes of women from across the world, providing jobs and competition for Brazilians and Nigerians, Chinese and Norwegians, Yanks and Canadians. Just as important, the W.U.S.A.'s existence helps justify soccer programs for girls in many nations where sports leaders may not think it important. 
But the W.U.S.A. cannot exist indefinitely as filler programming on marginal cable channels. It needs some buzz.
Now there is a chance to provide the buzz. This year's Women's World Cup cannot be held in China because of the SARS scare. The world soccer body, FIFA, is said to be mulling four countries as replacements, but there is really only one choice.
Everybody remembers what Americans did in 1999 with years of planning. It is getting late, but American promoters could fill lesser stadiums, even in September, with our glut of sports.
The executives of the W.U.S.A. bravely insist they don't need this World Cup to survive, but they do. Given this unfortunate opportunity, the league needs one more infusion of Mia and Brandi and all the emerging foreign stars.
One of these decades, some of the W.U.S.A. teams could be known around the world, a lucrative beacon to international stars. For now, Forza Milan! Go Hammers! 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Moving this fall's Women's World Cup to the United States would give the world another chance to see Mia Hamm, left, and her teammates. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Fed Worries About Prices, But Holds Rate 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve held short-term interest rates steady today, but took the unusual step of saying that it had become worried about the risks of a sustained fall in prices, commonly known as deflation. 
 The statement signals that the Fed stands ready to cut rates soon if the economy does not quickly recover from its recent weakness, and it suggests that some officials at the Fed remain considerably more nervous about the economy than Alan Greenspan, the chairman. 
 In announcing that it was keeping the benchmark interest rate on overnight loans between banks at 1.25 percent, the Federal Open Market Committee -- the Fed's rate-setting group -- acknowledged that companies had recently cut both production and employment.
"However, the ebbing of geopolitical tensions has rolled back oil prices, bolstered consumer confidence and strengthened debt and equity markets," the committee said. Those developments "should foster an improving economic climate over time." 
The chief danger facing the economy, the Fed said, is that inflation, which is already low, will fall further as demand for new products remains weak. Many economists say they believe that deflation can cripple an economy by effectively increasing debt levels and causing consumers to reduce their spending in anticipation of future bargains. Low inflation, on the other hand, is widely considered to be the ideal situation.
Stocks, after having risen in the morning, moved little after the announcement at 2:15 p.m. that rates would not change, which most analysts had expected. The dollar, however, accelerated its recent decline and fell 1.2 percent against the euro. Traders attributed the sharp move to the Fed's concern about potential deflation. Page C9. 
The worried tone of the Fed's announcement appeared to shed light on an emerging disagreement between Mr. Greenspan and some of his colleagues. 
Together, the statement and a unanimous vote in favor of holding rates unchanged "has 'compromise' written all over it," said Ian C. Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
Mr. Greenspan has argued that the war in Iraq caused many of the recent economic problems, like rising layoffs. With oil prices having fallen and a protracted war no longer a possibility, consumers and executives will probably accelerate their spending, lifting the economy from its long slump this year, Mr. Greenspan suggested to Congress last week.
Some other Fed officials remain nervous that companies are still cutting costs to recover from the excesses of the 1990's boom. At some point, the weakening labor market could cause consumers to pull back their spending and make the economy vulnerable to a new downturn, officials have said in recent speeches. 
"This economic recovery has been losing momentum since last summer," Anthony M. Santomero, the president of the Philadelphia Fed, said last month. "Not all of this can be laid at the feet of the Iraq situation. Other events and imbalances were and are still at work."
But the officials' concerns were not big enough for them to favor a rate cut today, or at least for them to take a public stand by voting for one. Mr. Greenspan, like previous Fed chairmen, has long preferred to keep most debates within the Fed's boardroom and to shape compromises that allow for unanimous votes.
"I think there's disagreement on the board," said Joel L. Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisers, a forecasting firm in St. Louis. "Greenspan's made it pretty clear that he thinks the main problem is geopolitical uncertainty from which we'll recover."
In March, at its previous meeting, the Fed also left rates unchanged, but it refused to characterize the risks of a downturn, saying the impending war with Iraq created too much uncertainty. 
Today, the Fed went into more detail than it typically does when describing the risks facing the economy. It called the upside and downside risks to sustainable growth "roughly equal," suggesting that a new recession this year was no more likely than an unhealthy spike in growth. But weakness remains a bigger worry than an overheated economy because of the small possibility of an "unwelcome substantial fall in inflation," the Fed said, not using the word deflation. 
Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley, called the new detail "a change in the way Fed communicates."
He added, "It's an important and welcome step in the Fed moving toward a more understandable policy."
The Fed began to cut its benchmark interest rate in January 2001, soon after unemployment started rising and the record-long expansion of the 1990's ended. Since then, the Fed has cut the rate 12 times, to 1.25 percent, its lowest level since 1961.
By lowering the cost of automobile, credit-card and other short-term loans -- and indirectly causing some of the fall in mortgage rates -- the reductions helped make the recession of 2001 one of the mildest on record. But to the surprise of Mr. Greenspan and most of his colleagues, who have regularly predicted a return to healthy growth over the last two years, the economy has remained in a rut, growing too slowly for companies to hire new workers.
The slow growth has also pushed down annual inflation to between 1.5 percent and 3 percent, depending on the measure, and raised fears that the economy could slip into a deflationary trap similar to the one hurting Japan. Echoing the opinion of most economists, the Fed called the risk minor today, but officials have said that they want to be vigilant because, having studied Japan's experience, they consider deflation harder to reverse than to prevent.
"We're living in amazing times," said Ian Morris, the chief domestic economist at HSBC. Deflation "has never been an issue since the 1930's," he added.
Most private-sector forecasters also expect the economy to gain strength in the coming months, but many say that they have already been surprised by the long slowdown.
"There's a lot to suggest that the precursors to a second-half recovery are falling into place," Mr. Prakken said. "But there's no evidence of an actual rebound. There's a lot of uncertainty. It's difficult to make a good forecast in a postbubble environment."
The Fed's rate-setting committee next meets on June 24 and 25. Forecasters are divided over whether a cut is likely then, although most seem to expect no change.

HEADLINE: Senator Graham of Florida Begins Run for Presidency 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY

DATELINE: MIAMI LAKES, Fla., May 6 

 BODY:
Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat from the state that was the fulcrum of the disputed 2000 presidential election, began his own White House campaign today by asserting that President Bush had "virtually ignored homeland security" in his drive to "settle old scores" and remove Saddam Hussein from power.
 In a speech to supporters standing in wilting heat in the prim middle-class development his family built on its southern Florida farm here, Mr. Graham also said Mr. Bush had wasted the strong economy he inherited. The senator described Mr. Bush's tax cuts as a threat to the health of the nation's economy. 
 "The Bush administration has reneged on our promise and jeopardized our future," Mr. Graham said, reading slowly from prepared remarks.
"The last Democratic administration not only put us on the path towards fiscal solvency, it produced the biggest budget surpluses in the history of our nation," he said. "The Bush administration has squandered all of that. We need a president who will fight for our nation's economic future instead of the short-term interest of a special few." 
Mr. Graham, a three-term senator who at 66 is the oldest of the candidates running, offered the case for his candidacy in an announcement speech that had been delayed both by the war in Iraq and by heart surgery that included a double bypass and valve replacement using the valve of a Holstein cow. 
He delivered his 24-minute speech in a picture-perfect town square on Main Street less than a mile from his home in this planned development. Mr. Graham had been planning to go from here to New Hampshire and Iowa, but delayed the trip to return to Washington for a Senate committee meeting, a reminder of the difficulties he and five other Democratic members of Congress face in trying to run for president.
Mr. Graham is one of nine Democrats seeking their party's presidential nomination. He is the third to deliver a formal announcement speech, after Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
Mr. Graham's speech today was notable for the harshness of his attacks on Mr. Bush's Iraq policy. Seizing a theme that drew him notice as a member of the Intelligence Committee after the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Mr. Graham argued that Mr. Bush had put Americans at increased risk for a terrorist attack at home by focusing on Iraq, a country that Mr. Graham said was not the greatest threat to the United States today.
"I know firsthand, as the former chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, how little this administration has done to provide real security at home, while it's directed attention away from the war on terrorism abroad," he said, adding, "Yet, instead of pursuing the most imminent and real threats, international terrorists, this Bush administration chose to settle old scores."
Mr. Graham told reporters later that the "old scores" he was referring to were what he described as the finishing of the war against Mr. Hussein that Mr. Bush's father started in 1991, and avenging a plot by Mr. Hussein to assassinate the elder Mr. Bush.
The tough words attacking President Bush's security and economic policies were delivered in a languorous and at times halting speech that left many supporters squirming in the midday sun. 
Many Democrats view Mr. Graham as a largely enigmatic force. He has many ingredients of a formidable candidate. He is a moderate Southerner with extensive foreign policy experience in the Senate and two terms as Florida governor. And he has the geographic advantage of coming from the state that Democrats believe they should have won, along with the presidency, in 2000, a point that Mr. Graham's advisers invariably return to in presenting him as the strongest candidate the Democrats could put up against Mr. Bush.
"This is clearly the most competitive state in the nation," Mr. Graham said today.
Yet Mr. Graham has not engaged in a competitive race since 1986, and his campaign skills remain in question. His habit of keeping detailed daily notebooks of the most trivial events of his day led advisers to Al Gore to reject him as a running mate, concerned that some voters might consider that behavior odd.
What is more, Mr. Graham joins this contest well after many opponents have spent months in the field, collecting money, signing up supporters, developing themes and learning basic campaign skills. Mr. Graham had originally planned to begin his campaign on Feb. 4.
In a sign of the tentativeness with which, it seems, even Mr. Graham views his prospects, he repeatedly declined to say he would not run for Senate in 2004, leaving himself an out in case his presidential campaign founders. Given all the obstacles to the nomination, many Democrats in opposing camps say they believe that Mr. Graham's real interest is to be considered for the second spot on the ticket, but Mr. Graham dismissed such speculation today as unfounded.
Mr. Graham's advisers went to considerable lengths to stage a vigorous rally to begin his candidacy. 
"This is the moment we've all been waiting for: the next first lady and the 44th president of the United States!" Scott Maddox, the Florida Democratic chairman who served as master of ceremonies, bellowed as Mr. Graham and his wife, Adele, appeared. 
They took the stage, to the amplified pulsing beat of a song by the band U2, "Where the Streets Have No Name," which has become an anthem at Democratic campaign rallies.
On the stage were men and women with whom Mr. Graham has appeared during what he calls "work days" -- in which he spends a day working to get a feel for different jobs, like driving a truck or working in a factory. Mr. Graham plans to hold a work day in New Hampshire, this time in the role of a teacher.
Mr. Graham's speech was filled with remarks intended to paint Mr. Bush's administration as a White House for the wealthy.
"It is time to bring America back -- from one of our longest economic slowdowns ever, and the only economic slowdown since when the last Bush was in the White House," he said. "It is painfully clear that this president has no economic policy other than granting tax cuts to the wealthiest Americans."

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
A new start, a new name. But have things really changed as Kmart comes out of bankruptcy?

BYLINE:  By Constance L. Hays

 BODY:
FIFTEEN months after filing for bankruptcy protection, Kmart yesterday completed its reorganization and today will become a publicly traded company once more -- a much smaller one, under new management and control, with a future that remains unclear.
 The company, renamed the Kmart Holding Corporation, called the emergence "a momentous day for Kmart." But inside the Kmart on West 34th Street in Manhattan at lunchtime, shoppers were buying clothes and a drawing for free jewelry was taking place; there were no signs that the nation's biggest retail bankruptcy had come and gone. 
 Perhaps that was appropriate, because, from Kmart's point of view, little about the world of retailing has improved since it entered Chapter 11 early last year. Wal-Mart Stores remains the leader among discounters, with Target overshadowing Kmart in sales as well. Stores like Kohl's that offer brand-name goods at low prices in settings considered a step up from the usual discount environment are growing fast and often at the expense of Kmart. 
Many suppliers that were angered by Kmart's treatment of them -- including a program known as Project Slow It Down, which relied on phony excuses and other means to intentionally delay payments, according to an internal Kmart investigation -- are still owed money. They will receive stock in the new company, however, and are part of a trust that can seek legal action against former Kmart management. 
The slumping economy is no friend to retailing, curbing sales at most chains in recent weeks. In addition, an exclusive Kmart brand, Martha Stewart Everyday, has been swept up in the government investigation of Martha Stewart's stock trading. Executives of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, in discussing the company's first-quarter performance last week, said sales at Kmart fell $800,000. Citing the chain's store closings, they predicted sales for the year would come in below the minimum guaranteed by Martha Stewart's contract with Kmart. 
Despite all that, Edward S. Lampert, the hedge fund manager who bought Kmart debt and accelerated the timetable for its exit from bankruptcy, said Kmart could and would perform better. He dismissed the falling shopper traffic as inconsequential and said the company would be run to make profits.
"The focus that a lot of people have in retail revolves around sales," Mr. Lampert said in an interview, "but sales without profit do not allow a business to be successful in the long term."
Yesterday, the board of Kmart appointed him chairman.
With fewer stores -- Kmart is down to about 1,500 stores from 2,100 before its bankruptcy filing -- the company has a better chance of turning those profits, he added. "The bankruptcy process allowed the company to position its store base so that what remains has a chance of being really successful," he said. 
One Kmart supplier said yesterday that it continued to press him to make concessions that were favorable to Kmart, much as it had before the bankruptcy. "They want to buy products, and they want us to ship them, and then they want 60 days to pay the bills," said the supplier, who insisted upon anonymity.
As Kmart's troubles mounted, the supplier insisted on being paid promptly for products he delivered. Now, he said, "they are punishing vendors who have said they will not extend open-account credit." 
Kmart's initial plan called for it to emerge from bankruptcy by July 2003. When Mr. Lampert acquired his stake after buying up bonds and other debt, he urged Kmart management to speed the process with a deadline of April 30. He got what he wanted, a week late. Mr. Adamson was forced out as chief executive in January. He was succeeded by Julian C. Day, a financial expert who has worked at Sears, Roebuck, among other companies. 
One retail expert said he thought Kmart had emerged too quickly. "You are bringing a company out that is still fundamentally flawed," said Burt Flickinger, a managing partner with the Strategic Resource Group, which advises stores. "If they had stayed in bankruptcy, they could have fixed all the infrastructure and buying and warehousing and transportation issues that continue to produce negative same-store sales" -- sales at stores open at least a year.
Mr. Lampert, whose ESL Investments put an additional $140 million into Kmart to win control of it along with Martin J. Whitman of Third Avenue Partners, said he saw no need to recast its image to compete with Wal-Mart and Target. Among discounters, Wal-Mart is known as the low-price leader, and Target as the store for the trend-conscious. 
"The image is different to different people," Mr. Lampert said. "When you look at a company that does $25 billion in sales, it means something to a lot of people."
Under Charles C. Conaway, the former chief executive who left Kmart last year, it was positioned as a source for mothers to buy products for their homes and families. Under James B. Adamson, who succeeded Mr. Conaway, it experimented with new store formats and strategies. 
Kmart represents an unusual foray into a distressed business for Mr. Lampert and ESL Partners. "We've always tried to invest in companies that were doing pretty well," he said. "In this case, you had a situation where there was a pretty big disconnect between what we thought Kmart could be in the marketplace and what was actually happening."
As Kmart moves ahead, he said, there will be no excuses. "It will have to perform, and we think it will."

HEADLINE: Bush's Budget Chief Leaving, Most Likely for Indiana Race 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6 

 BODY:
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr. said today that he was stepping down as the White House budget director, and Republicans said he was all but certain to return to his home state, Indiana, to run for governor.
 His resignation, effective in 30 days, completes an overhaul in the top ranks of President Bush's original economic team, including the forced departure late last year of Paul H. O'Neill as Treasury secretary and Lawrence B. Lindsey as director of the National Economic Council. 
 Mr. Daniels, in contrast, had remained a favorite of the president, who called him Blade for his budget-cutting fervor. Last month the president, Vice President Dick Cheney and Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff, walked into a meeting with Mr. Daniels in the Roosevelt Room, across the hall from the Oval Office, wearing buttons saying "My Man Mitch," teasing the budget director about the effort by some Republicans in Indiana to draft him to run for governor. 
"He has been a really good watchdog of the taxpayers' money," Mr. Bush told reporters today. "I'm going to miss him. On the other hand, this administration's loss is the gain of the people of Indiana."
Mr. Daniels was much less popular on Capitol Hill, where he made enemies in both parties with his sometimes acerbic advocacy of limited government and his efforts to pry from Congress additional power over spending.
But while he has been a champion of holding down spending, the expenses of fighting and defending against terrorism led him to shepherd through Congress some of the biggest increases in decades. Despite his reputation as tightfisted, he oversaw the budget during a period when it swung from huge projected surpluses to large deficits, and he will be leaving Washington as Democrats step up their attacks on what they describe as the White House's fiscal mismanagement. 
In an interview tonight, Mr. Daniels said he did not want to talk about his plans or confirm that he would run for governor. "I'm going to give President Bush 30 more days of hard work," he said. "Then I'm going to load up the car and think about the future when I get home."
There was no word from the White House on a successor. Initial speculation centered on Mr. Daniels's deputy, Clay Johnson, one of Mr. Bush's oldest friends, though some administration officials said the president was likely to consider candidates with deeper experience in the complex policy and politics of the budget.
Republican Party officials in Indiana said Mr. Daniels had not made a formal decision to enter the 2004 race for governor. But they said that they expected him to do so and that if he did, he would be a formidable candidate in a state that has been reliably Republican in presidential politics but where Democrats have been strong in statewide races.
"Mitch has the intellectual ability, the political acumen and the business management experience to move Indiana into the 21st century," said Jim Kittle, chairman of the Indiana Republican Party.
Mr. Kittle -- who ended a telephone interview this morning by saying he had to take a call from Mr. Daniels -- said he was not offering an endorsement or favoring Mr. Daniels over other Republican candidates. But he said a decision by Mr. Daniels to enter the race would almost certainly lead some of the other Republicans to give way. There are already four declared Republican candidates to replace the Democratic governor, Frank L. O'Bannon, barred by Indiana law from seeking a third term. They include David McIntosh, a former member of Congress who lost to Mr. O'Bannon in 2000 by 15 percentage points.
The Democratic candidates include Joe Andrew, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Vi Simpson, a state senator.
Mr. Daniels has been exploring the possibility of a race for governor for some time, and his long ties to the most popular Republican in Indiana, Senator Richard G. Lugar, would help him mobilize support among party activists and overcome a relatively low public profile. 
Mr. Lugar issued a statement today hinting at support for Mr. Daniels, who worked for him as an aide when Mr. Lugar was mayor of Indianapolis and who then followed him to Washington as a Senate aide.
"I look forward to finding new opportunities in which we can serve the people of Indiana, together, even more effectively," Mr. Lugar said. 
Mr. Daniels has also served as the White House's political director, during the Reagan administration, and later as a senior executive of the pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly & Company, based in Indianapolis. Throughout his time as budget director, he has commuted regularly to his Indianapolis home, where his wife and four daughters lived while he stayed in an undecorated apartment in Washington.
"I've got nothing on the walls, I always say, for two reasons," Mr. Daniels remarked last year. "One, I want the damage deposit back, and secondly, whenever this job is over, I'll be gone quickly."

HEADLINE: BUDGETS IN CRISIS: CENSUS; 
A Wide Income Gap Separates Commuters and City Residents

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to reinstitute a commuter tax may have expired in Albany, but an analysis of new census data suggests that suburbanites who commute to New York City are much better off on average than other New Yorkers and might not have been in a bad position to pay.
 The statistics, analyzed by Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociologist at Queens College, show that people who commute from the New York suburbs to the city make far more money, are more educated and more likely to have jobs in fields like finance, management and the professions. 
 The average suburban commuter earned $75,439, according to the data from the 2000 census released last month. The average for city residents who work in the city was $41,889, and for suburbanites working in the suburbs, $41,031. 
The census also shows that the commuters are more likely than others to be white, male and married. Nearly one in four had an advanced degree, and nearly 55 percent had completed college at a minimum.
Comparable 2000 figures for commuters from New Jersey and Connecticut are not yet available. But the 1990 census shows a similar pattern: people from New Jersey and Connecticut who commuted to New York City made much more than those who did not.
Mr. Bloomberg proposed reinstituting an income tax on commuters last November in an attempt to help close the city's budget deficit for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Gov. George E. Pataki opposed the idea, saying it would be damaging to the economy and would inhibit recovery.
Last week, the State Legislature promised more than $1 billion in new revenue for New York City as part of a budget plan that Mr. Pataki said he would veto. The plan would entail an increase in the sales tax and a temporary surcharge on state residents who make $150,000 or more. It does not include a commuter tax.
Asked whether the census data called into question any suggestion that the tax would impose an inordinate burden on suburban commuters, Joe Conway, the press secretary to Mr. Pataki, said, "The governor has made it clear that given the fragile nature of the economy, he's going to continue looking to other ways to help the city."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Dollar Plunge Accelerates On Worries About Economy
The dollar plunged and the bond market rallied after Federal Reserve policy makers said that the two risks ahead are further economic weakness and, possibly, a sharp fall in inflation. The stock market gave up some gains but finished the day higher.
 Fed policy makers, as expected, left the central bank's benchmark federal funds rate at 1.25 percent. What surprised bond and currency markets was the Fed's concern about prices falling further. Page C9. 

Tax Cut Plans Proceed in Congress
Republican leaders in the Senate offered a tax-cut plan that would temporarily suspend taxes on stock dividends and then reinstate them in three years. The House Ways and Means Committee approved a very different and more costly approach to tax reduction. A28.

Bush Signs Singapore Trade Pact
President Bush signed a free-trade agreement with Singapore, his first since Congress granted him trade promotion authority last summer and the largest since the North American Free Trade Agreement. C4.

Kmart Emerges From Bankruptcy
Kmart, which filed for bankruptcy protection 15 months ago, completed its reorganization, but emerged as a smaller company with an uncertain future. Market Place. C9.

Damages Awarded in Music Suit
The Island Def Jam Music Group and its chief executive were ordered to pay $132 million in damages to an independent record label after a jury found them liable for bad business practices. C5.

Publisher Named for New Magazine
Conde Nast hired Alan Katz, the publisher of New York magazine, to be publisher of a new shopping magazine for men modeled after Lucky, its magazine for women. C5.

Budget Director to Step Down
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., left, will be leaving his job as the White House budget director in 30 days. His resignation completes an overhaul in the top ranks of President Bush's economic team, including the forced departure late last year of Paul H. O'Neill as Treasury secretary and Lawrence B. Lindsey as director of the National Economic Council. A28.

Marriott Wins a Round in Court
A judge in New Orleans has declined to issue a temporary restraining order against Marriott International to prevent it from managing a luxury property in the city. C4.

New Subscribers Bolster EchoStar
EchoStar, owner of the Dish Network satellite TV service, had a first-quarter profit of $58 million after attracting a surge of new subscribers. EchoStar had 8.53 million subscribers at the end of March. C2.

Waste From India Coming to U.S.
Tons of hazardous waste from an abandoned thermometer factory owned by Hindustan Lever, India's largest consumer products company, is heading to a recycling plant in the United States for safe disposal. A13.

Expanded Role Seen for Halliburton
An emergency contract the Bush administration gave Halliburton to extinguish Iraqi oil fires also gave the company a lucrative role in helping repair the country's oil system. C13.

Niche Markets Dominate in Boston
Development in the niche markets of life-science research, academia and hotels is flourishing in Boston. Commercial Real Estate. C6.
